componenttext: Yes. I would say, basically, effectively a 0. I mean, there might be a tad bit of a little carryover. But I think for your modeling purposes, those are pretty much behind us.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then I guess shifting gears, Eric, to the Intermodal segment. You had called out some headwinds in the fourth quarter related to Triple Crown and some sourcing shifts. Can you kind of quantify how we should be thinking about that Triple Crown
componenttext: Got it. And then I guess shifting gears, Eric, to the Intermodal segment. You had called out some headwinds in the fourth quarter related to Triple Crown and some sourcing shifts. Can you kind of quantify how we should be thinking about that Triple Crown headwind for '16 or call out specifically the volume challenge that you guys saw? And should those sourcing shifts that we saw in the fourth quarter continue to weigh on Intermodal load growth for the domestic volumes as we look out?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Rob. As we indicated, we still -- we always expect our highway conversion strategy, which we are firmly focused on, to continue to drive growing domestic Intermodal volumes. And so we continue to see growing domestic Intermodal volumes despite headwi
componenttext: Yes, Rob. As we indicated, we still -- we always expect our highway conversion strategy, which we are firmly focused on, to continue to drive growing domestic Intermodal volumes. And so we continue to see growing domestic Intermodal volumes despite headwinds from Triple Crown and other things that occur all the time. We do expect, as I called out, to see headwinds on the international Intermodal side just because of all of what's going on with the Trans-Pacific trade in the China markets. But on the domestic Intermodal side, we continue to see our strategy working, which is growing volumes through highway conversions.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brandon Oglenski from Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brandon Oglenski from Barclays.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Lance or Eric, I mean, can you guys just give us some context here? Because I've only been covering the industry for about a decade. But the volumes seem pretty bad right now. I mean, maybe not quite as bad as 2009. And yet, we're still getting jobs growt
componenttext: Lance or Eric, I mean, can you guys just give us some context here? Because I've only been covering the industry for about a decade. But the volumes seem pretty bad right now. I mean, maybe not quite as bad as 2009. And yet, we're still getting jobs growth in the U.S. So how do you look at the environment very right now? Is the U.S. headed into a broader recession? Or is this just limited to energy and industrial? And are there specifics in your business that maybe look worse than the broader economy?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, Brandon, this is Lance. The impact on our railroad has been acute, as you point out, in energy, in commodities affected by the strong dollar like export grain, the steel markets. And those are not necessarily indicative of a broader U.S. reality. I
componenttext: Look, Brandon, this is Lance. The impact on our railroad has been acute, as you point out, in energy, in commodities affected by the strong dollar like export grain, the steel markets. And those are not necessarily indicative of a broader U.S. reality. I will share with you, though, there's also questions that we have about U.S. consumers. There are indicators that the consumer's healthy, like the unemployment rate is at a comfortable 5% level, the consumers are buying automobiles, as Eric outlined. But labor participation rate isn't that great, and fourth quarter retail sales for goods was not that great. So I'll let Eric give you a little more technicolor.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm not sure there's much else I would add to that. I would say the consumer is spending. There is consumer confidence. Household income is going up. There appears to be a shift between consuming on products of goods to spending on services. There do
componenttext: Yes, I'm not sure there's much else I would add to that. I would say the consumer is spending. There is consumer confidence. Household income is going up. There appears to be a shift between consuming on products of goods to spending on services. There does appear to be that shift. So it does -- some of the changes is impacting our business in the industrial space.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Brandon, one last thing. Early in the year, we talked about the impact on energy from low natural gas prices and the effect on coal, the effect on crude oil and natural gas exploration and development. And we said, ultimately, that should be a benefi
componenttext: Yes, Brandon, one last thing. Early in the year, we talked about the impact on energy from low natural gas prices and the effect on coal, the effect on crude oil and natural gas exploration and development. And we said, ultimately, that should be a benefit to other industries that we serve, like plastics manufacturing and consumers. And we just haven't seen yet the offset -- the positive offset from the headwinds that we've experienced.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I know it's difficult for a lot of investors on the line here too. Look, Rob, can you talk a little bit about the outlook for an improving operating ratio? What are the big drivers here, especially with the uncertainty on volume?
componenttext: Well, I know it's difficult for a lot of investors on the line here too. Look, Rob, can you talk a little bit about the outlook for an improving operating ratio? What are the big drivers here, especially with the uncertainty on volume?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the big driver -- I mean, volume, obviously, is our friend. And I guided, as you picked up, that we expect full year volume to be slightly down. We'd obviously like to see that improve from there. But given that slightly down sort of view of the worl
componenttext: Yes, the big driver -- I mean, volume, obviously, is our friend. And I guided, as you picked up, that we expect full year volume to be slightly down. We'd obviously like to see that improve from there. But given that slightly down sort of view of the world in a positive and improving operating ratio is our conviction around our ability and our focus on continuing to drive productivity, and our ability to continue to provide quality service to our customers enables us to get price in the marketplace.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Chris Wetherbee with Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Chris Wetherbee with Citigroup.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Want to touch a little bit on the outlook, or stay on the outlook for 2016. Rob, I know you don't give earnings guidance specifically, but if you can get sort of slightly down volumes, you have an improving OR, mix is going to be negative, certainly, in t
componenttext: Want to touch a little bit on the outlook, or stay on the outlook for 2016. Rob, I know you don't give earnings guidance specifically, but if you can get sort of slightly down volumes, you have an improving OR, mix is going to be negative, certainly, in the first quarter or so of the year. I mean, how do we think about the other puts and takes that potentially sort of impact that, whether you're sort of flat to down or flat to up. I'm just trying to make sure I understand how much you can control on the expense side to maybe offset some of this negative mix that we're expecting.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Chris. I mean, and the reason that I'm not giving earnings guidance is because of all those unknowns. Again, we will -- we're confident we can control what we can control, which again is the productivity, quality service, continue to drive positive p
componenttext: Yes, Chris. I mean, and the reason that I'm not giving earnings guidance is because of all those unknowns. Again, we will -- we're confident we can control what we can control, which again is the productivity, quality service, continue to drive positive price. But there is so much uncertainty at this point in time in terms of what the absolute volumes will be and what the mix of those volumes will play out. So that's why we're not at a position right now to give earnings guidance. But I assure you, we're focused on driving improvement on every aspect that we can, and we certainly would like to see as positive of results as we can drive.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then maybe just to follow up on that. In terms of the expense side, what you can control, you talked about headcount a little bit in the outlook, and I think you said it would be down a bit. I guess you're entering the year with a down, a little
componenttext: Okay. And then maybe just to follow up on that. In terms of the expense side, what you can control, you talked about headcount a little bit in the outlook, and I think you said it would be down a bit. I guess you're entering the year with a down, a little bit more than that and kind of try to chase that volume number down. I mean, how do we think about sort of headcount for the full year in a little bit more detail?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, Chris, as we've said all along, and I'll say it here again for 2016, is that volume will drive what our headcount ultimately is, although there's still productivity. So the volumes are slightly down. I would expect that we would have down hea
componenttext: Yes. I mean, Chris, as we've said all along, and I'll say it here again for 2016, is that volume will drive what our headcount ultimately is, although there's still productivity. So the volumes are slightly down. I would expect that we would have down headcount, driven by volume and layering on our expectation of driving further productivity. So it will flow with -- directionally, with what volume is. But we're very focused -- again, depending on what the mix actually plays out -- very focused on driving productivity in those numbers and being as efficient as we can.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chris, we outlined for you the expectations for volumes in the first quarter in a few specific areas. I would say we're in a much better posture entering 2016 from a realizing productivity and a headcount perspective, getting the resources right for the v
componenttext: Chris, we outlined for you the expectations for volumes in the first quarter in a few specific areas. I would say we're in a much better posture entering 2016 from a realizing productivity and a headcount perspective, getting the resources right for the volumes than we were entering 2015. We're just in a very different place.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Allison Landry with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Allison Landry with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So following up on the previous question. How much of a volume decline do you think that you can handle while still generating positive earnings growth? You did mention expectations for a slight decline, but if carloads track down 5%, 6%, 7%, is that sort
componenttext: So following up on the previous question. How much of a volume decline do you think that you can handle while still generating positive earnings growth? You did mention expectations for a slight decline, but if carloads track down 5%, 6%, 7%, is that sort of where you're thinking about the tipping point?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Allison, this is Rob. I mean, I can't give you and not giving guidance on the earnings. So I mean, I get the point of your question. But really, the driver will be what's the mix, what volumes actually move and et cetera. But I can just assure you that th
componenttext: Allison, this is Rob. I mean, I can't give you and not giving guidance on the earnings. So I mean, I get the point of your question. But really, the driver will be what's the mix, what volumes actually move and et cetera. But I can just assure you that there is obviously a tipping point at some point where if that were to go so negative, it would flip negative. But we're going to squeeze out productivity and continue to drive price where we can. And so I can't give you a direct answer as to where that tipping point is. But we're focused on, regardless of what the volume is, on controlling what we can and driving positive OR and earnings.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And my second question would be what your expectations for overall cost inflation are for 2016?
componenttext: Understood. And my second question would be what your expectations for overall cost inflation are for 2016?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As I said, Allison, overall inflation assumptions for us in 2016 are around 2%.
componenttext: Yes. As I said, Allison, overall inflation assumptions for us in 2016 are around 2%.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Scott Group with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Scott Group with Wolfe Research.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rob, just wanted to clarify a few things that you said. In terms of headcount down slightly or something like that, I mean we're going to be starting the year down 9%-or-so year-over-year. Are you talking about down slightly from kind of where you're endi
componenttext: Rob, just wanted to clarify a few things that you said. In terms of headcount down slightly or something like that, I mean we're going to be starting the year down 9%-or-so year-over-year. Are you talking about down slightly from kind of where you're ending the year at that 44,500 level?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Basically, that guidance or that view of the world, Scott, where I say it's slightly down, is a year-over-year assumption at this point in time. And again, full year. And again, what will drive that is what the ultimate volumes end up being.
componenttext: Basically, that guidance or that view of the world, Scott, where I say it's slightly down, is a year-over-year assumption at this point in time. And again, full year. And again, what will drive that is what the ultimate volumes end up being.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, just a little point of detail. At the tail end of many years, there's a lot of moving parts that affect headcount, the absolute headcount number. That average is the one that's most useful.
componenttext: Scott, just a little point of detail. At the tail end of many years, there's a lot of moving parts that affect headcount, the absolute headcount number. That average is the one that's most useful.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So are you thinking about adding headcounts from where you are right now? Because if you take where you are right now, I mean, it should imply a pretty meaningful drop in headcount.
componenttext: So are you thinking about adding headcounts from where you are right now? Because if you take where you are right now, I mean, it should imply a pretty meaningful drop in headcount.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're going to continue to match headcount to whatever the volume situation is. The other thing to note is headcount comes in and out on capital programs. As, for instance, in the wintertime, we start shutting down capital spend because of weather and spo
componenttext: We're going to continue to match headcount to whatever the volume situation is. The other thing to note is headcount comes in and out on capital programs. As, for instance, in the wintertime, we start shutting down capital spend because of weather and spooling it back up in the spring. There's just a lot of moving parts quarter-to-quarter sequentially.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. In terms of pricing, wanted to ask. So, I think, BN has talked about giving up some price to incent some coal demand. Are you guys doing anything similar like that? And maybe if you can talk overall on pricing, it sounds like you expect solid pricin
componenttext: Okay. In terms of pricing, wanted to ask. So, I think, BN has talked about giving up some price to incent some coal demand. Are you guys doing anything similar like that? And maybe if you can talk overall on pricing, it sounds like you expect solid pricing in '16. Should -- is it reasonable to expect some kind of deceleration in the pricing environment, just given what the volumes are doing? Or can we -- do you think we can hold steady around this 3% range ex legacy?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, this is Eric. So I cannot speak to what the BN does with pricing strategy. They do their own independent strategy, and I cannot speak to what they do. We continue to hold on our strategy of pricing to our value. We are driving a value proposition t
componenttext: Scott, this is Eric. So I cannot speak to what the BN does with pricing strategy. They do their own independent strategy, and I cannot speak to what they do. We continue to hold on our strategy of pricing to our value. We are driving a value proposition that we want to be an industry superior value proposition, and we're going to price accordingly for that. We do think that there are places in the market, in the economy, that are growing there. And we think that those provide value for us to continue to price according to our long-held strategy.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Alex Vecchio with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Alex Vecchio with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rob, I know you didn't give explicit earnings guidance. But in the past 2 years, you had noted in your slide deck record earnings, and that was note -- that comment was notably absent this time around. So I just want to confirm that we should interpret th
componenttext: Rob, I know you didn't give explicit earnings guidance. But in the past 2 years, you had noted in your slide deck record earnings, and that was note -- that comment was notably absent this time around. So I just want to confirm that we should interpret the lack of that expectation for record earnings to be what it is. That you won't -- at this point, you do not expect to achieve at least the $5.75 in earnings per share that you had achieved in 2014, which was the last record. I just want to confirm you're essentially expecting this year to be below that figure.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That is correct. Now nothing would please us more than to see the economy turn and things kind of go favorable. So we're going to fight like heck to do the best we can. But yes, you are correct, at this point in time, we do not see record earnings.
componenttext: That is correct. Now nothing would please us more than to see the economy turn and things kind of go favorable. So we're going to fight like heck to do the best we can. But yes, you are correct, at this point in time, we do not see record earnings.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then just to touch back on the pricing discussion. You noted that you expect inflation to be 2% in 2016. In the past, you've always kind of suggested nominal pricing above inflation. Is that still your expectation for 2016, to ac
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then just to touch back on the pricing discussion. You noted that you expect inflation to be 2% in 2016. In the past, you've always kind of suggested nominal pricing above inflation. Is that still your expectation for 2016, to achieve pricing above that 2% inflation level?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. But as you know, we don't set our prices based on what current year inflation numbers are. And as has been pointed out and we've discussed here today, we price to market. Every market's a little bit different. We clearly don't have the benefit of cal
componenttext: Yes. But as you know, we don't set our prices based on what current year inflation numbers are. And as has been pointed out and we've discussed here today, we price to market. Every market's a little bit different. We clearly don't have the benefit of call it 0.5 point legacy renewal that we'd enjoy in 2016. But having said all of that, yes, we're still focused on pricing above inflation.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Tom Wadewitz with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Tom Wadewitz with UBS.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd wanted to ask you a little bit about the volume side. So you've commented on first quarter, and I think Eric, in his slide, with the 2016 outlook, gave us the view by segment. If I look at that view by segment, it's either kind of plus and minus or I
componenttext: I'd wanted to ask you a little bit about the volume side. So you've commented on first quarter, and I think Eric, in his slide, with the 2016 outlook, gave us the view by segment. If I look at that view by segment, it's either kind of plus and minus or I guess, for Coal, it's minus, minus. But it seems like, by segment, it's pretty negative. But on a full year basis, you're saying it's down only slightly. So I assume slightly is not down 3% or 4%, it's maybe down 1% or 2%. What -- how do you kind of bridge those 2 together? Is it just a function of the comps getting so much easier in the second quarter? Or are you expecting, kind of adjusted for seasonality, improvement in demand later in the year? Or how do you put those 2 together? Because the -- kind of by segment, it looks a little more negative than the comment about a slight decline on a full year basis.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me just start off and Eric may want to comment further in term of maybe more specifics. But this is Rob. I would just say that, Tom, to your point, we clearly are highlighting and as you know, that the comp, particularly in the first quarter, is parti
componenttext: Let me just start off and Eric may want to comment further in term of maybe more specifics. But this is Rob. I would just say that, Tom, to your point, we clearly are highlighting and as you know, that the comp, particularly in the first quarter, is particularly challenging. And that's why we're calling out the down volume in the first quarter and coal clearly in the 20%-or-so range. So the comps do change throughout the year. But our view of the world right now is that the energy environment, which impacts our coal, impacts our shale, impacts our metals, it supports the shale activity on top of the continuing strong dollar, those are going to continue to be hurdles and pressures for us. But the comps do change as the year plays out, and I think that's what's driving sort of maybe the math that you're wrestling with.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Eric, do you got anything else to add to that?
componenttext: Eric, do you got anything else to add to that?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, that's it.
componenttext: No, that's it.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you would say it's more comps than anticipation of improved market later in the year?
componenttext: So you would say it's more comps than anticipation of improved market later in the year?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I said that's a bigger driver.
componenttext: I said that's a bigger driver.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Okay, I appreciate that. What about mix? If I look at your slides in the third quarter, mix, I think, was a 1% year-over-year headwind. And that got a lot more challenging in fourth quarter, which I think was the big thing we missed in our assumption
componenttext: Yes. Okay, I appreciate that. What about mix? If I look at your slides in the third quarter, mix, I think, was a 1% year-over-year headwind. And that got a lot more challenging in fourth quarter, which I think was the big thing we missed in our assumptions for fourth quarter with that 4% mix headwind. I know it's a tough one to forecast, but is -- do you think mix in 2016 is more like the 4% or more like the 1%? Is that a pretty material consideration?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Tom, this is Rob again. I would say, again, as you know, we don't -- it's very difficult, in fact, frankly impossible to precisely predict exactly what mix is going to be. But I would say just sort of directionally, if you look at the full year mix i
componenttext: Yes. Tom, this is Rob again. I would say, again, as you know, we don't -- it's very difficult, in fact, frankly impossible to precisely predict exactly what mix is going to be. But I would say just sort of directionally, if you look at the full year mix impact in 2015, it was about 1.5 points negative. And you're right, the fourth quarter was particularly bad at -- down -- at 4 [ph]. We do expect to still see mix headwinds as 2016 plays out. I don't anticipate that it would be, for the full year, as bad as we saw in the fourth quarter. We do have a comp challenge in the first quarter. But as the year plays out, things should get easier. And while mix will be a headwind for the full year, it should sort of get better than what we saw in the first quarter -- we'll see in the first quarter and what we saw in the fourth quarter of last year.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Recall, Tom, first quarter of 2015, we grew fracs and shipments. Coal was still relatively healthy; grain was healthier than what we saw as the year progressed than the later quarter. So markets have really changed pretty dramatically from the first
componenttext: Yes. Recall, Tom, first quarter of 2015, we grew fracs and shipments. Coal was still relatively healthy; grain was healthier than what we saw as the year progressed than the later quarter. So markets have really changed pretty dramatically from the first quarter of 2015.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the mix comps might be similar to the volume comps that they get a bit easier beyond the first quarter maybe was the question.
componenttext: So the mix comps might be similar to the volume comps that they get a bit easier beyond the first quarter maybe was the question.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll see.
componenttext: We'll see.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jason Seidl of Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jason Seidl of Cowen and Company.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to go back to -- on the pricing side and focus on Intermodal and any of the truck competitive merchandise traffic that you're hauling. Clearly, right now, it seems that there's excess trucking capacity. And all the data points, at least we track, a
componenttext: I want to go back to -- on the pricing side and focus on Intermodal and any of the truck competitive merchandise traffic that you're hauling. Clearly, right now, it seems that there's excess trucking capacity. And all the data points, at least we track, are pointing to truck pricing going down, both contractually and on the spot basis. How should we look at your ability to not only price but grow the Intermodal business ex some of the headwinds that we talked about with Triple Crown as we move throughout 2016?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Eric, Jason. So a big reason, as you know, for kind of the shrinkage in truck pricing is fuel is coming down, which is a major cause. So our customers are also seeing a cost reduction benefit as fuel goes down because of the fuel surcharge go
componenttext: Yes. This is Eric, Jason. So a big reason, as you know, for kind of the shrinkage in truck pricing is fuel is coming down, which is a major cause. So our customers are also seeing a cost reduction benefit as fuel goes down because of the fuel surcharge going down. So they're seeing that natural cost reduction benefit. So the gap, if you will, between the value proposition for intermodal rail service versus truck, I think, that gap is still there in terms of intermodal providing a value proposition to manufacturers. We've talked in the past about, just by laws of physics, steel wheel on steel rail is a lower cost than rubber tire on asphalt or concrete. So there still is a value proposition there that we think gives us a leverage to continue to drive highway conversions, which we demonstrated in '15 and we're going to continue to focus on in '16.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Eric, your team continually works with trucking companies themselves in terms of helping them with their cost structures and they look at intermodal conversions as an opportunity to modify their own cost structures as they compete in their marketplace
componenttext: And Eric, your team continually works with trucking companies themselves in terms of helping them with their cost structures and they look at intermodal conversions as an opportunity to modify their own cost structures as they compete in their marketplace, and that -- those opportunities continue as well.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. No, that's good color. As I look on the ag side, it seemed like there was a couple of puts and takes. But net-net for the year, would you guys say you were positive or slightly negative for ag?
componenttext: Okay. No, that's good color. As I look on the ag side, it seemed like there was a couple of puts and takes. But net-net for the year, would you guys say you were positive or slightly negative for ag?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Eric?
componenttext: Eric?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure I understand the question or...
componenttext: I'm not sure I understand the question or...

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of your outlook for '16?
componenttext: In terms of your outlook for '16?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oh, we don't give volume guidance for '16. I think if you look at the ag markets overall, I think the ag producers are expecting pretty good yields for 2016, of course, dependent on weather and number of acres planted and all of that, maybe not record lev
componenttext: Oh, we don't give volume guidance for '16. I think if you look at the ag markets overall, I think the ag producers are expecting pretty good yields for 2016, of course, dependent on weather and number of acres planted and all of that, maybe not record levels but pretty good levels. I think a large factor will depend on worldwide ag production, the strong dollar and how competitive U.S. ag is in worldwide market. There is a lot of corn, a lot of wheat in storage right now. And presumably, as U.S. ag becomes more competitive pricing wise in worldwide markets, that's got to move. And when that does move, presumably, we, as a transportation provider, will have a benefit then moving it.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is coming from the line of Ken Hoexter with Bank of America.
componenttext: The next question is coming from the line of Ken Hoexter with Bank of America.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Lance, I want to revisit one of the earlier questions in terms of looking back in market downturns and looking at the volumes. How do you figure out how to stay ahead of that in terms of furloughing employees and cutting locomotor -- or dropping locomotiv
componenttext: Lance, I want to revisit one of the earlier questions in terms of looking back in market downturns and looking at the volumes. How do you figure out how to stay ahead of that in terms of furloughing employees and cutting locomotor -- or dropping locomotives in terms of them being not -- I guess, not overdoing it so you can catch that rebound? How have you acted differently this time versus whether it was at the end of '14 and beginning of '15 when we ramped up maybe too much and then versus what you saw in '08, '09? Maybe can you give us a little feedback in terms of how you prep for that.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Ken. We've been clear historically about time lags and decisions that are just the nature of our business in terms of hiring somebody to operate a train. That's about a 6-month process. So we have to, by nature, when we're planning crews, look out 6
componenttext: Sure, Ken. We've been clear historically about time lags and decisions that are just the nature of our business in terms of hiring somebody to operate a train. That's about a 6-month process. So we have to, by nature, when we're planning crews, look out 6, 12, 18 months. And when we're talking about capital planning or locomotive acquisition, those lead times get longer. So it all begins with our business planning process and making sure that we have tight connectivity between what Eric and the commercial team are seeing and then how we're boiling that into a transportation plan and the resources necessary to run it. Every time we see a significant shift in volume, whether it's significant growth or a significant shrink, we try to learn from that situation. As we're going into 2016, we think our business planning process is tighter. We think our connectivity between what Eric sees in the marketplace and secondary and tertiary indicators of demand, more of that is being absorbed into our estimating process. And so -- and I shouldn't miss the opportunity to talk about also doing a better job of shrinking some of the time lines, let's say, in terms of hiring and bringing a crew on board or acquiring equipment. We're also better, candidly, at -- when we have to store equipment, storing it quickly and efficiently. And we're also better at trying to find the right mix of the right employee base, where they're located and training them for alternative jobs. So we're just getting a little better in all those ways, and that adds up, I think, into a better posture overall.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And to clarify that, you don't see that as rounding into like the 2008, '09, not that deep of a recession, but into -- I guess, so far what you see doesn't seem recession environment to you?
componenttext: And to clarify that, you don't see that as rounding into like the 2008, '09, not that deep of a recession, but into -- I guess, so far what you see doesn't seem recession environment to you?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wait, Ken. It's hard for me to speak and predict on whether the economy is going into a recession. Certainly, our volumes drop off as the 2015 year progressed quarter-to-quarter. And as we're entering 2016, is dramatic, and it's dramatic in a historical r
componenttext: Wait, Ken. It's hard for me to speak and predict on whether the economy is going into a recession. Certainly, our volumes drop off as the 2015 year progressed quarter-to-quarter. And as we're entering 2016, is dramatic, and it's dramatic in a historical reference. But it's nothing -- it's not approaching what we experienced in 2008 to 2009. Although again, a 6% decrease year-over-year and a quarterly 6%, 7%, 8%, 9% decrease year-over-year is pretty dramatic volume change.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. If I could do the follow-up just to quickly comment, I guess, yesterday or a couple of days ago, one of the other rails noted your quotes on M&A and said that, I guess, prior, you had talked about how it impacted Union Pacific and you were opposed
componenttext: Great. If I could do the follow-up just to quickly comment, I guess, yesterday or a couple of days ago, one of the other rails noted your quotes on M&A and said that, I guess, prior, you had talked about how it impacted Union Pacific and you were opposed to that. Can -- maybe can you clarify your comments on your thoughts on industry M&A, why it would or would not matter to you given you're operating in your own region? And does it, an industry change, impact Union Pacific?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Ken, we do not support mergers or consolidation in the current environment. We think that the regulatory outcomes, the regulatory impact would be substantial. The Surface Transportation Board has been clear that in the next merger that they consider,
componenttext: Yes. Ken, we do not support mergers or consolidation in the current environment. We think that the regulatory outcomes, the regulatory impact would be substantial. The Surface Transportation Board has been clear that in the next merger that they consider, it has to enhance competition, not just maintain it. It has to improve operations for customers and they also have to consider downstream impacts, whether one merger triggers a string of consolidations. We've shared with you, we're focused on safety, we're focused on efficiency, we're focused on an excellent customer experience. We don't think a merger enhances those efforts. As a matter of fact, we think it would have a negative impact on service and be a headwind, be disincentive to capital investment.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Ossenbeck with JPMorgan Chase.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Ossenbeck with JPMorgan Chase.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So obviously, one area of growth, in your view, looks like it's going to continue into next year. But how much of that is attributable to Mexico? And what type of impact do you see when it comes to -- we're seeing some reported first half retoolings and c
componenttext: So obviously, one area of growth, in your view, looks like it's going to continue into next year. But how much of that is attributable to Mexico? And what type of impact do you see when it comes to -- we're seeing some reported first half retoolings and changeovers south of the border. And do you think this would really have an impact on your length of haul or mix of business in that vertical?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brian, before I hand it over to Eric, I just want to say we are very bullish on Mexico in general in the long term. It's a vibrant economy, it's got a vibrant middle class. And our access to the 6 primary rail gateways to and from Mexico give us a real gr
componenttext: Brian, before I hand it over to Eric, I just want to say we are very bullish on Mexico in general in the long term. It's a vibrant economy, it's got a vibrant middle class. And our access to the 6 primary rail gateways to and from Mexico give us a real great opportunity to participate in that economy. Eric?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Brian. Historically, Mexico produced about 1.7 million vehicles. I think full year 2015, the number is probably close to about 2.9 million vehicles, up call it 17.5% [ph] that was sold. With all of the planned expansions, new plants, I think it's on
componenttext: Yes, Brian. Historically, Mexico produced about 1.7 million vehicles. I think full year 2015, the number is probably close to about 2.9 million vehicles, up call it 17.5% [ph] that was sold. With all of the planned expansions, new plants, I think it's on its way to 4 million or 4.5 million in the next, call it 1.5 years to 2 years. As it's been said, we have a great franchise for Mexico, and we think that, that will be a strong part of our business portfolio going into the future. As always, the issue is when the sales drive total volume and so our total volume will be aligned with whatever sales are. And our strategy is to have a franchise to move it wherever it is manufactured.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Just quick on that, was it -- about 60% of your auto comes from -- is attributable to Mexico, I'm remembering exactly?
componenttext: Okay. Just quick on that, was it -- about 60% of your auto comes from -- is attributable to Mexico, I'm remembering exactly?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Historically, we've said that, yes, and that's about what it was, yes.
componenttext: Historically, we've said that, yes, and that's about what it was, yes.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just one other quick one on train lengths. I think on the last call, you mentioned you have about 90% or about 7,000-foot capable on, I guess, in terms of sidings. Third quarter is around 6,000-foot average train lengths of -- clearly, you'
componenttext: Okay. And then just one other quick one on train lengths. I think on the last call, you mentioned you have about 90% or about 7,000-foot capable on, I guess, in terms of sidings. Third quarter is around 6,000-foot average train lengths of -- clearly, you're highlighting some of the best-ever lengths in 3 of the 5 areas. How much further and I guess, how much faster do you think you can take that up? And when would you hit the upper limit? I know it's different in every market. And I guess, the Intermodal's clearly got some headwinds here. But I think that's really the one for good economics to really work. That's the one you really need to get the longer trains. So maybe if you could focus on that and just some general comments about train lengths overall.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Cam, do you want out to talk a little bit about the productivity opportunity in train length?
componenttext: Cam, do you want out to talk a little bit about the productivity opportunity in train length?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Coal is about the only program that is nearly optimized, although there is opportunities still within coal. Every other commodity group has plenty of train size productivity opportunity. And you will see us continue to make progress, balancing customer ne
componenttext: Coal is about the only program that is nearly optimized, although there is opportunities still within coal. Every other commodity group has plenty of train size productivity opportunity. And you will see us continue to make progress, balancing customer needs along the way.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Matt Troy with Nomura Asset Management.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Matt Troy with Nomura Asset Management.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: A quick question about coal. Specifically, a lot of pushback we get from investors with respect to UNP specifically as you have a competitor who, due to some service issues and perhaps a much larger portfolio strategy, has invested a significant amount in
componenttext: A quick question about coal. Specifically, a lot of pushback we get from investors with respect to UNP specifically as you have a competitor who, due to some service issues and perhaps a much larger portfolio strategy, has invested a significant amount in CapEx out west. And there's concern given this structural market share loss in coal that a competitive dynamic has structurally changed in their favor. If I look at a 20-year market share chart of coal, you and the BN used to swap share and were about 50% each every year. And then in 2011, we saw a split and then again in 2014. So there's been roughly a 10% shift where what used to be 50-50 is now 60-40. I was wondering if you could just put some color around that. I know that there were service issues on your line last year. But even if I normalize for that spike, the line and the trend is pretty consistent over a 5-year basis. I'm just wondering how you can address structurally investor concerns that something hasn't changed in the West as it relates to Coal.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Matt, I think if you go back historically and go back to the '80s when really, the Powder River Basin franchise was developed for us certainly, in addition to our competitor, I think, it's been roughly, call it, a 55-45 split over time and -- as oppo
componenttext: Yes. Matt, I think if you go back historically and go back to the '80s when really, the Powder River Basin franchise was developed for us certainly, in addition to our competitor, I think, it's been roughly, call it, a 55-45 split over time and -- as opposed to the 50-50. But we don't look at markets in terms of what share we have in our market. We look at it in terms of what's the value of that market, what's the value of our franchise, where we think we have value, our value proposition to offer the market and we sell [ph] our value proposition. And we're comfortable with the outcome in terms of the business that we win or lose based on the value proposition that we sell.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. So I guess, again, in the context of people choosing to invest or not invest in your stock, if I look at the economy in volumes, Burlington Northern, positive on volumes last year in coal; Union Pacific, down double digit in coal, you're saying you
componenttext: Right. So I guess, again, in the context of people choosing to invest or not invest in your stock, if I look at the economy in volumes, Burlington Northern, positive on volumes last year in coal; Union Pacific, down double digit in coal, you're saying you are comfortable with that?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: What we're comfortable with, Matt, is the diversity of our franchise. Coal remains a nice book of business for us, generates an attractive return. That's how we look at all of our book of business in terms of can we generate an attractive return, and we i
componenttext: What we're comfortable with, Matt, is the diversity of our franchise. Coal remains a nice book of business for us, generates an attractive return. That's how we look at all of our book of business in terms of can we generate an attractive return, and we invest for that and we price for that. And I think our track record speaks for itself. We've done a pretty fair job of making that happen.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood. My quick follow-up would be then, if I look at cash flow -- you yourself said reducing the CapEx budget by north of $500 million. You've got some other tailwinds, you talked about bonus depreciation. It's pretty material numbers in terms
componenttext: Okay, understood. My quick follow-up would be then, if I look at cash flow -- you yourself said reducing the CapEx budget by north of $500 million. You've got some other tailwinds, you talked about bonus depreciation. It's pretty material numbers in terms of incremental cash flow potential. You slowed the pacing of share repurchases in the fourth quarter. Just wondering, with that excess potential cash flow in 2016, is there an opportunity to step up share repurchases? What are the gating factors in terms of either debt ratios or what not, in terms of how aggressively you're willing to use what should be some surplus cash flow in 2016?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rob, do you want to take that?
componenttext: Rob, do you want to take that?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Matt, you're right. I mean, our expectations coming off of certainly last year's low number from cash flow that we will hopefully positively generate increasing cash flow. And yes, we'll continue our philosophy of being opportunistic in the marketpla
componenttext: Yes. Matt, you're right. I mean, our expectations coming off of certainly last year's low number from cash flow that we will hopefully positively generate increasing cash flow. And yes, we'll continue our philosophy of being opportunistic in the marketplace as it relates to shares. So I would expect that we will continue to do that. And as I called out, by the way, in the third quarter, that was a high watermark, if you will, that we've seen, at least in modern times, of a rate of which we were buying back shares, and that clearly was not our ratable rate in terms of shares. But we are opportunistic in terms of when we buy and how much we buy, and that attitude and that philosophy will continue in 2016. But if we can generate stronger levels of cash that gives us greater opportunities. And as we continue to walk up our debt-to-EBITDA, as we said and as we have, that gives us further opportunity.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, job one is generating cash from operations. It all starts there and we're laser-focused on that.
componenttext: Yes, job one is generating cash from operations. It all starts there and we're laser-focused on that.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from the line of John Barnes with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: The next question is from the line of John Barnes with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So following up on that, that question around cap or cash flow, I hear what you're saying in terms of your opposition to M&A. But if it were to take place -- Burlington Northern has already said that they're going to be involved if there is a wave of cons
componenttext: So following up on that, that question around cap or cash flow, I hear what you're saying in terms of your opposition to M&A. But if it were to take place -- Burlington Northern has already said that they're going to be involved if there is a wave of consolidation. Given the cash flow that you're looking at generating in 2016, do you feel the need to maintain some of that as dry powder in the event that you are forced to react to a consolidation wave in the sector?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, in addition to saying we don't support rail mergers at this time, we've also said we're paying close attention to the situation. We're monitoring it. And as things evolve, we'll do what's in the best interest of our shareholders and our stakeholders
componenttext: John, in addition to saying we don't support rail mergers at this time, we've also said we're paying close attention to the situation. We're monitoring it. And as things evolve, we'll do what's in the best interest of our shareholders and our stakeholders. If you look at our capital structure, we're in a solid position strategically if we were -- if we had to do anything. But John, what we're focused on right now is that in the current environment, we think mergers are not in the interest of our customers and just monitoring that and keeping close tabs on it.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, all right. And then my follow-up is -- I hate to ask you such a short-term type of question. But Eric, you mentioned in your commentary, from an intermodal risk perspective, record-high inventories and you talked a little bit about your thoughts on
componenttext: Okay, all right. And then my follow-up is -- I hate to ask you such a short-term type of question. But Eric, you mentioned in your commentary, from an intermodal risk perspective, record-high inventories and you talked a little bit about your thoughts on the consumer. We've got the Chinese New Year kind of right around the corner. Normally, there is typically kind of a surge in activity ahead of that. Do you anticipate -- are you hearing from your shipper base, customer base yet that maybe there is some intention to use that period as an opportunity to kind of clear the decks a little bit, maybe clear the baffles on inventory and so you come out of maybe 1Q in a little bit better inventory situation? Or do you anticipate that you will still see maybe that normal pre-Chinese New Year type of surge in Intermodal volumes?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We're hearing nothing specific from our shippers surrounding the Chinese New Year to disclose here. I would say that every BCO is looking at rationalizing their inventories because they exited the holiday season higher than, I think, expected on inve
componenttext: Yes. We're hearing nothing specific from our shippers surrounding the Chinese New Year to disclose here. I would say that every BCO is looking at rationalizing their inventories because they exited the holiday season higher than, I think, expected on inventories with sluggish retail sales, I think, across the board. You hear every customer talking about trying to rightsize their inventories.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Justin Long with Stephens.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Justin Long with Stephens.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could provide more color on the magnitude of the record productivity you noted in your comments. And how much of that is predicated on a slightly down volume environment? In other words, if volumes end up being worse than you expect
componenttext: I was wondering if you could provide more color on the magnitude of the record productivity you noted in your comments. And how much of that is predicated on a slightly down volume environment? In other words, if volumes end up being worse than you expect this year, is record productivity still achievable?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll make one quick comment and that is what we saw in 2015 was both costs coming out because of volume, getting the structure right and a much more fluid network in the second half of the year, generating excellent productivity opportunities.
componenttext: I'll make one quick comment and that is what we saw in 2015 was both costs coming out because of volume, getting the structure right and a much more fluid network in the second half of the year, generating excellent productivity opportunities.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Justin, I would just add -- this is Rob. I would just add that kind of what gives us that confidence, the marker that I would point you to is our improvement in our operating ratio in -- throughout the full year and our confidence that we'll continue
componenttext: Yes. Justin, I would just add -- this is Rob. I would just add that kind of what gives us that confidence, the marker that I would point you to is our improvement in our operating ratio in -- throughout the full year and our confidence that we'll continue to do that. In terms of at what pace we can do it, I mean, we're all about doing it as quickly and as efficiently and safely as we can. But what will drive sort of the timing of that productivity as we move with volumes is going to be the mix effect and the timing of when there are volume changes. And as you know, throughout 2015, the first half, we were kind of chasing volume down and then we were able to sort of take advantage as things neutralized or straightened out a little bit in the back half. And so that will be a factor too in terms of what volume swings may or may not occur. But we're focused on squeezing out productivity as -- on everything we do. And that's all I can -- that I can point you to is that we'll look at every stone and uncover it and look for opportunities.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And I know you're not giving specific EPS guidance for 2016, but just putting together the pieces here, slightly down volumes, core price increases, record productivity, better OR, the benefit of share repurchases, just from a directional sta
componenttext: Okay, great. And I know you're not giving specific EPS guidance for 2016, but just putting together the pieces here, slightly down volumes, core price increases, record productivity, better OR, the benefit of share repurchases, just from a directional standpoint, would it be correct to say that you're thinking about EPS being up year-over-year?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the reason I'm not giving guidance on the earnings is because there are so many uncertainties, of which mix by the way is another headwind I would remind you of that I did call out, and that will dictate, I think, in large part, exactly how this yea
componenttext: Well, the reason I'm not giving guidance on the earnings is because there are so many uncertainties, of which mix by the way is another headwind I would remind you of that I did call out, and that will dictate, I think, in large part, exactly how this year plays out. So with all the uncertainties out there, we're going to certainly focus and fight like heck to take advantage of whatever the economy plays [ph] us to turn in as positive of earnings and returns and cash generation as we can. But we're not giving guidance as to exactly what the earnings will end up being for the year.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Jeff Kauffman with Buckingham Research.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Jeff Kauffman with Buckingham Research.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: A lot of my questions have been answered, but let me come back to the cash flow question, if I can. Could you remind us of where you ideally want to have your debt levels, whether you think about them as a debt to cap or a debt to EBITDA? And when I think
componenttext: A lot of my questions have been answered, but let me come back to the cash flow question, if I can. Could you remind us of where you ideally want to have your debt levels, whether you think about them as a debt to cap or a debt to EBITDA? And when I think about the positives to your 2016 cash flow, you mentioned about $400 million bonus depreciation, about $500 million less spend on CapEx and for better or for worse, with the shares down the way they are, you can buy back shares that won't cost as much to still pitch your numbers on a share repo. When you look at 2016, given the increased uncertainty, are you more likely to say, "Okay, we're going to buy back whatever shares we're going to buy back. But with excess cash flow, we just may not need as much debt to fund it"? Or is your view that you're still underlevered and you're willing to go to higher debt-to-cap levels?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rob?
componenttext: Rob?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Jeff, I would just remind you, the guidance that we've given which we are comfortable with is working towards that debt to EBITDA of 2x. I mean, we've said sort of that's a marker out there. I think we still have a little bit of room from the improve
componenttext: Yes. Jeff, I would just remind you, the guidance that we've given which we are comfortable with is working towards that debt to EBITDA of 2x. I mean, we've said sort of that's a marker out there. I think we still have a little bit of room from the improvement we made on that metric in 2015. So I would expect that we'll continue to march forward, if you will. And as I pointed out, we do expect largely because of the reduction, and we hope to generate stronger cash on the front end. But we also have the benefit of lower CapEx and the benefit of the bonus depreciation that I outlined. So -- and we may do debt this year. I would -- we will look at that. We -- that would not be an unrealistic expectation that you'll see us take on additional debt this year. All of that gives us additional -- it gives us opportunities to generate stronger free cash flow and gives us opportunities to continue to be opportunistic in the marketplace.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And so basically, you were saying we have -- I think you are at 1.7x debt to EBITDA, and you're saying we can go to 2x so we can take on a little bit more debt, but more likely, we would use the cash flow just to fulfill our obligations?
componenttext: Okay. And so basically, you were saying we have -- I think you are at 1.7x debt to EBITDA, and you're saying we can go to 2x so we can take on a little bit more debt, but more likely, we would use the cash flow just to fulfill our obligations?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think Rob said that. I think he said we're going to generate cash, we've got room in our balance sheet and we'll see how the year plays out.
componenttext: I don't think Rob said that. I think he said we're going to generate cash, we've got room in our balance sheet and we'll see how the year plays out.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Ben Hartford with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Ben Hartford with Robert W. Baird.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Eric, could you remind us what your percent of carloads yields are tied to the underlying price of the commodity that it holds?
componenttext: Eric, could you remind us what your percent of carloads yields are tied to the underlying price of the commodity that it holds?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not quite sure what you are asking. If you're asking about our pricing strategy, we don't really talk publicly about our pricing strategy. We have historically said we don't think philosophically that we need to tie transportation to swings, in commod
componenttext: I'm not quite sure what you are asking. If you're asking about our pricing strategy, we don't really talk publicly about our pricing strategy. We have historically said we don't think philosophically that we need to tie transportation to swings, in commodity markets. We've said that philosophically, but we don't talk about our pricing strategy publicly.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's -- I guess, I'm not interested in the strategy specifically. Is there a percentage that you provide of carloads that have the yield component that is specifically tied to the price of the underlying commodity?
componenttext: Yes, it's -- I guess, I'm not interested in the strategy specifically. Is there a percentage that you provide of carloads that have the yield component that is specifically tied to the price of the underlying commodity?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Again, that -- we don't talk publicly about our pricing strategy. We don't talk about what our -- how our prices are developed.
componenttext: Yes. Again, that -- we don't talk publicly about our pricing strategy. We don't talk about what our -- how our prices are developed.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Cleo Zagrean with Macquarie.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Cleo Zagrean with Macquarie.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to talk about mix in terms of length of haul. Actually, length of haul getting shorter this quarter, not just for coal, but also chemicals and industrials. Is there a structural change going on? What are the drivers of that? And where do you see
componenttext: I wanted to talk about mix in terms of length of haul. Actually, length of haul getting shorter this quarter, not just for coal, but also chemicals and industrials. Is there a structural change going on? What are the drivers of that? And where do you see that trend?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Eric, do you want to talk about that?
componenttext: Eric, do you want to talk about that?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our length of haul is down slightly this year. And again, it is the thing that we had been talking about in terms of some of the mix headwinds with our coal business, some of the mix headwinds with our frac sand business, our long whole-grain export busin
componenttext: Our length of haul is down slightly this year. And again, it is the thing that we had been talking about in terms of some of the mix headwinds with our coal business, some of the mix headwinds with our frac sand business, our long whole-grain export business. Those are all mix factors that has impacted our length of haul, which was down slightly this year.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think we see anything structural that's some kind of long-term trend.
componenttext: I don't think we see anything structural that's some kind of long-term trend.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I appreciate that. And then my follow-up is tied to one of your comments earlier that you haven't seen the benefit from low oil prices that -- not just you, but many of us were talking about some kind of silver lining. So what are you hearing from y
componenttext: Okay. I appreciate that. And then my follow-up is tied to one of your comments earlier that you haven't seen the benefit from low oil prices that -- not just you, but many of us were talking about some kind of silver lining. So what are you hearing from your customers? Do you get the sense or -- that they are postponing decisions just due to uncertainty or they are signaling to you that there's simply lower demand? And what do you think might trigger a boost of the investor economy that would reflect in your volumes? And I know that's a long question. But maybe tied to that, if you could discuss where you focus your business development as a result.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Cleo, so I'll focus the answer on your question about not seeing the benefits of low oil. There's multiple moving parts in there. We are seeing capital investment occurring, specifically along the Gulf Coast, in our chemical franchise. Those investments j
componenttext: Cleo, so I'll focus the answer on your question about not seeing the benefits of low oil. There's multiple moving parts in there. We are seeing capital investment occurring, specifically along the Gulf Coast, in our chemical franchise. Those investments just haven't yet turned over into operating units, and so that's a matter of time. That's an end of this year, 2017, 2018 kind of impact. We're still hopeful for that impact. The other part of it is consumers doing something with the windfall of lower energy costs. And that's where it's really hard to see that showing through in the goods that we ship for retailers. And their feedback is while maybe services consumption is relatively healthy, goods consumption isn't necessarily showing that.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So then your business development remains focused in the Chemical Gulf Coast footprint?
componenttext: Okay. So then your business development remains focused in the Chemical Gulf Coast footprint?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our business has a wonderful franchise that we've talked about. One of the wonderful parts of that is this Gulf Coast franchise. And with low natural gas as a feedstock to many of those manufacturers, that's a benefit to them and we think, ultimately, wil
componenttext: Our business has a wonderful franchise that we've talked about. One of the wonderful parts of that is this Gulf Coast franchise. And with low natural gas as a feedstock to many of those manufacturers, that's a benefit to them and we think, ultimately, will be something we can participate when they increase production.

componenttext: Sammy, this is Lance. We -- in the third quarter of last year and into the fourth quarter, we announced and executed an involuntary force reduction on our nonagreement to our management ranks. And that's been executed. And then as we look forward, we continue to look for opportunity to get our overall structure sized right for the markets that we're serving. Attrition is our friend in that effort. We typically get an attrition rate of 7% or 8% a year. And we will use that to our advantage as and if we need to continue to adjust our overall structural cost.

componenttext: Rob, I think you called out an $0.11 headwind from fuel in the fourth quarter. Have you guys thought about trying to range what we can expect from a fuel headwind for next year? componenttext: Yes, I didn't put a number on the full year, but it could well be a headwind. I did call out that the first quarter -- remember that we had about an $0.08 positive last year. So we clearly have that as a hurdle facing us as the first quarter continues to play out. Of course, how fuel and the timing within any particular quarter will dictate exactly what that number ends up being year-over-year. But we do see that as a headwind certainly in the first quarter and could continue at some pace throughout the year.
