headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greetings. Welcome to Union Pacific First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded and the slides for today's presentation are available on Union Pacific's website. It's now my pleasure to
componenttext: Greetings. Welcome to Union Pacific First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded and the slides for today's presentation are available on Union Pacific's website. It's now my pleasure to introduce your host, Mr. Lance Fritz, Chairman, President and CEO for Union Pacific. Thank you, Mr. Fitz, you may now begin.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everybody, and welcome to Union Pacific's First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. With me here today in Omaha are Eric Butler, our Executive Vice President of Marketing and Sales; Cameron Scott, the Executive Vice President of Operations; an
componenttext: Good morning, everybody, and welcome to Union Pacific's First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. With me here today in Omaha are Eric Butler, our Executive Vice President of Marketing and Sales; Cameron Scott, the Executive Vice President of Operations; and Rob Knight, our Chief Financial Officer. This morning, Union Pacific is reporting net income of nearly $1 billion for the first quarter of 2016. This equates to $1.16 per share, which compares to $1.30 in the first quarter of 2015. Total volume decreased 8% in the quarter compared to 2015. Carload volume declined in 4 of our 6 commodity groups, with Coal and Industrial Products down 34% and 10%, respectively. Automotive continued to be a bright spot this quarter with carloads up 7% versus 2015. The quarterly operating ratio came in at 65.1%, up only 0.3 percentage point from the first quarter last year as solid core pricing and productivity improvements helped to offset the significant decrease in total volumes. In this challenging volume environment, we've continued our intense focus on operating safely and efficiently, managing our resources and improving our customer experience. Our team will give you more of the details starting with Eric.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lance and good morning. In the first quarter, our volume was down 8%, with a gain in Automotive and solid Chemicals volume more than offset by declines in the other business groups. While we've generated core pricing gains of just over 2.5%, it wa
componenttext:
Thanks, Lance and good morning. In the first quarter, our volume was down 8%, with a gain in Automotive and solid Chemicals volume more than offset by declines in the other business groups. While we've generated core pricing gains of just over 2.5%, it was not enough to offset decreased fuel surcharge and significant mix headwinds as average revenue per car declined 6% in the quarter. Overall, the decline in volume and lower average revenue per car drove a 14% reduction in freight revenue. 
Let's take a closer look at each of the 6 business groups. The Ag Products revenue was down 6% on a 4% volume reduction and a 2% decrease in average revenue per car. Grain volume declined 7% as strength in domestic feed markets was more than offset by soft export demand. Domestic feed grain was up 4% as animal counts increased and there was less local grain available in our key estimation markets at the Midsouth and West. Exports declined 26% as ample worldwide production and the strong dollar continued to amp the U.S. grain exports. Grain products volume declined 6% in the quarter. EBGs [ph] were down 29%, driven by decline in exports to China and increased inclusion in feed rations in the Midwest. Soybean milk carloads were down 9% as U.S. exports declined from last year's record sales. Ethanol volumes were flat despite lower margins and higher inventories. Food and Refrigerated Products carloads grew 3%, driven by continued strength and demand for import beer. 
Automotive revenue was down 1% in the quarter as the 7% increase in volume was more than offset by an 8% reduction in average revenue per car. Finished vehicles shipments increased 5% driven by consumer demand for technology and safety features. The seasonally adjusted annual rate for first quarter Automotive sales was 17.1 million vehicles, above last year at levels of 16.7 million but below the fourth quarter pace of 17.8 million. Lower fuel prices sustained increased demand for light [indiscernible] trucks and sport-utility vehicles over passenger cars. On the parts side, strong vehicle production increased and the continued focus on over the road conversions drove a 10% increase in volume. 
Chemicals revenue was down 2% for the quarter on flat volume and a 3% decrease in average revenue per car. Year-over-year, crude oil shipments were down 32% due to lower crude oil prices and unfavorable price spreads. Chemical volumes excluding crude oil shipments were up 4% at the quarter. Fertilizer was down 8% due primarily to weak global potash demand. Soft domestic agricultural economics also was a headwind for fertilizer volumes. Strength in other areas including growth in industrial chemicals and LPG volumes offset the declines in crude oil and fertilizer shipments. 
Coal revenue declined 43% in the quarter on a 34% volume decline and a 13% decrease in average revenue per car. Powder River Basin rail shipments were down 38% and Colorado Utah volumes were down 35% in the quarter as the warm winter, low natural gas prices and soft exports continue to negatively impact coal demand. According to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, this was the warmest winter on record. With natural gas prices around $2 or less for much of the first quarter, TRB coal inventory levels are at 108 days, 41 days above the 5-year average. 
Industrial Products revenue was down 18% on a 10% decline in volume and a 9% decrease in average revenue per car during the quarter. Mineral volumes were down 38% year-over-year for the quarter. Frac sand carloadings decreased 49% due to reduced drilling activity and market shifts to local brown sand. Metal shipments were down 13% due to the strong U.S. dollar, weak commodity pricing, reduced drilling and increased imports. Demand for Construction Products, particularly rock and sand -- and cement improved 5% in the quarter driven by favorable weather conditions, which supported construction activity. Waste volume was also up 14% during the quarter, driven by growth in dirt shipments. 
Intermodal revenue was down 9% in the quarter on 3% lower volume and a 6% decrease in average revenue per unit. Domestic shipments declined by 3% in the quarter primarily driven by high inventory levels and continued sluggish retail sales. The U.S. Census Bureau reported business inventories were unchanged during the quarter and further declines in sales pushed the number of months [indiscernible] to clear shelves of inventory to the highest levels since 2009. International Intermodal volume was down 3% due to transpacific market challenges. Slower global trade continued to pressure transpacific rates resulting in ocean carrier rationalization and market share losses by Union Pacific aligned carriers. Return of competitive premium service in the PNW also contributed to our volume declines in Intermodal. 
To wrap up, let's take a closer look at our outlook for the rest of the year. Many economic projections continue to forecast market volatility and a sluggish economy. Although we face economic challenges, our diverse franchise continues to provide growth opportunities. In Ag Products, strong worldwide crop reductions suggest little change to the current export environment, and we expect [indiscernible] wheat will continue to be softer in the first half of the year due to large global wheat supply in U.S. competitiveness in world markets. Partially offsetting global macroeconomic conditions, we anticipate strength in domestic corn, driven by increased poultry production. We also expect import beer growth. 
Turning to autos light vehicle sales are forecasted at 17.8 million, a 2% increase above the 2015 seasonally adjustable annual rate of 17.5 million, driving both finished autos and parts including over the road conversions. While we expect low gasoline prices will continue to sustain demand, we remain cautious with respect to auto sales supporting these levels. Due to declines in demand for coal, we expect volume will be down significantly. High inventory stockpiles and low natural gas prices will continue to impact demand. As always, electricity consumption will be driven by weather conditions. 
Our Chemicals franchise is expected to remain steady through 2016 with growth in LPG markets and Industrial Chemicals. Strained agricultural economics and soft exports are expected to put downward pressure on the fertilizer market this year. Year-over-year, weakness in crude shipments is expected to continue for the balance of the year. 
At Industrial Products, mineral volumes are expected to be down as a result of weak drilling demand. We anticipate strength in lumber and construction volumes with rock as the biggest driver of growth. The strong dollar could continue to create headwinds for our metals market. 
Finally, in Intermodal, we see growth potential in domestic Intermodal from high reconvergence [ph] though muted by high retail inventories and sluggish retail sales. With transpacific market challenges, we expect continued volatility in international Intermodal. 
As we navigate worldwide economic uncertainties, we will continue to stay focused on strengthening our customer value proposition and cultivate new business opportunities across our diverse franchise. 
With that, I'll turn it over to Cameron for an operating update.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Eric, and good morning. Starting with our safety performance. Our first quarter reportable personal injury rate improved 12% versus 2015 to a record low of 0.75. These results continue to validate the effectiveness of our comprehensive strategy in
componenttext:
Thanks, Eric, and good morning. Starting with our safety performance. Our first quarter reportable personal injury rate improved 12% versus 2015 to a record low of 0.75. These results continue to validate the effectiveness of our comprehensive strategy in finding and addressing risks in the workplace. With respect to rail equipment incidents or derailments, our first quarter reportable rate of 3.23 increased slightly versus last year. However, enhanced TE-wide training and continued infrastructure investment helped reduce the number of incidents including those that did not meet the reportable threshold to a record low. 
In public safety, our grade [indiscernible] and incident rate increased to 2.37 as we took a step backward from last year's solid performance. However, we are confident that our focus on reinforcing public awareness through community partnerships and public safety campaigns will drive improvements in the future. In summary, for overall safety, the team has carried forward the momentum from last year's record results as we progress towards an incident-free environment. 
In addition to safety, we have continued to make significant incremental progress in our operating metrics. As reported to the AAR, velocity and terminal dwell improved 11% and 7%, respectively, when compared to the first quarter of 2015. In fact, our first quarter velocity of 27.3 miles per hour was the best ever at the level of volume handled during the quarter. We were able to generate this solid performance even in the face of March flooding events that impacted operations on several key routes in the southern region of our network. To minimize delays and disruptions for our customers, we temporarily utilized a portion of our surge locomotive fleet and recalled TE&Y crews mostly from our alternative work status as our employees worked around the clock to restore operations. 
Moving on to resources. Driven by the decline in volume and improved network fluidity, our total TE&Y workforce was down 22% in the first quarter versus the same period in 2015. Almost half of this decrease was driven by fewer employees in the training pipeline. In lieu of hiring new employees, we have recalled some furloughed employees to backfill attrition where needed. As a result, the number of TE&Y employees either furloughed or on alternative work status has declined status slightly from 3,900 at the beginning of the year. Our active locomotive fleet was down 15% from the first quarter of 2015. 
In addition, we also continue to address other aspects of our business to lower demand. At the end of the first quarter, we had around 600 total engineering and mechanical employees on furlough as well. While balancing our resources continues to be a key focus, we also continue to realize efficiency gains through many other productivity initiatives. One primary area we continue to make progress is in train length. Now while we were unable to overcome the volume decline within Intermodal, we did run record train lengths in all other major categories. We were also able to generate efficiency gains within terminals as initiatives led to record terminal productivity even with the 5% decline in the number of car switched [ph] . Overall, we continued to intensify our focus on productivity and efficiency across the network. 
In summary, we've made solid progress to start off the year and completed the quarter on a strong holding. Moving forward, we expect further momentum as we focus on those critical initiatives that will drive improvement. First and foremost in safety where we expect once again to yield record results on our way towards 0 incidents. While near-term uncertainty remains in the current the volume environment, we will continue adjusting our resources to demand while also realizing productivity through other company initiatives to further reduce costs. This includes our capital investments where we have adjusted our 2016 capital program down by $75 million to $3.675 billion. Over the longer term, we are in a tremendous position to leverage volume growth to the bottom line through increased utilization of existing assets. As a result, we will enhance our value proposition with an excellent customer experience. 
With that, I'll turn it over to Rob.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, and good morning. Let's start with a recap of our first quarter results. Operating revenue was $4.8 billion in the quarter, down 14% versus last year. Significantly lower volumes, a challenging business mix and lower fuel surcharges more than offs
componenttext:
Thanks, and good morning. Let's start with a recap of our first quarter results. Operating revenue was $4.8 billion in the quarter, down 14% versus last year. Significantly lower volumes, a challenging business mix and lower fuel surcharges more than offset solid core pricing achieved in the quarter. Operating expenses totaled about $3.1 billion. Strong productivity improvements, along with volume-related reductions and lower fuel costs, drove the 14% improvement compared to last year. The net result was a 15% decrease in operating income to $1.7 billion. 
Below the line, other income totaled $46 million, up $20 million versus the previous year, primarily driven by gains from real estate sales and lower environmental costs. Interest expense of $167 million was up 13% compared to the previous year, driven by increased debt issuance during 2015 and the first quarter of 2016. Income tax expense decreased 17% to $587 million, driven primarily by lower pretax earnings. Net income totaled nearly $1 billion, down 15% versus 2015, while the outstanding share balance declined 4% as a result of our continued share repurchase activity. These results combined to produce quarterly earnings of $1.16 per share. 
Now turning to our top line. Freight revenue of $4.5 billion was down 14% versus last year. Volume declined 8% and fuel surcharge revenue decreased $334 million when compared to 2015. All in, we estimate the net impact of lower fuel prices was a $0.10 headwind to earnings in the first quarter versus last year, and keep in mind that we did report an $0.08 positive fuel benefit in the first quarter of 2015. As expected, a challenging business mix did have a negative 2.5% impact on freight revenue in the first quarter. The primary drivers of this mix shift were significant declines in frac sand, steel and export ag shipments partially offset by a decline in Intermodal volumes. Core price was a positive contributor to freight revenue in the quarter at just over 2.5%. 
Slide 21 provides more detail on our pricing trends. Pricing continued to be solid in the first quarter of 2016 and represents the strong value proposition that we provide our customers in the marketplace. 
Moving on to the expense side. Slide 22 provides a summary of our compensation and benefits expense, which decreased 11% versus 2015. The decrease was primarily driven by a combination of lower volumes and improved labor efficiencies. Labor inflation was about 1% in the first quarter, driven primarily by health and welfare, which is partially offset by pension favorability. 
Looking at our total workforce levels, our employee count declined 11% or more than 5,000 when compared to the first quarter of 2015. Remember that we still -- we're realigning our resources and we had a number of employees in the training pipeline at this time last year. Sequentially, total workforce levels were also down 2% from the fourth quarter of 2015. For the full year and longer term, we expect our force levels will continue to trend with volume, but as always, we expect to offset some of the volume variability with productivity. Labor inflation still expects to come in around 2% for the full year. This was driven primarily by wage inflation and health and welfare partially offset by lower pension expense. This is also consistent with our all-in inflation expectations in the 2% range for the full year. 
Turning to the next slide. Fuel expense totaled $320 million, down 43% when compared to 2015. Lower diesel fuel prices, along with a 13% decline in gross ton-miles, drove the decrease in fuel expense for the quarter. Compared to the first quarter of last year, our fuel consumption rate increased 1%, driven by negative mix, while our average fuel price declined 36% to $1.25 per gallon. 
Moving on to our other expense categories. Purchased services and materials expense decreased 12% to $569 million. The reduction was primarily driven by lower volume-related expense and reduced repair costs associated with our locomotive and car fleets. Depreciation expense was $502 million, up 2% compared to 2015, driven primarily by higher depreciable asset base. For the full year, we still expect depreciation expense to increase slightly compared to last year. 
Slide 25 summarizes the remaining 2 expense categories. Equipment and other rents expense totaled $289 million, which is down 7% when compared to 2015. Lower volumes, improved cycle times and lower locomotive lease expense were the primary drivers of the decline. Other expenses came in at $249 million, down 4% versus last year. A decrease in personal injury and casualty expenses were partially offset by higher state and local taxes. For 2016, we expect the other expense line to increase about 5% excluding any large unusual items. 
Turning now to our operating ratio performance. The first quarter operating ratio came in at 65.1%, 0.3 points unfavorable when compared to the first quarter of 2015. Fuel did have a negative 0.5 point impact in the quarter. Even with the sharp decline in volumes, our enhanced focus on productivity, rightsizing our resources to current demand and solid core pricing have all been key drivers to strong operating ratio performance. 
Turning now to our cash flow. In the first quarter, cash from operations totaled almost $2.2 billion, up slightly when compared  to the first quarter of 2015. The timing of tax payments primarily related to bonus depreciation on capital spending, along with changes in working capital, more than offset the decrease in net income. After dividends, our free cash flow totaled $1 billion for the quarter. 
Taking a look at the balance sheet. Our cash balance at quarter-end was unusually high as a result of our $1.3 billion debt issuance in March. This increased our all-in adjusted debt balance to about $18.3 billion at quarter-end. We finished the first quarter with an adjusted debt-to-EBITDA ratio of 1.8, up from 1.7 at year-end as we continue to target a ratio of less than 2x. 
In the first quarter, share repurchases exceeded 9.3 million shares and totaled over $700 million. Since initiating share repurchases in 2007, we have repurchased almost 27% of our outstanding shares. Adding our dividend payments and our share repurchases, we returned about $1.2 billion to our shareholders in the first quarter. So that's a recap of the first quarter results. 
As we look to the second quarter and the remainder of the year, there are a number of factors which will impact our results. Our energy-related volumes, especially coal, will continue to be challenged. We acknowledge that coal volumes in the first quarter finished well below what we had anticipated coming into the year primarily due to unseasonably warm weather that persisted throughout the winter, along with continued low natural gas prices. That said, we are still going to try again to give you our best sense of where we think second quarter coal volumes will be. If volume levels stay where they are today, coal could be down as much as 30% or so for the second quarter versus last year. In total, we would expect second quarter volumes to be down around 10% or so. Overall, volume comparisons should get easier in the second half. So at this point for the full year, we expect total volumes to be down in the mid-single-digit range. The impact of fuel prices on net earnings should start to moderate in the second quarter assuming fuel prices and spreads remain approximately where they are today. While we still expect some mix pressure for the remainder of the year, the magnitude should be less than what we had experienced in the last couple of quarters. In addition as Cam just mentioned, we are tightening the capital plan somewhat and reducing our capital spending by $75 million to $3.675 billion for the full year. This is a reduction of over $600 million from last year. We are still counting on record productivity and solid pricing to drive an improved operating ratio for the full year. 
In an uncertain volume environment, we are focusing our efforts on the steps we can take to make Union Pacific a better company. Key to this is our growth to 55 plus 0 initiative, which is our effort to drive our operating ratio to 55 over the longer term. The entire organization is energized and aspiring to new and improved levels of performance in productivity in innovation, in customer experience and, of course, in safety. This is the mindset that will drive not just our operating ratio but, ultimately, our earnings, our cash flow and our returns in the years ahead. 
So with that, I'll turn it back over to Lance.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rob. As you've heard from the team, 2016 has brought the continuation of many of the same trends that we experienced throughout most of last year. An energy market recession, low commodity prices, the strength of the U.S. dollar and soft global
componenttext:
Thank you, Rob. As you've heard from the team, 2016 has brought the continuation of many of the same trends that we experienced throughout most of last year. An energy market recession, low commodity prices, the strength of the U.S. dollar and soft global economy and muted domestic retail demand have all committed to overall market weakness across many of our business lines. And it's likely that many of these themes will be with us for some time. That said, we are stronger coming into this year than we were a year ago. We've improved the fluidity of our network with service metrics at all-time bests. We also achieved a record industry best employee safety rates as we work toward our ultimate goal of 0 injuries. It's challenging to do business in such an uncertain market, but we will continue to be agile in adapting to new business environments, making our company more productive, more innovative and, ultimately, more successful for the long term. We will continue to leverage the strength and diversity of the Union Pacific franchise to drive new business opportunities, to provide an excellent customer experience and to generate strong long-term value for our shareholders. 
With that, let's open up the line for your questions.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question is coming from the line of Jason Seidl with Cowen & Company.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question is coming from the line of Jason Seidl with Cowen & Company.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess the first one is going to be a bigger picture one. You talked about, Rob, I think cost inflation being at around 2% this year, yet, we have seen some of the core pricing at least sequentially, trend down to 2.5%. That's not a huge delta for you gu
componenttext: I guess the first one is going to be a bigger picture one. You talked about, Rob, I think cost inflation being at around 2% this year, yet, we have seen some of the core pricing at least sequentially, trend down to 2.5%. That's not a huge delta for you guys to play with. Where do you see core pricing going forward? And what has pressured it sequentially? It looks to me probably Intermodal and Coal, but I'd love some commentary on that.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes Jason, I would remind -- I know you know this, but I would remind everyone that if you look -- compared results to last year, remember, we got about, say, 0.5 point of legacy pricing that was embedded in full year results the previous year. And as we
componenttext: Yes Jason, I would remind -- I know you know this, but I would remind everyone that if you look -- compared results to last year, remember, we got about, say, 0.5 point of legacy pricing that was embedded in full year results the previous year. And as we called out, the legacy activity is pretty much behind us. So that 2.5 is convertible to something legacy light, if you will. Having said that, we don't give specific guidance by commodity group in terms of our pricing. In fact, our commitment still is to be an inflation plus kind of environment. We're going to continue to work as hard as we can, providing a quality service product to our customers so that we can continue to garner positive price above inflation as we move forward.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And my follow-up question is going to be on Ag volumes, specifically potentially export ag. The [indiscernible] loss rate regulations are coming up here in July. It seems that basically people [indiscernible] here in the U.S. seem to be reacting mor
componenttext: Okay. And my follow-up question is going to be on Ag volumes, specifically potentially export ag. The [indiscernible] loss rate regulations are coming up here in July. It seems that basically people [indiscernible] here in the U.S. seem to be reacting more negatively, particularly some people in the agricultural side. What's UP's view on it? And do you think it could be a potential negative impact even if it's just short term?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you're right. The regulation just came out here I think in the last -- clarity on the regulation just came out in the last 30 days, and it really put a lot of the requirements for implementation upon the shipping community, which is part of the reactio
componenttext: So you're right. The regulation just came out here I think in the last -- clarity on the regulation just came out in the last 30 days, and it really put a lot of the requirements for implementation upon the shipping community, which is part of the reaction that you get. Like most regulations, I think the shipping community will figure out a way to manage through that. And long term, if you look at our Ag business, it really is depending on the fact that the U.S. still is a great producer. Generally speaking, long term, it is in a sweet spot in terms of growth competitiveness. We had headwinds this year with a strong dollar, but it's in the sweet spot and the U.S. has produced and will continue to be a good producer and we, as a transportation provider, will continue to have the benefit of moving that business.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So there are no real concerns on your part with [indiscernible]?
componenttext: Okay. So there are no real concerns on your part with [indiscernible]?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not for the long term, no.
componenttext: Not for the long term, no.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is coming from the line of Tom Wadewitz with UP.
componenttext: The next question is coming from the line of Tom Wadewitz with UP.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask you on the comp and benefit. So you did well with the headcount reduction. And I know, Rob, you say that kind of moved with volume. But how would you think sequentially headcount changes? And also, is there anything in the per worker? The
componenttext: I wanted to ask you on the comp and benefit. So you did well with the headcount reduction. And I know, Rob, you say that kind of moved with volume. But how would you think sequentially headcount changes? And also, is there anything in the per worker? The per worker change is pretty low, which is kind of notable. In contrast, the effects are more of a mid-single-digit increase in that. So I just wondered if you had any thoughts on those 2 on kind of how your headcount changed per worker.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Tom. I would say that, first of all, on the per worker, really what drives changes from quarter-to-quarter is largely -- in our case, is largely driven by the mix of employees that show up in capital or happen to be working on capital that quarter or
componenttext: Yes, Tom. I would say that, first of all, on the per worker, really what drives changes from quarter-to-quarter is largely -- in our case, is largely driven by the mix of employees that show up in capital or happen to be working on capital that quarter or not working on capital. That is generally why you might see swings from one quarter to the next because other than that, it's just basically kind of straightforward in terms of the inflation that shows up on the labor line. In terms of our headcount going forward, I mean as I said and as we've always said, we're going to continue to squeeze out productivity. Headcount will move as volume does but not 1 for 1 because we are continually focused on identifying continuing productivity initiatives. And I think you saw that certainly in the first quarter with an 11% reduction in the headcount. That was good productivity initiatives, but we're not done. The whole theme of the G to 55 initiative is focused on continued productivity. So I would expect that trend will continue in terms of moving with volume but offset by productivity results.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And as a follow-up, just in terms of pricing, do you think that the pricing environment took a little bit of a step-down as you saw in the core price and now it's stable? Or would you say that they're kind of pressured, they're building a bit furthe
componenttext: Okay. And as a follow-up, just in terms of pricing, do you think that the pricing environment took a little bit of a step-down as you saw in the core price and now it's stable? Or would you say that they're kind of pressured, they're building a bit further as you look forward on just contracts that get negotiated through the year. Is that pricing getting worse? Or is it just kind of a step-down and stable where we are?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Before I turn it over to Eric, this is Lance, just globally, of course, we would prefer an environment like 2014, where volumes growing robustly and there's a lot of demand for our services. That's a more favorable environment to be in. We're in a less fa
componenttext: Before I turn it over to Eric, this is Lance, just globally, of course, we would prefer an environment like 2014, where volumes growing robustly and there's a lot of demand for our services. That's a more favorable environment to be in. We're in a less favorable environment. But even so, we're still committed to doing exactly what Rob said, which is pricing for our value, getting a reinvestable return on it and pricing above inflation. Eric, any more?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think I would say, we all know that low fuel prices are allowing trucks to be [indiscernible] They're very tough competitors. Sluggish retail sales is a headwind to the economy, but within that, we think we have a great value proposition and we're g
componenttext: No. I think I would say, we all know that low fuel prices are allowing trucks to be [indiscernible] They're very tough competitors. Sluggish retail sales is a headwind to the economy, but within that, we think we have a great value proposition and we're going to continue to price towards our value proposition.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question was from the line of David Vernon with Bernstein Research.
componenttext: Our next question was from the line of David Vernon with Bernstein Research.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe Rob or Cameron, as you think about the drivers of productivity in the drive to 55 as an operating ratio, can you help us kind of frame like where that's going to come from? Is it the application of technology? Is it business process? And I know it's
componenttext: Maybe Rob or Cameron, as you think about the drivers of productivity in the drive to 55 as an operating ratio, can you help us kind of frame like where that's going to come from? Is it the application of technology? Is it business process? And I know it's kind of a broad question, but I guess some investors had a little bit of feedback around where is this going to come from. I'm just wondering if you give us some color in terms of the big broad brushstrokes where you think this productivity could come from in the business.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Cam, let's start with you.
componenttext: Cam, let's start with you.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. We mentioned train size earlier in the presentation. Every commodity group that we have has headroom for additional train size in productivity, and we feel very good about our progress. We've made record train sizes in every commodity with the excep
componenttext: Okay. We mentioned train size earlier in the presentation. Every commodity group that we have has headroom for additional train size in productivity, and we feel very good about our progress. We've made record train sizes in every commodity with the exception of coal which is fairly optimized for a number of years in a row and we'll do that again this year. Variable cost in every department within the operating team is a very big initiative for us, transportation, mechanical and engineering. And initiatives like [indiscernible] rate, where we've made enormous progress over the last 18 months coming down to record [indiscernible] performance. So those are some of the events.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I also want to add, let's not shorthand, when Rob's talking about the grow to 550 and 0, productivity isn't just about cutting heads. It's more predominantly about doing things more efficiently, getting more out of our assets, getting more out of a gallon
componenttext: I also want to add, let's not shorthand, when Rob's talking about the grow to 550 and 0, productivity isn't just about cutting heads. It's more predominantly about doing things more efficiently, getting more out of our assets, getting more out of a gallon of fuel. And the growth side is equally important, as Eric and his commercial team, in the context of all the headwinds we see on the energy side of the world growing all the other commodities where we have opportunity, and there's lots of that opportunity.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, I will promise we will not have 3 responses to every question here, but this is due to all of our [indiscernible]. I would just add to the discussion that Cam and Lance have had, is that we're looking at every stone that we could turn over in the c
componenttext: David, I will promise we will not have 3 responses to every question here, but this is due to all of our [indiscernible]. I would just add to the discussion that Cam and Lance have had, is that we're looking at every stone that we could turn over in the company. And Cam obviously talked heavily about the operations, which is where the big dollars are and the big opportunities are, but we're not leaving it at that. And Lance talked about the growth opportunities. But aside from that, we're looking -- we're challenging the entire organization even the administrative groups to turn over every stone of looking for additional opportunities to be more efficient than ever before. And to your question, yes, technology where it can enable that, whether it's coal operations or in support activity, we are certainly looking to leverage that even further.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Excellent. And then maybe just kind of as a follow-up, as you think about some of the stranded asset issues that may come with the coal network running at obviously levels that we've never seen before at least in the last 10 or 15 years, how much of a hea
componenttext: Excellent. And then maybe just kind of as a follow-up, as you think about some of the stranded asset issues that may come with the coal network running at obviously levels that we've never seen before at least in the last 10 or 15 years, how much of a headwind should we expect in terms of some assets being stranded out there or [indiscernible] being stranded out there with the decline of coal.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, this is Rob. I would say that, that's not the case in our network. Again, if you're going to look at -- we don't have stranded assets. We don't envision there'll be stranded assets because we look at again, using coal as the obvious example, I mean
componenttext: David, this is Rob. I would say that, that's not the case in our network. Again, if you're going to look at -- we don't have stranded assets. We don't envision there'll be stranded assets because we look at again, using coal as the obvious example, I mean we've still got the lines going up to the PRB mines. I mean those lines, while less volumes traveling over there and perhaps right now than maybe at their peak, they are still the same lines that we've enjoyed. So we don't have a situation. Now having said that, we're going to squeeze to be as productive as we can on our asset base. You see that in our locomotives and certainly our headcount related to that. But as it relates to sort of stranded assets, that -- I don't see that as an issue for us.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Ossenbeck with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Ossenbeck with JPMorgan.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to ask a couple of high-level questions. Eric, you mentioned strong dollars still a headwind on grain and crews and excess inventories in that market, but come off from the peak [indiscernible] crew had a nice run for a long time. How long do
componenttext: I just want to ask a couple of high-level questions. Eric, you mentioned strong dollars still a headwind on grain and crews and excess inventories in that market, but come off from the peak [indiscernible] crew had a nice run for a long time. How long do you think it needs to stay at this level? Or roughly how much lower do you think it needs to go before you start to see some relief? And I guess what would be the first place you'd expect to see that.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not a central banker, but I would say the dollar is still very high and [indiscernible] relative since it has dropped a little from the peak, but it still is very high. And as you know, dollars impact the competitiveness of U.S. exports across the boa
componenttext: I'm not a central banker, but I would say the dollar is still very high and [indiscernible] relative since it has dropped a little from the peak, but it still is very high. And as you know, dollars impact the competitiveness of U.S. exports across the board. So whether it's Ag, whether it's things like steel, whether it's things like iron or metals business or other commodities business, it impacts all of those things. So I don't have any prediction of how much the dollar needs to fall. It still is very high in any relative historical sense.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: To clarify, it sounds like you're not seeing anything at this stage.
componenttext: To clarify, it sounds like you're not seeing anything at this stage.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The dollar is still a headwind. The strong dollar is still a headwind to U.S. exports.
componenttext: Yes. The dollar is still a headwind. The strong dollar is still a headwind to U.S. exports.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then a follow-up on oil, again, the macro factor clearly had been moving off the loads. How much upside do you think can be to the frac sand business? Do you start to see any signs of activity there? I know you have another tough quarter
componenttext: Okay, great. And then a follow-up on oil, again, the macro factor clearly had been moving off the loads. How much upside do you think can be to the frac sand business? Do you start to see any signs of activity there? I know you have another tough quarter on tough comps. You mentioned some regional sourcing that's starting to work its way into the business, but are you starting to [indiscernible] some more optimism that completions which start to move forward here and get some more sand down the wells?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the public numbers still show drilling rigs down about 45% or 49%, 50%. So there's not a lot of drilling activity that has picked back up with the slight bump-up on fuel. Certainly, when the drilling activity picks back up, we would expect to part
componenttext: I think the public numbers still show drilling rigs down about 45% or 49%, 50%. So there's not a lot of drilling activity that has picked back up with the slight bump-up on fuel. Certainly, when the drilling activity picks back up, we would expect to participate in that in the various markets that we operate in.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The good news on that is the shale energy producers have done a tremendous job in getting their own cost structures in line and getting productivity as they had experienced with this new approach to drilling. And so the strike price for win activity picks
componenttext: The good news on that is the shale energy producers have done a tremendous job in getting their own cost structures in line and getting productivity as they had experienced with this new approach to drilling. And so the strike price for win activity picks up is lower than it was 3 or 4 or 5 years ago, but we're still not at that point.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ken Hoexter with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ken Hoexter with Bank of America.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rob, can you -- just following up on Tom's question before, you talked about the costs per employee coming down a bit. Would you expect to increase with incentive comp or you mentioned pension reductions, can those outweigh -- can you just walk through th
componenttext: Rob, can you -- just following up on Tom's question before, you talked about the costs per employee coming down a bit. Would you expect to increase with incentive comp or you mentioned pension reductions, can those outweigh -- can you just walk through the pension savings and incentive comp impact as we move forward through the year?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I wouldn't anticipate a drill change or much of a change at all in the pension. And incentive comp for us, Ken, is not a big mover because it doesn't -- we don't have a wide-based plan that affects wide percentages of our employees. So you boil it do
componenttext: Yes, I wouldn't anticipate a drill change or much of a change at all in the pension. And incentive comp for us, Ken, is not a big mover because it doesn't -- we don't have a wide-based plan that affects wide percentages of our employees. So you boil it down -- the big driver is going to be, again, I would use that 2% labor inflation number that we expect in the full year, and again, the timing of that can change quarter-to-quarter depending on how many employees are actively involved in capital or not involved in capital. That's really going to be what changes that number going forward. So I don't see any big changes.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So nothing that materially changes the productivity gains that you saw in the quarter.
componenttext: So nothing that materially changes the productivity gains that you saw in the quarter.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not as it relates to the comp per employee.
componenttext: Not as it relates to the comp per employee.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, okay. And then, Eric, just thinking about Intermodal obviously given the pressures you talked about maybe one more to throw out at you with the Panama Canal opening up soon, I know over the past few years, you and Lance have thrown out you don't expe
componenttext: Yes, okay. And then, Eric, just thinking about Intermodal obviously given the pressures you talked about maybe one more to throw out at you with the Panama Canal opening up soon, I know over the past few years, you and Lance have thrown out you don't expect much change. But as you see plans and new teaming up amongst the container liners that's going on, is there any thought of any shift of capacity given the impact of the port strike a year ago and thoughts on how that distributes the Intermodal volumes?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, there's a lot of moving parts, as you know, and there are a lot of ins and outs. I don't think anything substantially has changed our perspective that we've given over the time. A couple of the key factors we always look at is West Coast port entry s
componenttext: Ken, there's a lot of moving parts, as you know, and there are a lot of ins and outs. I don't think anything substantially has changed our perspective that we've given over the time. A couple of the key factors we always look at is West Coast port entry still is the fastest option to get to the Eastern markets, usually by 2 weeks. Another factor is, with all of the rationalization going on in the container shipping industry, all of the alliances and the mergers and all of that's going on, there does seem to be a migration to the larger ships. About half the new capacity coming on is with ships greater than 12,000 or 13,000 TE use on it. Those ships cannot go through even the expanded Panama Canal. So I think as you look at this transpacific rationalization, larger ships -- there are even larger ships posting right now on the West Coast that cannot go through even the expanded canal. I think the West Coast ports still will remain a very strong -- a viable competitor, and fundamentally, we're not changing our perspective and our outlook that we've had over the last couple of years.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from the line of Justin Long with Stephens.
componenttext: The next question is from the line of Justin Long with Stephens.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So first question I wanted to ask, there's a lot of noise in the volume numbers right now between volatile comps, the impact of flooding and what's going on in coal, and it's pretty tough to get a feel for the underlying demand environment. From your pers
componenttext: So first question I wanted to ask, there's a lot of noise in the volume numbers right now between volatile comps, the impact of flooding and what's going on in coal, and it's pretty tough to get a feel for the underlying demand environment. From your perspective, through the first 3 or 4 months of the year, what's your view on the demand environment and economy relative to where your outlook was at the start of the year?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Eric, you want to take a stab at that?
componenttext: Eric, you want to take a stab at that?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So clearly, as Rob said earlier, the coal side was a lot softer than what we anticipated, again warmest winter weather. We did not expect these low natural gas prices. The shale impact is significant, but we set aside the shale impact, the kind of the ene
componenttext: So clearly, as Rob said earlier, the coal side was a lot softer than what we anticipated, again warmest winter weather. We did not expect these low natural gas prices. The shale impact is significant, but we set aside the shale impact, the kind of the energy, the coal impact, you do have some variability going on in terms of retail sales. It's probably a little softer than what we had anticipated. But if you look at net-net everything else, I think it's pretty solid growth and aligned with what we expected and aligned with the slowly strengthening economy. So you have a retail sales kind of international Intermodal kind of market issue. You got a shale coal energy market issue. But if you look at everything else, I think it's pretty aligned and slowly strengthening.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as a follow-up, one of the big discrepancies between your year-to-date volume performance and your Western competitor is coming in Intermodal. So I'm just curious if you're seeing more competitive pricing dynamics and any market share shifts. Or is th
componenttext: And as a follow-up, one of the big discrepancies between your year-to-date volume performance and your Western competitor is coming in Intermodal. So I'm just curious if you're seeing more competitive pricing dynamics and any market share shifts. Or is there any other explanation for this discrepancy?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes definitely. As I said in my prepared comments that if you look at the international Intermodal side of the business and all of the rationalization that's going on there with the steamship carriers and the alliance changes and some of the mergers, that
componenttext: Yes definitely. As I said in my prepared comments that if you look at the international Intermodal side of the business and all of the rationalization that's going on there with the steamship carriers and the alliance changes and some of the mergers, that clearly has had more of an impact on our book of business based on the shippers that we historically had been aligned with of vis-a-vis our Western competitors.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Justin, taking a step back, when you think about Intermodal, when you break out international Intermodal and domestic, we still are quite bullish on domestic Intermodal over the long run. There is still a rich opportunity to take trucks off the highwa
componenttext: And Justin, taking a step back, when you think about Intermodal, when you break out international Intermodal and domestic, we still are quite bullish on domestic Intermodal over the long run. There is still a rich opportunity to take trucks off the highway, and we think we're going to be able to grow that product for the foreseeable future.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Matt Troy of Nomura Securities.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Matt Troy of Nomura Securities.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want a broader question as it relates to CapEx. I know if I go back to 2000, 2005 time frame, your volumes today are relatively flat, but your CapEx budget is up 100%. It's doubled [indiscernible] spending twice as much to handle the same level of
componenttext: I just want a broader question as it relates to CapEx. I know if I go back to 2000, 2005 time frame, your volumes today are relatively flat, but your CapEx budget is up 100%. It's doubled [indiscernible] spending twice as much to handle the same level of traffic. I know you layered in PTC. I know given the long-winded nature of the assets that there's inflation. But I'm just curious, is it time for you and your rail peers to kind of rethink the brackets or the goalpost in terms of the percentage of revenues you're spending on CapEx. I know you got a take a long 10-, 20-year view where most people in the market take a 1- or 2-month view. But I'm just curious, in a slower growth environment, which seems to be stubbornly persistent, you took 600 down year-over-year, which is impressive. Is it time to rethink more broadly what capital is required to run these railroads?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for the question, Matt. As Rob reminds our investment community all the time, we are constantly reviewing our capital spend in the context of projects that are generating attractive returns, our overall volumes and where those volumes are moving. I
componenttext: Thanks for the question, Matt. As Rob reminds our investment community all the time, we are constantly reviewing our capital spend in the context of projects that are generating attractive returns, our overall volumes and where those volumes are moving. If you look at us compared to 10 or 15 years ago in capital, there are a couple of very big moving parts. One is PTC, which full year last year was a $300 million or $390 million kind of number that didn't exist at that time. Another big moving part can be locomotives. We're in the market for locomotives more in the past few years than we were 10 or 15 years ago. And the third big moving part is in maintenance capital. I recall back in those days, we were spending in the neighborhood of maybe $1.2 billion. And in these days, we're spending more like $1.8 billion number. And for that, we have a much more robust network that's operating at very high levels. Now having said all that, as we look forward, our capital spend will depend on the first 3 things I mentioned. First and foremost, what's the outlook for volume with, what the environment looks like, where is that volume showing up, and what are the projects that we have in front of us that generate attractive returns. In my mind's eye, you're still going to see a spend down in our Southern tier of our network. That's still an area where we would like to continue to enhance our capacity, and you'll still continue to see us invest at a fairly robust level for maintaining the railroad, although that also ebbs and flows with how much we're consuming in GTMs.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just one follow-up. Looking for a silver lining in what is otherwise a choppy volume environment, I was surprised that the strength in industrial [indiscernible] up 16% just given that they historically have had rail chemical traffic [indiscernible] s
componenttext: And just one follow-up. Looking for a silver lining in what is otherwise a choppy volume environment, I was surprised that the strength in industrial [indiscernible] up 16% just given that they historically have had rail chemical traffic [indiscernible] such a high correlation with economic expansion. Was wondering if you could perhaps just put some additional color on there given that strength. Is that share-driven, was that new customer driven? Just some sort of greater clarity there would be extremely helpful.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So as we regularly say, we are continuing to focus on business development and we have a huge number of business development initiatives underway across the board, which are really overshadowed by the coal in the Shale and some of the rationalization we'r
componenttext: So as we regularly say, we are continuing to focus on business development and we have a huge number of business development initiatives underway across the board, which are really overshadowed by the coal in the Shale and some of the rationalization we're seeing in international Intermodal. If you look at our Chemicals business, the Gulf Coast franchise, while many of those plastics expansions will not come on to next year, as we talked about in the past, we still have lots of opportunities in terms of LPG growth, Mexico energy reform. There's a lot of growing interest in terms of moving products there and we're working on a number of different initiatives with that. And so there is general economic strength that we're seeing in our industrial products business in terms of the construction coming back, housing coming back. Chemicals has a benefit of plastics going to the Automotive industry as you see Automotive sales. And so there's a slowly strengthening economy out there. We're doing a lot of business development to go after it, which again is being overshadowed by just the huge volume numbers for coal and shale and the other headwinds we have.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from the line of Allison Landry with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from the line of Allison Landry with Crédit Suisse.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Given everything that's happening with coal, similar to what your eastern peers have done in the past few years, are you having to explore potentially changing contracts with your customers and moving more towards a fixed variable structure?
componenttext: Given everything that's happening with coal, similar to what your eastern peers have done in the past few years, are you having to explore potentially changing contracts with your customers and moving more towards a fixed variable structure?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Eric, do you want to handle that?
componenttext: Eric, do you want to handle that?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Allison, as you know, we have a standard answer where we don't really talk about specific contract negotiations. I will say we negotiate aggressively and assertively, and we're in a very competitive environment. And for any particular contract negotiat
componenttext: So Allison, as you know, we have a standard answer where we don't really talk about specific contract negotiations. I will say we negotiate aggressively and assertively, and we're in a very competitive environment. And for any particular contract negotiation, we probably have dozens, if not hundreds, of terms that we're negotiating. And like always, as markets change and we look to competitively evaluate a bunch of those terms and conditions, what works for us, what works for our customer base.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as a follow-up question, if we look a little bit to the future and see volumes will eventually come back to the network, could you talk a little bit about how you're thinking about the operating leverage and inherent earnings power of the company just
componenttext: And as a follow-up question, if we look a little bit to the future and see volumes will eventually come back to the network, could you talk a little bit about how you're thinking about the operating leverage and inherent earnings power of the company just in light of the fact that you've taken a significant amount of cost over the last few quarters?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So as you just lined up, volume is our friend. We're looking forward to the point where we're growing on the top line because it does make it easier to drop back to the bottom line. Having said that, in the place we are right now, we're in the proces
componenttext: Yes. So as you just lined up, volume is our friend. We're looking forward to the point where we're growing on the top line because it does make it easier to drop back to the bottom line. Having said that, in the place we are right now, we're in the process of giving our overall structure to match where our markets are today. And then from that point moving forward, we'll continue to be aggressive on our productivity, on our efficiency, on our business development, and generally, that model is very attractive when we grow.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Chris Wetherbee with Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Chris Wetherbee with Citigroup.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to touch a little bit on the flooding. You haven't mentioned it on the call. Just want to get a sense if you can quantify any impact if it was material both from a cost and maybe from a volume standpoint and maybe we see some a little bit of sort o
componenttext: I want to touch a little bit on the flooding. You haven't mentioned it on the call. Just want to get a sense if you can quantify any impact if it was material both from a cost and maybe from a volume standpoint and maybe we see some a little bit of sort of lost volumes come back in Q2, just give us a sense on how to think about that.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chris, this is Rob. [indiscernible] work by the operating team because it was a significant challenge for them but they did a fabulous job. And I would say the impact to us was less than $0.01 in terms of EPS in the quarter.
componenttext: Chris, this is Rob. [indiscernible] work by the operating team because it was a significant challenge for them but they did a fabulous job. And I would say the impact to us was less than $0.01 in terms of EPS in the quarter.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then wanted to follow up on mix. So mix, obviously, improved from the fourth quarter and feels like it was a little bit less bad than maybe some were thinking for the first quarter despite the fact that some of the bulk commodity
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then wanted to follow up on mix. So mix, obviously, improved from the fourth quarter and feels like it was a little bit less bad than maybe some were thinking for the first quarter despite the fact that some of the bulk commodity groups were down pretty significantly. As you think about the rest of the year, how can this trend -- is the first quarter likely to be the low watermark in terms of the headwind for mix? How do we think about that going forward?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chris, this is Rob. You know we don't give guidance on mix and the reason we don't is because we are in so many different markets, which we are really proud of in terms of the diversity of our network. There are really a lot of moving parts, as you know,
componenttext: Chris, this is Rob. You know we don't give guidance on mix and the reason we don't is because we are in so many different markets, which we are really proud of in terms of the diversity of our network. There are really a lot of moving parts, as you know, and there's mix even within each of the commodity groups. Having said that, you're right, we are coming off of unusually high negative mix challenges. And we do think our best look at the balance of the year is that will moderate. Again, we're at high water marks here, I would hope, at 2.5. And certainly, last quarter's 4 negative impact on mix I would hope is an all-time high water mark, but we do think our best guess is that's going to moderate but it's difficult to actually put any finer point on it.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Ravi Shankar with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Ravi Shankar with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to take a longer-term view here and ask you about coal, obviously, another step-down in the next couple of quarters. But when you look to 2017, is this a market that can be flat or even up next year? Or what's going to be there?
componenttext: Just wanted to take a longer-term view here and ask you about coal, obviously, another step-down in the next couple of quarters. But when you look to 2017, is this a market that can be flat or even up next year? Or what's going to be there?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me take a stab at that, Ravi. So the way we think about coal is it's facing a large number of headwinds right now. Low natural gas prices is an alternative, pretty significant inventory overhang on the piles right now, and a weak electricity gene
componenttext: Yes, let me take a stab at that, Ravi. So the way we think about coal is it's facing a large number of headwinds right now. Low natural gas prices is an alternative, pretty significant inventory overhang on the piles right now, and a weak electricity generating market some driven by weather. So as those headwinds persist, coal is going to continue to have some difficulty. We're going to have to true up some of this excess inventory before we see coal demand really  strengthen. What it might look like 2, 3, 4, 5 years from now, we still think it's a pretty important part of the overall electricity generating base in the United States. It's not going back. We don't think to where it was 4 or 5 years ago. And you can make an argument either way that it strengthens a bit or that it might decline a bit. Our best guess is we're probably in kind of the relative [indiscernible] it's going to operate other than the really significant headwinds that we're facing in this particular time frame.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And as a follow-up, going back to the flooding, we heard there's a lot of cooperation between a number of rails and get everyone out of that mess. But just generally talking about the competitive environment, what are you seeing out there in terms
componenttext: Got it. And as a follow-up, going back to the flooding, we heard there's a lot of cooperation between a number of rails and get everyone out of that mess. But just generally talking about the competitive environment, what are you seeing out there in terms of some of the actions that some of your peers are taking?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think if you're asking specific to the floods, we did a great job of making sure our customers had alternatives and satisfying their needs and keeping them well informed. If you're asking in terms of the overall operating environment, we are in a compet
componenttext: I think if you're asking specific to the floods, we did a great job of making sure our customers had alternatives and satisfying their needs and keeping them well informed. If you're asking in terms of the overall operating environment, we are in a competitive environment. We compete every day for every piece of the business that we enjoy and we compete on the basis of providing our customers the best experience they're going to get in the marketplace. And everything we do every day is oriented towards making that happen.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Scott, Rob. I'd say minor and I would anticipate that will be minor be for the balance of the year.

componenttext: Correct.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
