componenttext: Your point, Rob, about there was more capital than expense employees in the quarter, I think that was your point, is that something that -- is it just a first quarter event? Or is it just kind of continuing all year where we see [indiscernible] employee because of that less than the 2% wage inflation you talked about?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Scott, the point I was trying to make on the -- number one, you can always have those swings depending on what capital projects are going on, but that was more of a sequential comment. I mean generally speaking, you would start to ramp up some of you
componenttext: Yes, Scott, the point I was trying to make on the -- number one, you can always have those swings depending on what capital projects are going on, but that was more of a sequential comment. I mean generally speaking, you would start to ramp up some of your capital projects in the first quarter that perhaps you weren't running as you finished the fourth quarter. So that was more of a comment relative -- this particular [indiscernible] relative to the sequential look. Year-over-year not as much -- in the first quarter not as material of an impact, but that can change from time to time. But I think if you look at it again, the first quarter was pretty clean, in my view, when you look year-over-year. In terms of 11% headcount reduction really is representative of very solid outstanding productivity performance. And of course, remember, the year before we had our share of challenges.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess I'm just leaning on the comp per employees because you talked about inflation of 2% and comp per employee was down 1%. And I'm just trying to understand if that's a number that can continue through the rest of the year.
componenttext: I guess I'm just leaning on the comp per employees because you talked about inflation of 2% and comp per employee was down 1%. And I'm just trying to understand if that's a number that can continue through the rest of the year.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't give guidance on that. I think probably the best way they'll think about it is the 2% inflation I mean, generally speaking, should look like the guidance we're getting on the labor inflation line, which should be close to the 2%.
componenttext: I wouldn't give guidance on that. I think probably the best way they'll think about it is the 2% inflation I mean, generally speaking, should look like the guidance we're getting on the labor inflation line, which should be close to the 2%.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if I could just ask one more. Eric, maybe can you let us know where are coal stockpiles now relative to targets? And if you think back to the last cycle, kind of -- how long does it take for the stockpiles to come down? Is it one good weather se
componenttext: Okay. And if I could just ask one more. Eric, maybe can you let us know where are coal stockpiles now relative to targets? And if you think back to the last cycle, kind of -- how long does it take for the stockpiles to come down? Is it one good weather season? Is it 2, 3? I don't know.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The actual numbers I think are 108 days, which is about 41 days above, call it, a 5-year average. And I think no, 41 days above last year, and how long it takes to come down just depends on all the factors we've talked about.
componenttext: The actual numbers I think are 108 days, which is about 41 days above, call it, a 5-year average. And I think no, 41 days above last year, and how long it takes to come down just depends on all the factors we've talked about.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of John Barnes with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of John Barnes with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, I believe it's on [indiscernible] we're going to see some recovery in volumes. I guess we all hope that, right? But in the meantime, as you go through these [indiscernible] production efforts and align resources with the coal volume, that type of t
componenttext: First, I believe it's on [indiscernible] we're going to see some recovery in volumes. I guess we all hope that, right? But in the meantime, as you go through these [indiscernible] production efforts and align resources with the coal volume, that type of thing, how long can you do that before you get some ramp-up in carloads and protect the profitability of the railroad? I mean obviously, the profitability was down in the quarter, but [indiscernible] protecting that and that kind of thing. How long can you continue that until you run out of cost reduction initiatives and you start to cut into the muscle of the organization.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, we can do it for as long as it's necessary. We've demonstrated that we understand how to use attrition as our friend, how to use initiatives like grow to 55 and 0. We know how to get our cost structure right. We're in the middle of doing that. We're
componenttext: John, we can do it for as long as it's necessary. We've demonstrated that we understand how to use attrition as our friend, how to use initiatives like grow to 55 and 0. We know how to get our cost structure right. We're in the middle of doing that. We're going to continue to do it. My expectation is that we don't have to do that forever because I do expect this, at some point, to start growing the top line. We're kind of in a unique environment right now with a lot of headwinds. Some of those headwinds represent structural shift like in coal, where a portion of that book of business is probably permanently reduced. But in the big scheme of things, at some point, those headwinds abate, we start growing again. And even in that environment, we're still focused on making sure that we have the structure right, that we have our cost right and we're constantly looking for efficiency.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, right, right. And then secondly, Rob, you commented in your presentation about significant increase in the cash balances because your debt issuance. You've reduced the CapEx budget a little bit, which I would imagine probably reduces the cash flow a
componenttext: Okay, right, right. And then secondly, Rob, you commented in your presentation about significant increase in the cash balances because your debt issuance. You've reduced the CapEx budget a little bit, which I would imagine probably reduces the cash flow a little bit. Can you just talk a little bit about -- I guess with rail I mean you got off the table, there's no real need to be hoarding cash for some kind of of move in that arena, what do you think the plan is on the use of cash going forward? Is there any alteration, should we expect in the acceleration in share buyback just given the cash balances at this point.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, I would say no. I mean I wouldn't read into the fact that we happen to finish the quarter with high cash balance as they change and I think it's going to be the balanced approach and we need the cash flow for working capital, for taxes, for dividend
componenttext: John, I would say no. I mean I wouldn't read into the fact that we happen to finish the quarter with high cash balance as they change and I think it's going to be the balanced approach and we need the cash flow for working capital, for taxes, for dividend. And we continue to be, as we have been, opportunistic on share buybacks as we move forward.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Cherilyn Radbourne of TD Securities.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Cherilyn Radbourne of TD Securities.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to ask one on grain because there's so much in storage. You could make the case that there's potential upside in the back half just on the basis that some will have to move to make for this year's harvest, but you still seem pretty cautious. And I'
componenttext: Wanted to ask one on grain because there's so much in storage. You could make the case that there's potential upside in the back half just on the basis that some will have to move to make for this year's harvest, but you still seem pretty cautious. And I'm just curious if that's because it's really in the season or something else?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Eric, Cherilyn. There is a lot of grain in storage. There's about 200 million bushels that were carried out from last year. I think the USDA estimates are that can grow by another 500 million bushels based on the number of acres that are being pla
componenttext: This is Eric, Cherilyn. There is a lot of grain in storage. There's about 200 million bushels that were carried out from last year. I think the USDA estimates are that can grow by another 500 million bushels based on the number of acres that are being planted and the types of yields that are expected. So there is a lot of grain out there. We believe that eventually it has to move, and so we are certainly optimistic that when it does move we're going to get our fair share of that and it will move. It's just right now U.S. grain is not competitive on world markets. The strong dollar is an issue. There are other issues in terms of really good crops in other places growing regions around the world, but we do think it ultimately will move and we're going to get our fair share when it does.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then in terms of the locomotives that you got in storage, our any of those potential lease turnback candidates? Or are you comfortable with that as a surge fleet?
componenttext: Okay. And then in terms of the locomotives that you got in storage, our any of those potential lease turnback candidates? Or are you comfortable with that as a surge fleet?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Cam, do you want to start by talking about locomotives in storage?
componenttext: Cam, do you want to start by talking about locomotives in storage?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a really good mix of high horsepower and low horsepower in storage. And particularly on the low horsepower fleet, as we look out over the next 3 to 4 years, there's some very nice fleets for turnbacks that we will do, and we're very confident we c
componenttext: We have a really good mix of high horsepower and low horsepower in storage. And particularly on the low horsepower fleet, as we look out over the next 3 to 4 years, there's some very nice fleets for turnbacks that we will do, and we're very confident we can hold our horsepower fleet size and return those leases without any impact for our customers.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Brandon Oglenski with Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Brandon Oglenski with Barclays.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: But Lance or Rob, you guys did guide to an improved operating ratio this year. So could you just talk about the confidence that you have in achieving that, especially with volume down 10% in 2Q, as well as talk a little bit more about the fuel headwind th
componenttext: But Lance or Rob, you guys did guide to an improved operating ratio this year. So could you just talk about the confidence that you have in achieving that, especially with volume down 10% in 2Q, as well as talk a little bit more about the fuel headwind that you're discussing in 1Q?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll let Rob talk about fuel headwind. From a standpoint of operating ratio, we wouldn't be reaffirming it and talking about it if we didn't have confidence and faith in achieving it. We believe that given any reasonable outlook, we are going to improve o
componenttext: I'll let Rob talk about fuel headwind. From a standpoint of operating ratio, we wouldn't be reaffirming it and talking about it if we didn't have confidence and faith in achieving it. We believe that given any reasonable outlook, we are going to improve operating ratio this year.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Probably to add to that, Brandon, that clearly, we'd rather have positive volume. And just a reminder, we did guide that we -- that full year volumes will be down mid-single digits. That's a challenge, but to Lance's point, what we're discussing here is o
componenttext: Probably to add to that, Brandon, that clearly, we'd rather have positive volume. And just a reminder, we did guide that we -- that full year volumes will be down mid-single digits. That's a challenge, but to Lance's point, what we're discussing here is our confidence in our ability to continue to be squeezing out productivity initiatives and continue to price appropriately in the marketplace. On the fuel, the guidance we're giving on fuel is that while it was a $0.10 headwind in the first quarter largely driven by the $0.08 benefit the previous first quarter last year, we think that's going to moderate. If they stay kind of where they are, our expectation would be that, that headwind will moderate largely because we sort of lap the fall-off in fuel from the previous year.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So that was just the year-on-year impact or the lag impact from last year.
componenttext: Okay. So that was just the year-on-year impact or the lag impact from last year.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's exactly the quarter-over-quarter look, yes.
componenttext: That's exactly the quarter-over-quarter look, yes.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just one real quick one for the model. You did do a debt offering in the quarter. Where should your run rate interest expense be going forward?
componenttext: Okay. And then just one real quick one for the model. You did do a debt offering in the quarter. Where should your run rate interest expense be going forward?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say probably comparable to what we saw in the first quarter.
componenttext: I would say probably comparable to what we saw in the first quarter.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from the line of Tyler Brown with Raymond James.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from the line of Tyler Brown with Raymond James.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Cameron, just thanks for the details on some of initiatives behind the grow to 55. But of the 45 projects that you guys have specifically identified, how many of those have kicked off or going to kick off this year? And what's the cadence of the remaining
componenttext: Cameron, just thanks for the details on some of initiatives behind the grow to 55. But of the 45 projects that you guys have specifically identified, how many of those have kicked off or going to kick off this year? And what's the cadence of the remaining projects over the next couple of years? I just want to try to understand the pipeline of opportunities there.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. Within the operating department team, we have 12 projects that we've identified that we kicked off late '14 and into 2015. Many of those projects are gaining very, very good traction in 2016, and we have a couple of others lined up for the end
componenttext: Absolutely. Within the operating department team, we have 12 projects that we've identified that we kicked off late '14 and into 2015. Many of those projects are gaining very, very good traction in 2016, and we have a couple of others lined up for the end of '16 going into '17. So they're broad-based, they're well measured. We feel very confident, to an earlier question, that when we identify one of these productivity projects, that we can hold that productivity as volume comes back to is so that we have great leverage out into the future.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, no that's great. And then Rob, my follow-up. There just remains a lot of concern over there about the impact of mix, the decline in coal and kind of what it's doing to the holistic margin profile of the railroad. So I totally get it that you don't g
componenttext: Okay, no that's great. And then Rob, my follow-up. There just remains a lot of concern over there about the impact of mix, the decline in coal and kind of what it's doing to the holistic margin profile of the railroad. So I totally get it that you don't give margins by commodity, but how should we think about the stratifications of margins by commodity maybe, say, versus the past? So have they tightened over the past couple of years? Meaning, are they much closer to the corporate average today versus maybe a more disparate profile in the past? Or is that kind of a oversimplification?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Tyler, you know we don't break it up by commodity. But clearly, the mix that we've seen in the last -- a few quarters is a challenge, and I think we're proud of the fact that the reductions in volume and the headwind that we faced in the mix, we have
componenttext: Yes, Tyler, you know we don't break it up by commodity. But clearly, the mix that we've seen in the last -- a few quarters is a challenge, and I think we're proud of the fact that the reductions in volume and the headwind that we faced in the mix, we have continued to drive outstanding operating ratio performance. So that's kind of the focus. Irrespective -- you've heard me say this many times, we're going play the hand that the economy deals us. We're going to use the challenge that we're facing right now of a mix headwind as an excuse not to make continued margin improvement, and that's what we're all about. That's what's driving our initiative of G55. That's what's still driving our plus or minus 60 operating ratio by full year 2019 focus. I mean it's -- we have to kind of live in that world, but clearly, those challenges that we faced here on the mix have been challenges.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Obviously, you've done an admirable job in what is a fairly high fixed cost business in managing costs and bringing them down aggressively in line with -- or almost in line with the rate where we should see revenues fall. Help me think about this, though,
componenttext: Obviously, you've done an admirable job in what is a fairly high fixed cost business in managing costs and bringing them down aggressively in line with -- or almost in line with the rate where we should see revenues fall. Help me think about this, though, is if we see further volume declines, can you be as productive? In other words, I mean I'm assuming this. We furlough 1,400 locomotives. You're not furloughing the youngest, most efficient locomotives. You're furloughing the oldest most in need of maintenance least efficient locomotives. So if you make further cuts, is it realistic to expect that you can be as effective in your cost control as you have been so far? Or am I thinking about it incorrectly?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. It is reasonable to expect us to continue to be able to be effective at adjusting our cost structure even in the face of further volume declines. Now we're not saying we anticipate things get worse from where they are right now. But if they were to, w
componenttext: No. It is reasonable to expect us to continue to be able to be effective at adjusting our cost structure even in the face of further volume declines. Now we're not saying we anticipate things get worse from where they are right now. But if they were to, we have the ability to continue to adjust our cost structure. We've demonstrated that to this point, there's still levers to be pulled. We have much preferred to grow but we will pull those levers as we need to.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: But will cost-cutting be as productive in the future as it has been in the past?
componenttext: But will cost-cutting be as productive in the future as it has been in the past?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: From my perspective, there are ample opportunities to be more efficient everywhere I look on the railroad. We will continue to be able to generate productivity from that perspective. And as we have to take larger chunks of cost out, we'll continue to evaluate that and do that effectively as well.
