componenttext: The first question I wanted to ask was on your optimism for the second half in grain. Up to now, you've been a little bit cautious about being optimistic in that segment just given your view on storage in the U.S. I just wonder if you could update us there on your thoughts?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hopefully, this is Eric, hopefully, I was sounding more balanced and optimistic. But if you look at storage right now, there's -- storage is about 30% higher, storage of all types, grain, beans, et cetera, than what the 5-year average has been. And then i
componenttext: Hopefully, this is Eric, hopefully, I was sounding more balanced and optimistic. But if you look at storage right now, there's -- storage is about 30% higher, storage of all types, grain, beans, et cetera, than what the 5-year average has been. And then if you look at the crop, there was something like 6 million more acres of corn planted this year, and it's still all depended upon kind of the weather and the harvest. But right now, it looks like it's going to be pretty decent yields from the current crop. And so if you look at the pretty decent yields from the current crop, if you look at the high storage levels on a historical basis, if you look at some of the challenges that, in particular, South American crops have had, it suggests that there's going to be a opportunity to move grain in the second half of the year at a higher run rate than what we saw in the first half.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And in terms of thinking about how much of your Ag Products segment is really sensitive to the size of the crops, should we be thinking about that grain subsegment? Or are grain product movements also very sensitive to the size of the crop?
componenttext: Great. And in terms of thinking about how much of your Ag Products segment is really sensitive to the size of the crops, should we be thinking about that grain subsegment? Or are grain product movements also very sensitive to the size of the crop?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So grains clearly are -- grain products are from the standpoint, the driver in grain products is ethanol as a large portion of that; and then next kind of the soybean meals. And so those are also very sensitive to the crops, and basically the crop pricing
componenttext: So grains clearly are -- grain products are from the standpoint, the driver in grain products is ethanol as a large portion of that; and then next kind of the soybean meals. And so those are also very sensitive to the crops, and basically the crop pricing and whether or not ethanol that will be in the money.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Ravi Shanker with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Ravi Shanker with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: You said earlier that you don't necessarily price, set your price to be 50 bps, well above inflation. Can you just talk about what might be any structural drivers that kind of keeps that margin and prevents pricing from closing the gap further to inflatio
componenttext: You said earlier that you don't necessarily price, set your price to be 50 bps, well above inflation. Can you just talk about what might be any structural drivers that kind of keeps that margin and prevents pricing from closing the gap further to inflation?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ravi, this is Lance. When you think about pricing for us, you start at the highest level, which is, we try to provide an excellent customer service and excellent experience, which generates value for our customers, and we price for that. In that context,
componenttext: Ravi, this is Lance. When you think about pricing for us, you start at the highest level, which is, we try to provide an excellent customer service and excellent experience, which generates value for our customers, and we price for that. In that context, we are constantly looking to make a reasonable return so that it's a reinvestable piece of business, and then we have the reality of the dynamics of other competitive modes or competition. You put that altogether, and that's what informs our ability to price. So when you think about it going forward, markets that have less modal capacity, markets that are robust and growing strongly, those are better markets to price in than not. But that generally informs our pricing scheme.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I had a follow-up on coal as well. You touched on this in response to a previous question. But the 3Q coal level was somewhat soft given the step-up in the burn. I'm wondering if you think that, that's not sustainable or why that would not -- or why
componenttext: Okay. I had a follow-up on coal as well. You touched on this in response to a previous question. But the 3Q coal level was somewhat soft given the step-up in the burn. I'm wondering if you think that, that's not sustainable or why that would not -- or why inventories will not be drawn down further. And also, when we look out into 2017, there are some folks talking about a potential coal book [ph] as -- where you see v-shape recovery in '17 just given drawdowns. How would you dimension that? Or what kind of probability would you assign a case for that?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ravi, I think you're right. If you look at kind of the burn, the burn has stepped up, but the inventories still are high on a relative basis. They're still 35 days higher than a 5-year average. So you have to burn a lot of those inventories even as the bu
componenttext: Ravi, I think you're right. If you look at kind of the burn, the burn has stepped up, but the inventories still are high on a relative basis. They're still 35 days higher than a 5-year average. So you have to burn a lot of those inventories even as the burn has stepped up. And so that is a headwind to growing coal volumes in the third quarter. As you look at the outlook for next year, as we say always, it depends on weather, it depends on natural gas pricing, it depends on energy consumption. So that's what's going to drive in the future.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from the line of Tom Wadewitz with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from the line of Tom Wadewitz with UBS.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: A quick one first on inventories. I don't think you've commented on inventories and the effect on Intermodal. Does that situation seem to be getting any better? Or is that still an issue that makes it hard to see a lot of improvement in Intermodal volume?
componenttext: A quick one first on inventories. I don't think you've commented on inventories and the effect on Intermodal. Does that situation seem to be getting any better? Or is that still an issue that makes it hard to see a lot of improvement in Intermodal volume?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Tom, inventories have gotten better every -- we treat it from the 7-year highs that we saw last month. They're still high in a relative basis, but they are coming down.
componenttext: Yes, Tom, inventories have gotten better every -- we treat it from the 7-year highs that we saw last month. They're still high in a relative basis, but they are coming down.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tom, to add a little technicolor to that. In that domestic Intermodal space, something that Eric continually reminds us is that there's a lot of opportunity out there from a truck competitive perspective. And that really informs a pretty good portion of o
componenttext: Tom, to add a little technicolor to that. In that domestic Intermodal space, something that Eric continually reminds us is that there's a lot of opportunity out there from a truck competitive perspective. And that really informs a pretty good portion of our ability to grow. That overall consumer demand and demand for goods is what is informed by that retail-to-sales inventory ratio and inventory in general.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the second question, how would you -- just wondering if you could kind of frame the way we would think about operating leverage as volumes get less worse, and then hopefully, I guess, see then 2017 actually grow. Given current train lengths
componenttext: Okay. And then the second question, how would you -- just wondering if you could kind of frame the way we would think about operating leverage as volumes get less worse, and then hopefully, I guess, see then 2017 actually grow. Given current train lengths and ability to expand that given the initiatives, Lance, that you mentioned, how would we think about the operating leverage and kind of how long you can go with handling volume without adding a whole lot of incremental cost?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Cameron?
componenttext: Cameron?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: With the amount of locomotives we have in storage, the locomotive productivity leverage is fantastic. On the employee side, depending on where growth shows up, we will continue to bring furloughed employees back and potentially transfer employees to the p
componenttext: With the amount of locomotives we have in storage, the locomotive productivity leverage is fantastic. On the employee side, depending on where growth shows up, we will continue to bring furloughed employees back and potentially transfer employees to the part of the network where growth is residing. So we continue to see our employee pipeline to be staying very, very lean. And there's great opportunity in every category with train size. Our coal network is truly the only network that is optimized to a very large extent. Every other network we have has plenty of headroom with train size.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you size that as that 10% room or 20%? Or is there a way to kind of frame that train size opportunity?
componenttext: Can you size that as that 10% room or 20%? Or is there a way to kind of frame that train size opportunity?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you see us quarter-to-quarter making continued improvement, and we feel very confident you will continue to see that.
componenttext: I think you see us quarter-to-quarter making continued improvement, and we feel very confident you will continue to see that.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Tom. This is Lance again. We've done a nice job staying ahead of demand in terms of overall capacity, whether it's fungible capacity or track capacity. Clearly, at this point, given how we built out the network and we're supporting 180,000, 190,000,
componenttext: Hey, Tom. This is Lance again. We've done a nice job staying ahead of demand in terms of overall capacity, whether it's fungible capacity or track capacity. Clearly, at this point, given how we built out the network and we're supporting 180,000, 190,000, 7-day carloads a couple of years ago, we've got ample capacity for growth at this point.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I can. We won't do this, I promise on too many questions, Tom. This is Rob. I got a follow on, and that is, all of that leverage that we're confident and that Cam and Lance just talked through, all embedded in that drive to that 60 plus or minus operat
componenttext: If I can. We won't do this, I promise on too many questions, Tom. This is Rob. I got a follow on, and that is, all of that leverage that we're confident and that Cam and Lance just talked through, all embedded in that drive to that 60 plus or minus operating ratio. And of course, as you know, we're going to -- we're striving to even set our sights beyond that at a 55. So it's that confidence that we are well positioned with positive volume growth to be in a great position of leveraging that.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from the line of Ken Hoexter with Bank of America.
componenttext: The next question is from the line of Ken Hoexter with Bank of America.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just want to follow up on the international side of Intermodal. Eric, you talked a bit about carrier consolidation. I wouldn't think that has much to do with the demand side, that's them filling their slots or they oversupply in the market. What are your
componenttext: Just want to follow up on the international side of Intermodal. Eric, you talked a bit about carrier consolidation. I wouldn't think that has much to do with the demand side, that's them filling their slots or they oversupply in the market. What are your thoughts on the state of global trade? Seems like we're starting to see some of the port volumes pick up a bit. Just wanted to see if that's something you're seeing as well as any? Or is that a shift from the Panama Canal change or Swiss Canal? Any thoughts on the state of global trade?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I think if you look at the absolute volumes  and the PT trade, they are not strong. There are some period-to-period kind of shifts going on. And you do see some of the business that shifted to the canal because of the strike just gradually coming
componenttext: Yes, so I think if you look at the absolute volumes  and the PT trade, they are not strong. There are some period-to-period kind of shifts going on. And you do see some of the business that shifted to the canal because of the strike just gradually coming back there. So that's kind of coloring some of the trends. But the TP [ph] trade volumes are relatively weak from a historical standpoint. If you look at the carrier consolidation issues, there's huge volatility going on in there, as I mentioned that at last earnings release, significant volatility in terms of mergers, acquisitions. And that volatility does have impact to the supply chain, depending on which carriers have what book of business that you are aligned with. So that volatility is impacting what we see in the supply chain.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Rob, anything -- thoughts on the balance sheet. Obviously, a pretty strong situation here. Thoughts on increasing the buyback accelerating given the volatility in the stock. Just kind of your thoughts on cash flow.
componenttext: Great. Rob, anything -- thoughts on the balance sheet. Obviously, a pretty strong situation here. Thoughts on increasing the buyback accelerating given the volatility in the stock. Just kind of your thoughts on cash flow.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, Ken, as you know, it all starts with driving a stronger cash flow as we can, and we will -- we're obviously committed on returning cash to shareholders. And we'll continue to be opportunistic in terms of at what price and when and how much we
componenttext: Yes. I mean, Ken, as you know, it all starts with driving a stronger cash flow as we can, and we will -- we're obviously committed on returning cash to shareholders. And we'll continue to be opportunistic in terms of at what price and when and how much we actually buy back. So same philosophy, focus on generating as much cash as we can, so that we're in a high-class challenge of deciding what to do with that cash. And I would expect that we'll continue to be opportunistic as we move forward on the share buyback.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is coming from the line of Brandon Oglenski with Barclays.
componenttext: The next question is coming from the line of Brandon Oglenski with Barclays.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Eric Morgan on for Brandon. I just wanted to follow up on some of your grain comments. It sounds like the setup from a harvest perspective is pretty constructive. I was just wondering if you could provide a bit more color specifically with corn pr
componenttext: This is Eric Morgan on for Brandon. I just wanted to follow up on some of your grain comments. It sounds like the setup from a harvest perspective is pretty constructive. I was just wondering if you could provide a bit more color specifically with corn prices coming down so much recently and the dollar is still strong, if there's enough storage capacity, could we be in a similar environment as last year where farmer just don't want to move the crop?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Eric, I think you pegged all of the dynamics exactly correct. Corn prices are coming down. They're projected to come down even more because of the strong harvest that is projected to come. But there is an issue where it will have to move, so that is
componenttext: Yes, Eric, I think you pegged all of the dynamics exactly correct. Corn prices are coming down. They're projected to come down even more because of the strong harvest that is projected to come. But there is an issue where it will have to move, so that is exactly the dynamic that's going on. There's probably some headwinds the farmers wanting to move it, but there's probably some physical logistics where they have to move it, and that's some of, I think, what we're seeing in the outlook.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, I appreciate it. And just a quick one, is there kind of a good way to think about land sales going forward?
componenttext: Okay, I appreciate it. And just a quick one, is there kind of a good way to think about land sales going forward?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

componenttext: I'm sorry, Brandon, could you repeat that?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just in other income line, is there kind of a good run rate to think about with respect to land sales?
componenttext: Yes. Just in other income line, is there kind of a good run rate to think about with respect to land sales?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry. Yes, it's yours.
componenttext: I'm sorry. Yes, it's yours.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Eric, no. I mean, the other income, plus or minus 150, is kind of the number. But no, it -- those tend to be as you've seen, lumpy, and there's no straight line way of thinking about that.
componenttext: Eric, no. I mean, the other income, plus or minus 150, is kind of the number. But no, it -- those tend to be as you've seen, lumpy, and there's no straight line way of thinking about that.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Jeff Kauffman with Buckingham Research.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Jeff Kauffman with Buckingham Research.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Eric, I just wanted to ask you a question about in the money, which I think is something that came up a few questions ago. If we look at Powder River Basin coal, say, relative to Western markets, relative to some of the Midwest markets, just where prices
componenttext: Eric, I just wanted to ask you a question about in the money, which I think is something that came up a few questions ago. If we look at Powder River Basin coal, say, relative to Western markets, relative to some of the Midwest markets, just where prices are now, where prices may or may not be. And if I look at ethanol, with corn prices down and diesel fuel prices up, how close are we to being in the money in these products in terms of the forward outlook?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I assume you're asking a coal question and an ethanol question separately. So on the coal question, I would say it depends on what energy region you're in, what ISO, what RTO you're in. It depends on the utility that's within that region. So it depends
componenttext: So I assume you're asking a coal question and an ethanol question separately. So on the coal question, I would say it depends on what energy region you're in, what ISO, what RTO you're in. It depends on the utility that's within that region. So it depends on a lot of different things. I think it's instructive to look at the fact of the reference increase in burn month-over-month to indicate that, clearly, there are a lot more utilities that are in the money just if you look at that increased burn. So that would be my coal comment. In terms of ethanol, I think ethanol, from a used standpoint, is "always in the money" because it's needed as necessary oxygenate and then replacement from the MBTEs for gasoline. And so as gasoline volumes go, ethanol blending with that will go. The question is, how much margin the ethanol manufacturers are making? But ethanol is more driven by gasoline sales and the need to get the oxygenate and the replacement for the MBTEs.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeff, one piece on that PRB answer, and that is while natural gas, where it is right now to 70-ish, plus/minus, has put some additional units "in the money" I think in the context you're asking or weather in the central part of the country and in the Sout
componenttext: Jeff, one piece on that PRB answer, and that is while natural gas, where it is right now to 70-ish, plus/minus, has put some additional units "in the money" I think in the context you're asking or weather in the central part of the country and in the Southeast is helping tremendously with increased electricity demand, and that's putting more units online just from a raw demand perspective.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that's where I was going with this, is to the extent you have incremental burn demand, are you more in the money and more likely to be moving coal. Just one last follow-up, Eric, on the brown sand comment that you made on the frac sand. Are we getti
componenttext: Well, that's where I was going with this, is to the extent you have incremental burn demand, are you more in the money and more likely to be moving coal. Just one last follow-up, Eric, on the brown sand comment that you made on the frac sand. Are we getting to the point where we're seeing increased demand for the white frac sand or not yet?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So if you look at the number of drilling rigs, they're up modestly. I think the numbers, you're going from like 400 rigs to 430 rigs or something like that. That's close to probably what the number is compared to 1,000 rigs last year. So it's increas
componenttext: Yes. So if you look at the number of drilling rigs, they're up modestly. I think the numbers, you're going from like 400 rigs to 430 rigs or something like that. That's close to probably what the number is compared to 1,000 rigs last year. So it's increased modestly because the price of fuel has increased, and there's slightly more drilling activity. I think the amount of white sand we'll see will be a direct correlation to as drilling activity comes on, you'll see white sand demand go up.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from the line of Justin Long with Stephens.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from the line of Justin Long with Stephens.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I wanted to ask about the volume guidance for a 6% to 8% decline for the full year. So that's worse than your guidance last quarter for a mid-single-digit decline. But if we look at 2Q volumes, they finished fairly close to your initial expectation for
componenttext: So I wanted to ask about the volume guidance for a 6% to 8% decline for the full year. So that's worse than your guidance last quarter for a mid-single-digit decline. But if we look at 2Q volumes, they finished fairly close to your initial expectation for a 10% decline. And it sounds like you're a little bit more incrementally positive on coal and grain. So can you just help us understand what drove this guidance reduction in terms of volumes, seems like, in the back half of the year?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Justin, this is Rob. I would say that the biggest piece, and I totally understand your question because you're exactly right in terms of the way you kind of mapped through that, is -- centers around that consumer. I mean, it centers around the Interm
componenttext: Yes, Justin, this is Rob. I would say that the biggest piece, and I totally understand your question because you're exactly right in terms of the way you kind of mapped through that, is -- centers around that consumer. I mean, it centers around the Intermodal product as much as anything else and the cautiousness that we're expressing today. You're right, we did come in a little bit stronger in the second quarter largely driven by pickup in coal, if you look at the difference in the second quarter where we finished versus what we had guided to. But the full year number, simply said, is largely driven by that consumer cautiousness that we're seeing in the Intermodal space.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. That's helpful. And secondly, I wanted to get your thoughts around how your core price increases and general merchandise are trending relative to your core price increases in Intermodal? I don't -- I know you don't break that out specifically
componenttext: Okay. Great. That's helpful. And secondly, I wanted to get your thoughts around how your core price increases and general merchandise are trending relative to your core price increases in Intermodal? I don't -- I know you don't break that out specifically. But are you seeing general merchandise and Intermodal pricing trending up at similar levels? Or is the Intermodal increase something like 100 basis points less because of the excess capacity in truck load?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Justin, you nailed it when you said, you know we don't give that break out, because, I mean, we endeavor to price to market and drive value in every one of our commodity groups. But we don't break out by commodity, as you're striving for.
componenttext: Justin, you nailed it when you said, you know we don't give that break out, because, I mean, we endeavor to price to market and drive value in every one of our commodity groups. But we don't break out by commodity, as you're striving for.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: But just from a high level, can you say that general merchandise price increases are above what you're seeing in Intermodal?
componenttext: But just from a high level, can you say that general merchandise price increases are above what you're seeing in Intermodal?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, and I would say, it -- number one, it varies. I mean, each sort of negotiation is separate. But no, I wouldn't even go so far to say that.
componenttext: No, and I would say, it -- number one, it varies. I mean, each sort of negotiation is separate. But no, I wouldn't even go so far to say that.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from the line of David Vernon with Bernstein Research.
componenttext: The next question is from the line of David Vernon with Bernstein Research.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Cameron, maybe a question for you. It looks like the volatility on the ocean carrier alliances and some of the changing in vessel cost is bringing down that international Intermodal, and you saw like 5% reduction in train length. How long do think it'll b
componenttext: Cameron, maybe a question for you. It looks like the volatility on the ocean carrier alliances and some of the changing in vessel cost is bringing down that international Intermodal, and you saw like 5% reduction in train length. How long do think it'll be before you can get that back up? Or should we be expecting you to kind of have to deal with that lower train length because of this headwind?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We adjust our Intermodal program on a weekly basis looking at inbound volumes, and Eric does his best to forecast. And so balancing customer requirements and productivity is always a tight rope. Our first priority is to take care of our customers. And so
componenttext: We adjust our Intermodal program on a weekly basis looking at inbound volumes, and Eric does his best to forecast. And so balancing customer requirements and productivity is always a tight rope. Our first priority is to take care of our customers. And so we will continue to make those adjustments on a week-by-week basis.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Would you expect that train length back up?
componenttext: Would you expect that train length back up?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: As we step into the second half of the year, depending, as Rob outlined, on what the consumer does driving Intermodal, we absolutely can bring that train size metric right back in line.
componenttext: As we step into the second half of the year, depending, as Rob outlined, on what the consumer does driving Intermodal, we absolutely can bring that train size metric right back in line.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then maybe, Rob, as a quick follow-up, could you comment a little bit of update, the cadence in the operating results through the quarter? It would seem like you have been aggressively kind of pushing down on the headcount and then saw that sequ
componenttext: Okay. And then maybe, Rob, as a quick follow-up, could you comment a little bit of update, the cadence in the operating results through the quarter? It would seem like you have been aggressively kind of pushing down on the headcount and then saw that sequential improvement into the volume growth. I guess, did results -- was there any kind of sort of inflection forward in the results, in the trajectory results as we move through the quarter?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: By following your question, David, I would say no. I mean, it was a continuation of our focus on being as efficient and as productive as we can, which I think our results reflect -- lined up well given unfortunate downturn in 11% volume. So I'd say there'
componenttext: By following your question, David, I would say no. I mean, it was a continuation of our focus on being as efficient and as productive as we can, which I think our results reflect -- lined up well given unfortunate downturn in 11% volume. So I'd say there's nothing unique about that, other than it was good hard work across the entire organization to make the right decisions.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the run rate profitability was kind of the same at the beginning of the month as at the end of the month -- or in the quarter?
componenttext: So the run rate profitability was kind of the same at the beginning of the month as at the end of the month -- or in the quarter?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, yet fuel was a big dip. I'd say there's nothing to call out there other than the fuel, which rose late in the quarter.
componenttext: Yes. I mean, yet fuel was a big dip. I'd say there's nothing to call out there other than the fuel, which rose late in the quarter.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Rob Salmon with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Rob Salmon with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Cameron, actually, just to dig in a little bit more with regard to the Intermodal train sizes. Can you describe kind of what was going on with the domestic Intermodal train size versus the international and kind of the factors that was driving the relativ
componenttext: Cameron, actually, just to dig in a little bit more with regard to the Intermodal train sizes. Can you describe kind of what was going on with the domestic Intermodal train size versus the international and kind of the factors that was driving the relative weakness that we saw with regard to train lengths?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the domestic front, we will pay attention to what is being in-gated on a weekly basis. We have extreme sensitivity to UPS and some of our LTL customers that we will always preference for any of those trains as long as the volumes are adequate. As I sai
componenttext: On the domestic front, we will pay attention to what is being in-gated on a weekly basis. We have extreme sensitivity to UPS and some of our LTL customers that we will always preference for any of those trains as long as the volumes are adequate. As I said, in the international side, we really depend on Eric's forecast on what is hitting our ports, and we'll make the appropriate decisions on a week-to-week basis. The good news on the Intermodal front despite the decline is that there's plenty of opportunity to increase train size as we see volumes coming back into that space.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rob, this is Eric. I would not add a lot of focus on kind of the train size in Intermodal. We are always adding different products and services as part of our growth and value proposition, as part of our conversion strategy. And so you're going to be addi
componenttext: Rob, this is Eric. I would not add a lot of focus on kind of the train size in Intermodal. We are always adding different products and services as part of our growth and value proposition, as part of our conversion strategy. And so you're going to be adding a product or service in the lane and they will start small, because that has a potential to grow, and that's part of the mix in train size that you'll always see.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. That makes sense. I guess, Eric, kind of a follow-up with regard to this kind of market dynamics. Can you give us a sense, if we think about Automotive kind of on a very holistic basis, including kind of inbound parts to the manufacturers of the au
componenttext: Great. That makes sense. I guess, Eric, kind of a follow-up with regard to this kind of market dynamics. Can you give us a sense, if we think about Automotive kind of on a very holistic basis, including kind of inbound parts to the manufacturers of the automotive as well as the automotive part producers, how big that represents? And then maybe, which networks that's running on between unit train and manifest?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So trying to make sure I understand your question. So auto parts network is a growing network. It grew about 9%, 10% in the quarter. It is -- it's smaller than our multilevel network, but it is growing. Probably 2/3, 3/4 of it does run as part of a
componenttext: Okay. So trying to make sure I understand your question. So auto parts network is a growing network. It grew about 9%, 10% in the quarter. It is -- it's smaller than our multilevel network, but it is growing. Probably 2/3, 3/4 of it does run as part of a premium Intermodal network runway container shipment, and that's of necessity because it is a premium product.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And if I think about just how big it is as a percentage of total volumes, so just like the Automotive line segment, it's a little over 10%. But if I include kind of the metals that are going to the factories as well as parts in Intermodal that would
componenttext: Yes. And if I think about just how big it is as a percentage of total volumes, so just like the Automotive line segment, it's a little over 10%. But if I include kind of the metals that are going to the factories as well as parts in Intermodal that would be going to the automotive parts producers, how much additional volume would that represent for your network? Is there a good rule of thumb or not really?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't know if there's a good rule of thumb there.
componenttext: I don't know if there's a good rule of thumb there.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: But if I can, Rob, this is Rob. I would say, I mean, you're using the autos example, which is a good one, and there are other examples where we enjoy -- to your point, we enjoy the sort of a multiple move. And in fact, I would just -- using your example,
componenttext: But if I can, Rob, this is Rob. I would say, I mean, you're using the autos example, which is a good one, and there are other examples where we enjoy -- to your point, we enjoy the sort of a multiple move. And in fact, I would just -- using your example, I'd say, we also supply coal to the utilities providing the electricity to make the cars, so there's a lot of moving parts there. Specifically what percent in autos, we don't have that.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Jason Seidl Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Jason Seidl Cowen and Company.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I apologize if this was covered, but our phone dropped here for a little bit here. Eric, you mentioned that there was a sequential increase in the burn from June to May, I think you said from May to June, I think you said 47%. What's the historical increa
componenttext: I apologize if this was covered, but our phone dropped here for a little bit here. Eric, you mentioned that there was a sequential increase in the burn from June to May, I think you said from May to June, I think you said 47%. What's the historical increase in burn? Can you put that into perspective?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that -- yes, I don't have the historical number right at my fingertips. That is larger than the typically historical norm. As you know, we do have the shelf month there in the second quarter because you're not heating or cooling, and then you have to
componenttext: Yes, that -- yes, I don't have the historical number right at my fingertips. That is larger than the typically historical norm. As you know, we do have the shelf month there in the second quarter because you're not heating or cooling, and then you have to pick up cyclically. But that is higher than what you would typically see.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's good color. Also, I'm looking at your stock, obviously under a little bit of pressure today. I think based on some of the incoming calls, and obviously there's a little bit of worry of your core pricing falling down a little bit. If you had t
componenttext: Okay, that's good color. Also, I'm looking at your stock, obviously under a little bit of pressure today. I think based on some of the incoming calls, and obviously there's a little bit of worry of your core pricing falling down a little bit. If you had to bucket the pressure on core pricing between lose truck capacity and increased competition from other rail carriers, how would you do it on a percentage basis?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: As I said before, there are all those competitive factors that are going on. I mentioned earlier, it might have been while you dropped off the call, that there was surplus capacity in all modes, truck capacity, shipping capacity, rail capacity, and you do
componenttext: As I said before, there are all those competitive factors that are going on. I mentioned earlier, it might have been while you dropped off the call, that there was surplus capacity in all modes, truck capacity, shipping capacity, rail capacity, and you do see that capacity tightening across all modes as we look into the future.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So there wasn't one that was more prominent than the other as you look at 2Q?
componenttext: So there wasn't one that was more prominent than the other as you look at 2Q?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: All of those factors or factors that go into our pricing, we price to a value. And those are all factors.
componenttext: All of those factors or factors that go into our pricing, we price to a value. And those are all factors.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question would be from the line of John Barnes with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: The next question would be from the line of John Barnes with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to go back to your commentary around maybe some of the logistics in the grain business. So we've had a couple of decent harvest over the last couple of years. And for whatever reason, we keep hearing about the storage is tight and yet the crop ne
componenttext: I wanted to go back to your commentary around maybe some of the logistics in the grain business. So we've had a couple of decent harvest over the last couple of years. And for whatever reason, we keep hearing about the storage is tight and yet the crop never seems to kind of get moved. Have we finally hit that inflection point where the storage has tightened up, there's too much, the prior harvest is still in storage, and that this one just absolutely has to get moved this year?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't know if I'm an expert on kind of the inflection point of total storage. I do think, if you look at the trends and your seeing some of those trends materialize even now, storage is tight. Farm income is under stress given the lower pricing, and so
componenttext: I don't know if I'm an expert on kind of the inflection point of total storage. I do think, if you look at the trends and your seeing some of those trends materialize even now, storage is tight. Farm income is under stress given the lower pricing, and so there is a cash flow dynamic for farmers in terms of holding versus selling that comes into play here. There is a demand that's picking up because of the weakness in some international markets like South American markets, and then there's a big crop coming in. So if you look at all of those things, they do indicate that there's a high probability you're going to see strong moves.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then you mentioned the difficulty in South America. Strong U.S. dollar continues to plague the export activity. Is the domestic demand this year, domestic moves of grain going to be more important than they have been in years past? Do we see may
componenttext: Okay. And then you mentioned the difficulty in South America. Strong U.S. dollar continues to plague the export activity. Is the domestic demand this year, domestic moves of grain going to be more important than they have been in years past? Do we see maybe less of this moving for export purposes?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We do have a strong domestic franchise, as you know. Exports are picking up, and they're all interrelated. Because to the extent you have a strong export market, that takes the demand. And we also participate in the export market, whether it's moving into
componenttext: We do have a strong domestic franchise, as you know. Exports are picking up, and they're all interrelated. Because to the extent you have a strong export market, that takes the demand. And we also participate in the export market, whether it's moving into the Gulf, moving into the river, moving into the West Coast, particularly the PNW. So we have a strong domestic franchise, but the export markets also benefit us.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Eric, recall, John, that Mexico is also an export markets for us.
componenttext: And Eric, recall, John, that Mexico is also an export markets for us.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And so that -- but you're saying that the export, you actually are seeing some movement in the export side of the business?
componenttext: Okay. And so that -- but you're saying that the export, you actually are seeing some movement in the export side of the business?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Export markets are picking up.
componenttext: Export markets are picking up.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from the line of Ben Hartford with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from the line of Ben Hartford with Robert W. Baird.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Curious how you feel about service today relative to, let's say, the high watermarks pre-2014. Some of the metrics, train speed being one of them, are back to those measures. Obviously, there's some mix and other elements at play. But how do you feel abou
componenttext: Curious how you feel about service today relative to, let's say, the high watermarks pre-2014. Some of the metrics, train speed being one of them, are back to those measures. Obviously, there's some mix and other elements at play. But how do you feel about the "service" across the network today relative to prior to the issues that you and the industry experienced in early '14?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Ben, so this is Lance. When you think about our overall network and the service we're providing, absent the impacts of things like the flooding that we've experienced in Texas through some just epic weather events, we are performing essentially at a
componenttext: Yes. Ben, so this is Lance. When you think about our overall network and the service we're providing, absent the impacts of things like the flooding that we've experienced in Texas through some just epic weather events, we are performing essentially at a 2013- or 2012-type level. So our service performance level, on average, in aggregate, is about as good as it's been for this kind of volume level. Our intent, and what Cameron and team are constantly working on, is ways to improve that, right? So '12 and '13 are a benchmark. They're not the only benchmark. We think we can do better than that over time. And his team is constantly working with a commercial team and other functions at the railroad to try to find ways to improve that service product.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. Are there any specific elements or areas of service where you don't believe that you're back to those 2012, '13 benchmarks that still have some room to go?
componenttext: That's helpful. Are there any specific elements or areas of service where you don't believe that you're back to those 2012, '13 benchmarks that still have some room to go?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would tell you we have room for improvement virtually everywhere, and that's not a statement of not as good as '12 or '13. That's a statement of there are -- we are never perfect. There's always an opportunity to run the network more on time from o
componenttext: Yes, I would tell you we have room for improvement virtually everywhere, and that's not a statement of not as good as '12 or '13. That's a statement of there are -- we are never perfect. There's always an opportunity to run the network more on time from original terminal to making sure we don't leave any cars behind to running the premium domestic Intermodal product at greater speeds or at more significant -- significantly reduced span. All of those things are within our visuals, and we're working on all of them.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Mark Levin with BB&T Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Mark Levin with BB&T Capital Markets.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Most of my questions have been asked and answered. I just wanted to see if there was any potential impact from the Mexican excise tax credit benefit, the one that KSU alluded to yesterday?
componenttext: Most of my questions have been asked and answered. I just wanted to see if there was any potential impact from the Mexican excise tax credit benefit, the one that KSU alluded to yesterday?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No.
componenttext: No.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No benefit whatsoever?
componenttext: No benefit whatsoever?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right.
componenttext: Right.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then with regard to auto yield and the mix headwind that you mentioned this quarter, when you look forward, is that something, as we model RPU in the auto segment, we should be mindful of? And what type of expectations should we have as t
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then with regard to auto yield and the mix headwind that you mentioned this quarter, when you look forward, is that something, as we model RPU in the auto segment, we should be mindful of? And what type of expectations should we have as that -- looking forward there?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our auto parts business is growing faster than our finished vehicles business because that is the growth area, and you saw that in the second quarter. auto parts business has a lower RPU than the finished vehicles business.
componenttext: Our auto parts business is growing faster than our finished vehicles business because that is the growth area, and you saw that in the second quarter. auto parts business has a lower RPU than the finished vehicles business.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And will it be -- the decrease is moderate? Or is that sort of the way to think about that going forward this quarter?
componenttext: And will it be -- the decrease is moderate? Or is that sort of the way to think about that going forward this quarter?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: There aren't decreases. The auto parts business is growing.
componenttext: There aren't decreases. The auto parts business is growing.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from the line of Donald Broughton with Avondale Partners.
componenttext: The next question is from the line of Donald Broughton with Avondale Partners.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Help me better understand core pricing. Obviously, it's a very challenging environment. And as you've reported, your core pricing part has been essentially cut in half over the last 4 or 5 quarters. Did you report that 2% core pricing represent the pricin
componenttext: Help me better understand core pricing. Obviously, it's a very challenging environment. And as you've reported, your core pricing part has been essentially cut in half over the last 4 or 5 quarters. Did you report that 2% core pricing represent the pricing achieved on all new contracts settled in that quarter that, for instance, 2% being just those settled in the second quarter? Or does that represent the amount of year-over-year gains made in your overall book of business?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Don, this is Rob. The way we calculate that core price number is what did we actually yield in that quarter from our pricing actions. And as you I think know, the way we calculate that, I'm proud to say, is ultra-conservative, and that is that we tak
componenttext: Yes. Don, this is Rob. The way we calculate that core price number is what did we actually yield in that quarter from our pricing actions. And as you I think know, the way we calculate that, I'm proud to say, is ultra-conservative, and that is that we take it across our entire book of revenue even if -- either as work contracts that were being repriced in that particular time frame, it's what did we yield overall. And I would also just point out, of course, as you know, given that calculation, when we don't have the benefit of positive growth in commodities like coal, we obviously no longer have any of the legacy renewals. I mean, that's part of the change if you look at where we are today versus where we were a year plus ago.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wait a second, Rob, I'm a little confused here. So it's over -- it's the contracts reset in the quarter and their effect in the overall book, is that what you just said?
componenttext: Wait a second, Rob, I'm a little confused here. So it's over -- it's the contracts reset in the quarter and their effect in the overall book, is that what you just said?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it's not necessarily what was reset in the quarter, it's what dollars -- the calculus is simply what dollars did we yield from price increases during the quarter. So it perhaps was something that was reset prior to the quarter, but that's -- and again
componenttext: No, it's not necessarily what was reset in the quarter, it's what dollars -- the calculus is simply what dollars did we yield from price increases during the quarter. So it perhaps was something that was reset prior to the quarter, but that's -- and again, and what did we yield against our entire book of revenue.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the denominator in the equation is the overall book of business?
componenttext: So the denominator in the equation is the overall book of business?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's right.
componenttext: That's right.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So that means the core pricing -- for the core price to deteriorate from 4% to 3.5% to 3% to 2.5% to 2%, it means the pricing your achieving on all new contracts is actually less than 2%?
componenttext: So that means the core pricing -- for the core price to deteriorate from 4% to 3.5% to 3% to 2.5% to 2%, it means the pricing your achieving on all new contracts is actually less than 2%?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Don, it -- there's a number of moving parts, and Rob just walked you through them. One thing that's happening is, we might have achieved incremental price on a piece of business that isn't moving or isn't moving at the same volume, so we don't get the ben
componenttext: Don, it -- there's a number of moving parts, and Rob just walked you through them. One thing that's happening is, we might have achieved incremental price on a piece of business that isn't moving or isn't moving at the same volume, so we don't get the benefit of that price. It doesn't affect the top line. It could be that A-lift is changing period-to-period. I mean, there's a number of moving parts there. You can't just presume the calculus is lower yields period-to-period.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. But if the -- for the overall, the denominator here is the overall book of business and the rate of rate increase has to be less than what the core is that you're stating, no matter how perverse the mix gets in coal?
componenttext: Right. But if the -- for the overall, the denominator here is the overall book of business and the rate of rate increase has to be less than what the core is that you're stating, no matter how perverse the mix gets in coal?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean -- but we're agreeing that the yields on the pricing this quarter, for lots of different reasons, was lower.
componenttext: Yes. I mean -- but we're agreeing that the yields on the pricing this quarter, for lots of different reasons, was lower.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So then, let me ask another question. Is there a floor? Is there a rate of core pricing at which you're going to simply draw the line and say no, we will not accept less pricing than that, that we'll lose the volumes if we have to, but we're not goi
componenttext: Okay. So then, let me ask another question. Is there a floor? Is there a rate of core pricing at which you're going to simply draw the line and say no, we will not accept less pricing than that, that we'll lose the volumes if we have to, but we're not going to accept the lower level of pricing than, say, 1%, 1.5% or 2%?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Don, there -- we've stated even earlier in this call, there is a floor. And a floor is, is it reinvestable and does it reflect the value that we're delivering to that particular customer market? So we don't think of floors in terms of percent yield or per
componenttext: Don, there -- we've stated even earlier in this call, there is a floor. And a floor is, is it reinvestable and does it reflect the value that we're delivering to that particular customer market? So we don't think of floors in terms of percent yield or percent price. We think of floors in terms of if that piece of business or book of business is not reinvestable, it becomes much less attractive to us. And we've demonstrated over a long period of time that we will choose not to pursue business that does not generate an attractive financial return over a long period of time.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Keith Schoonmaker with Morningstar.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Keith Schoonmaker with Morningstar.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd like to ask a bit more about the Automotive franchise that was a longer-term focus. First, what portion of the Automotive portfolio consist of moves to or from Mexico? And could you describe the positive and negative impact your franchise from product
componenttext: I'd like to ask a bit more about the Automotive franchise that was a longer-term focus. First, what portion of the Automotive portfolio consist of moves to or from Mexico? And could you describe the positive and negative impact your franchise from production shift into Mexico compared to prior production locations?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So about 1/2 of our franchise is, 2 are from Mexico, that's all in finished vehicles and parts. We -- the Mexico volume is growing, as you know. Historically, it was like 2 million vehicles. I think this year, they're probably up to about 3.7 million
componenttext: Yes. So about 1/2 of our franchise is, 2 are from Mexico, that's all in finished vehicles and parts. We -- the Mexico volume is growing, as you know. Historically, it was like 2 million vehicles. I think this year, they're probably up to about 3.7 million vehicles produced in Mexico. The forecasts are that they're going to get close to about 5 million vehicles produced in Mexico. We think we have a great Mexico franchise. We're the only railroad that has rail connectivity to all 6 rail border crossings. We have great interline business relationships with every railroad in Mexico. We also have multimodal relationship that we're working within Mexico. So we think we have a great, great franchise, and we'll partake in that uptick over time.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so the shifts in general, Eric, of production in Mexico as it close in the U.S. or Canada, it's a net positive, surely, from the revenue gains? Or is it negative due to other factors like length to haul?
componenttext: And so the shifts in general, Eric, of production in Mexico as it close in the U.S. or Canada, it's a net positive, surely, from the revenue gains? Or is it negative due to other factors like length to haul?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so there's a lot of factors that go in. I would say, generally, we think that the net shift is a positive for our franchise.
componenttext: Yes, so there's a lot of factors that go in. I would say, generally, we think that the net shift is a positive for our franchise.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Scott Schneeberger with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Scott Schneeberger with Oppenheimer.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Curious, in the industrial production, in the industrial product segment, you called out the severe weather in Texas in the quarter, but otherwise, very strong construction activity. But could you just speak to kind of the 2Q to 3Q dynamic there and the t
componenttext: Curious, in the industrial production, in the industrial product segment, you called out the severe weather in Texas in the quarter, but otherwise, very strong construction activity. But could you just speak to kind of the 2Q to 3Q dynamic there and the trend in the back half assuming that we don't have bad weather events going forward?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we see a normal cyclical pickup as you go to the 2Q to the 3Q just because of the summer construction season that you see across -- most of our serving territory don't have as much construction in the winter as you do in the summer, so we do expect t
componenttext: Yes, we see a normal cyclical pickup as you go to the 2Q to the 3Q just because of the summer construction season that you see across -- most of our serving territory don't have as much construction in the winter as you do in the summer, so we do expect to see sequential pick up. You also are seeing some strengthening in housing starts, not as much as you would expect based on the demographic trends. We think that's a positive for the long term for our business, because the demographic trends are suggesting there has to be a stronger pickup than what we've seen. So you are still seeing that along with the cyclical trends, so we think, sequentially, that will be positive for us.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just on this -- the new potential minimum crew size rule that's being considered. Could you just discuss the company perspective and proceed timing on -- if something should happen, how you approach that then?
componenttext: Okay. And then just on this -- the new potential minimum crew size rule that's being considered. Could you just discuss the company perspective and proceed timing on -- if something should happen, how you approach that then?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thank you, Scott. Regarding the FRA's proposed rule on minimum crew size, historically, that's been a topic for collective bargaining over the past number of decades, and we believe that's where it belongs. There is no evidence that crew size is rela
componenttext: Yes, thank you, Scott. Regarding the FRA's proposed rule on minimum crew size, historically, that's been a topic for collective bargaining over the past number of decades, and we believe that's where it belongs. There is no evidence that crew size is related to safety. The FRA stated that in the preamble to their own rule. The NTSP, the National Transportation Safety Board, has also stated they see no empirical evidence between crew size and safety. Having said that, we do not have any plan right know to reduce crew size on our -- in our locomotives. What we think should happen is we should allow technology to take its course and determine when it's appropriate for some of the work to be removed from the cab and to be placed somewhere else. There is an amount of work that gets done for every train, and that work needs to be done. It's just a matter of where it will be done. So that's our perspective on that rule.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. At this time, I would turn the floor back to Mr. Lance Fritz for closing remarks.
componenttext: Thank you. At this time, I would turn the floor back to Mr. Lance Fritz for closing remarks.
