componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Tom Wadewitz with UBS.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask a little bit more on the pricing side. You commented how the higher natural gas price is helpful for coal. So that's obviously a constructive thing. But I'm wondering if you're optimistic if that will -- if that should help the coal tonnag
componenttext: I wanted to ask a little bit more on the pricing side. You commented how the higher natural gas price is helpful for coal. So that's obviously a constructive thing. But I'm wondering if you're optimistic if that will -- if that should help the coal tonnage and obviously have a -- if you have a normal winter and so forth. But what about the pricing in coal? If we stay at this gas price or go a little higher, do you think that the -- you'll be able to go transition to better competitive environment where you could raise price for coal transport? Or is that something that some of that pricing pressure would likely persist?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Tom, you're asking a couple of different things here. As you know, there are always a variety of market conditions that impact price, transportation, capacity availability and availability on transportation networks for other commodities, as you k
componenttext: Yes. So Tom, you're asking a couple of different things here. As you know, there are always a variety of market conditions that impact price, transportation, capacity availability and availability on transportation networks for other commodities, as you know, competition, weather. There are a lot of things, natural gas prices that will affect coal. We are positive that the use of coal should be increasing in the midterm if you just look at, again, the competition against natural gas, if you look at the economic pickup and the use of energy, we are confident that the use of coal should be picking up in the near midterm. And we saw that in the second to the third quarter in terms of the sequential use of coal. We will consider to price with we investable based on the value in service that we provide. And we're confident in our strategy. We're confident in the value that we're providing and we're going forward.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tom, this is Lance. Clearly, in an environment where natural gas price is increasing, put it north of $3.50 or so, and where weather is favorable and where the stockpiles have been worked down, that's a better pricing and competitive environment than not.
componenttext: Tom, this is Lance. Clearly, in an environment where natural gas price is increasing, put it north of $3.50 or so, and where weather is favorable and where the stockpiles have been worked down, that's a better pricing and competitive environment than not. So it helps.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then for the follow-up. I don't know if this is kind of Rob or Cameron. But you've shown nice improvement in the train length. Good momentum there. So that's very favorable. I'm wondering if you look at 2017, and if you do see a volume growth as
componenttext: Okay. And then for the follow-up. I don't know if this is kind of Rob or Cameron. But you've shown nice improvement in the train length. Good momentum there. So that's very favorable. I'm wondering if you look at 2017, and if you do see a volume growth as a couple of things play out, what do you see a couple of points for volume growth. How does that translate to incremental margins? Could you see something well above the kind of normal 50% incremental margin we're talking about? Could you see something 60%, 70% as you expand train length more in some of the benefits cost takeouts and so forth? Is that a reasonable equation? Or would you be more cautious about the incremental '17 if the volumes come back?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rob, why don't you take that?
componenttext: Rob, why don't you take that?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tom, this won't surprise you but we won't give guidance on the actual incremental margins. But every thing's had are certainly opportunities. As you know, our "G55 + 0" initiatives, which are  some 15 areas that our view is we're looking at every single c
componenttext: Tom, this won't surprise you but we won't give guidance on the actual incremental margins. But every thing's had are certainly opportunities. As you know, our "G55 + 0" initiatives, which are  some 15 areas that our view is we're looking at every single cost bucket in the entire company and attacking it aggressively with an eye on safety and efficiency and customer value. I would just answer that question by saying the scenario up you outlined, whether there's positive volume and a positive that's reasonably positive economic environment would give us an outstanding opportunity to continue to drive productivity and staying away from an actual incremental margin calculation, we would expect it to be a positive contributor. And by the way, for us to go from where we are today to our 60 plus or minus by 2019 and with an eye on getting to 55 assumes we're going to have very healthy incremental margins from the here to there. So we're certainly going to go after it.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tom, as we open up the door now for productivity in your question, I just want to give recognition to the entire UP team who d have done a tremendous job in a reduced volume environment of finding ways to grow, for instance, manifest train size 5% year-ov
componenttext: Tom, as we open up the door now for productivity in your question, I just want to give recognition to the entire UP team who d have done a tremendous job in a reduced volume environment of finding ways to grow, for instance, manifest train size 5% year-over-year. That's a phenomenal effort and that's just one of many in terms of finding productivity on the network. I think the team has done a tremendous job in a pretty difficult environment.

componenttext: Jason, we don't give any guidance on price. What's happening on import demand and the financial health of our international intermodal ocean carriers, that helps. What happens for industrial production in the United States, that helps. What's happening to truck capacity alternative modes, that helps. So all of those are helpful environment for our pricing.

componenttext: We, as we said, we don't give out and guidance. The one cautionary area that we talked about before is in automotive sales and cautionary that you look at even our Mexico franchise, we had great growth in our Mexico franchise in the quarter. componenttext: If I could just add to Eric on this. Our thesis for this point over the longer period is a positive volume environment. But we do feel there's great opportunity for us to continue to leverage and over the longer period of time for us to have volume on the positive side of the ledger, certainly.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes the line of Brandon Oglenski from Barclays.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a couple, I think -- a few months into this year, we've been talking about OR improvement even when volumes are down pretty significantly in the first quarter. And I know you guys backed off from that in Q2. But I guess as I listen to the call here, so
componenttext: So a couple, I think -- a few months into this year, we've been talking about OR improvement even when volumes are down pretty significantly in the first quarter. And I know you guys backed off from that in Q2. But I guess as I listen to the call here, sounds like pricing might kind of be in line would cost inflation, maybe a little bit below it next year. And let's say volume still don't come back tremendously, what can you guys do on the operating ratio that maybe we could still see some confidence that you guys would break in the lower territory.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me start, Brandon, this is Lance. And I'll remind you that we have confidence, extreme confidence in our ability to continually find opportunities to be more efficient, reduce waste and increase the value that we're adding. I'll ask Cameron just to gi
componenttext: Let me start, Brandon, this is Lance. And I'll remind you that we have confidence, extreme confidence in our ability to continually find opportunities to be more efficient, reduce waste and increase the value that we're adding. I'll ask Cameron just to give us a handful of examples of things we're working on when we're going up to next year. But our bucket is full of opportunities to be better.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: On train size, the only commodity group that is truly optimized or really optimized is coal. Every single commodities that we have out there manifest automotive to intermodal to grain, ore, rock all have tremendous opportunity for us to continue with the
componenttext: On train size, the only commodity group that is truly optimized or really optimized is coal. Every single commodities that we have out there manifest automotive to intermodal to grain, ore, rock all have tremendous opportunity for us to continue with the results that you have seen. So we feel confident that, that is going to happen in 2017. The record all-time rig crew rate from the process perspective we feel like we have well on hand. And we should continue to see that in '17 and '18. And we work on other initiatives like rationalizing our [indiscernible] power fleet. We have done a great job of moving to a single unit local operations versus 2 units. There's a number of initiatives that we have. We're truly we're just getting started in framing of the opportunity and getting ready to realize step in the new year.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Exactly. Adn even little things like sea rate, that improves 2% year-over-year. There's plenty of opportunities we look forward to become world-class if you will and consumption rate for diesel. So there's just a host of issues there, Brandon, that w
componenttext: Yes. Exactly. Adn even little things like sea rate, that improves 2% year-over-year. There's plenty of opportunities we look forward to become world-class if you will and consumption rate for diesel. So there's just a host of issues there, Brandon, that we can continue to look up.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I appreciate all that you guys have probably we can see from here. But I guess in retrospect, length, was it volume got a lot worse in the second quarter or was it competitive factors, was it market pricing? What was it that led to the lack of ability
componenttext: And I appreciate all that you guys have probably we can see from here. But I guess in retrospect, length, was it volume got a lot worse in the second quarter or was it competitive factors, was it market pricing? What was it that led to the lack of ability to drive OR improvement this year?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me let Rob handle it.
componenttext: Let me let Rob handle it.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Brandon. Your comment is right and we always said and we do believe that we can make improvements in the operating ratio in spite of the lack of volume growth. And in fact, you look at over the last decade, we've taken almost 25 points of our operati
componenttext: Yes, Brandon. Your comment is right and we always said and we do believe that we can make improvements in the operating ratio in spite of the lack of volume growth. And in fact, you look at over the last decade, we've taken almost 25 points of our operating ratio without the benefit of positive volume over that time frame. I would say your exactly right though. Here in the short-term this year, I would say that the major driver of not likely improving the operating ratio this year is the pace of what we've been kind of changing volume now. I mean, we've never have perfect visibility as to where that volume is going to trough. And that makes it difficult. So we are always,  if you will. I think that's really tacit what you're seeing this year. So as we look forward, I think it still a fair resumption and certainly a drive that we expect to make improvements in our operating ratio in spite of what the economy uses in terms of what happens with volume now. Having said that, as we look out over the next several years, we do have volume and our thesis on the positive side of the ledger. But we're going to not use that as an excuse not to make continued productivity improvements.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Scott Group with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Scott Group with Wolfe Research.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I wanted to follow up on pricing. Rob, your point about inflation picking up to 2.5% next year. Is that to caution us that pricing could be below inflation? Or is that you telling us that we have line of sight to inflation getting to higher so we have
componenttext: So I wanted to follow up on pricing. Rob, your point about inflation picking up to 2.5% next year. Is that to caution us that pricing could be below inflation? Or is that you telling us that we have line of sight to inflation getting to higher so we have line of sight to our pricing accelerating too next year. I'm not sure what you're trying to tell us?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Scott. My point on the inflationary comment is we do expect inflation to go back up, if you will, to normal levels versus the below inflation -- below normal levels  that we enjoyed this year. And again, 2.5 global inside our numbers because of the h
componenttext: Yes, Scott. My point on the inflationary comment is we do expect inflation to go back up, if you will, to normal levels versus the below inflation -- below normal levels  that we enjoyed this year. And again, 2.5 global inside our numbers because of the health and welfare cost might be higher than that. So my point of that is sadly to say not unusual against historical numbers, but we do expect inflationary pressures to be back to sort of normal conditions,  if you will.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: But because you have line of sight to inflation picking up, do you have line of sight to your pricing reaccelerating, too?
componenttext: But because you have line of sight to inflation picking up, do you have line of sight to your pricing reaccelerating, too?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say no. It's not mechanical, as you know, the way we price and the way we played so many different markets that it's not a cookie cutter. It's not a one-size-fits-all. Just as Eric outlined, there are opportunities for us to achieve stronger price
componenttext: I would say no. It's not mechanical, as you know, the way we price and the way we played so many different markets that it's not a cookie cutter. It's not a one-size-fits-all. Just as Eric outlined, there are opportunities for us to achieve stronger price than other areas in the short-term. But we will continue to drive service, drive value and price at minimum of 3 reinvestable levels as Eric outlined in spite of what that inflationary turns out to be. So I would say they're disconnected, if you will, in terms of the day-to-day pricing initiatives that we take.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So maybe just bigger picture.  It feels like for the long-term, you guys have said, "Hey, we're going to get pricing no matter what. If we get volume, okay. If we don't get volume, we don't care." And truthfully, you haven't had much volume haven't had gr
componenttext: So maybe just bigger picture.  It feels like for the long-term, you guys have said, "Hey, we're going to get pricing no matter what. If we get volume, okay. If we don't get volume, we don't care." And truthfully, you haven't had much volume haven't had great pricing. It's the philosophy changing where you care more about volume now as part of G55, and so there's -- it's less clear that you necessarily always get the pricing?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scott, our philosophy is not changing. And as a matter of fact, our top line this quarter reflects that it's not changing. We are pursuing business in the marketplace that we can price for the value that we represent. And that's reinvestable. And if we ca
componenttext: Scott, our philosophy is not changing. And as a matter of fact, our top line this quarter reflects that it's not changing. We are pursuing business in the marketplace that we can price for the value that we represent. And that's reinvestable. And if we can't find that, we walk away from it. So nothing's changed about that philosophy.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if I could just ask one more thing on grain pricing specifically. So as the rain volumes are finally, picking up, are there opportunities to start raising grain tariffs? I was a little surprised with a sequential drop in ad revenue per car this
componenttext: Okay. And if I could just ask one more thing on grain pricing specifically. So as the rain volumes are finally, picking up, are there opportunities to start raising grain tariffs? I was a little surprised with a sequential drop in ad revenue per car this quarter. I don't know if that's mix or lack of pricing there just anything specifically on grain pricing?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Scott. Some of grain pricing, as you know, are with tariffs, which are publicly available. And I think you'll see some of that sequential increase in pricing publicly available tariffs and mirror kind of the demand it's picking up in grain. I think y
componenttext: Yes, Scott. Some of grain pricing, as you know, are with tariffs, which are publicly available. And I think you'll see some of that sequential increase in pricing publicly available tariffs and mirror kind of the demand it's picking up in grain. I think you'll also see that some of the secondary markets' huge increase is kind of the valley the secondary markets  for equipment for grains. So some of that public visibility and I think if you look at those public grains, you will see pricing going with the demand increases.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes in the line of Allison Landry with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes in the line of Allison Landry with Credit Suisse.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Danny for Allison. So just coming back to pricing a little bit. I think investors are looking at the downward trend and wondering whether we could eventually see flat pricing at some point. And I think after today, we're a little bit potentially c
componenttext: This is Danny for Allison. So just coming back to pricing a little bit. I think investors are looking at the downward trend and wondering whether we could eventually see flat pricing at some point. And I think after today, we're a little bit potentially closer to that. So what can you tell investors to alleviate the concern that flat pricing is not a possibility.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just exactly what we've said this morning, which is our pricing philosophies that we looking for markets and opportunities where we can price and value that we represents. And if we can find that and have it reinvestable, we'll keep searching. As markets
componenttext: Just exactly what we've said this morning, which is our pricing philosophies that we looking for markets and opportunities where we can price and value that we represents. And if we can find that and have it reinvestable, we'll keep searching. As markets improve, as the competitive environment improves, that should translate into a environment where we have more opportunities and not. But our philosophy, our way of conducting business is not going to change.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And just switching gears on the fuel side. You discount too spot diesel prices seem to have climbed a little bit this quarter backed up to around 66%, another 300 basis points up. So should we expect this trend to continue upwards? Or in othe
componenttext: Okay, great. And just switching gears on the fuel side. You discount too spot diesel prices seem to have climbed a little bit this quarter backed up to around 66%, another 300 basis points up. So should we expect this trend to continue upwards? Or in other words, expect that discount that you received spot diesel to diminish as fuel prices go up?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rob?
componenttext: Rob?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I guess I would answer that by saying, it's hard to say. Our guidance what got the certainly, the way we look at it is as overall as diesel prices increase, we'll work hard and have good mechanisms in place to continue to maybe a timing difference. B
componenttext: Yes. I guess I would answer that by saying, it's hard to say. Our guidance what got the certainly, the way we look at it is as overall as diesel prices increase, we'll work hard and have good mechanisms in place to continue to maybe a timing difference. But our surcharges in place. So from a net impact, we work hard to minimize that. But I can't predict exactly what the delta to the spot will be.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Justin Long with Stephens.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: I wanted to ask about the OR. I know you said you're not expecting improvement this year. But do you think we'll see year-over-year improvement in the OR in the fourth quarter given what you're expecting for volumes?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: Rob, do you want to...

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As you're probably on top of your comps skew a little bit easier, if you will, in the fourth quarter, number one; and number two, we're going to continue to try the initiatives that we've been successful with this year and volumes would be easier. An
componenttext: Yes. As you're probably on top of your comps skew a little bit easier, if you will, in the fourth quarter, number one; and number two, we're going to continue to try the initiatives that we've been successful with this year and volumes would be easier. And the volumes stake flattish, as I outlined in my comments, even flattish with where they are now. We would see the fourth quarter GAAP over previous years narrowing. So having said all that, again, without giving specific precise guidance on the OR for the quarter, we certainly have an opportunity to do that.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's really helpful. And I don't want to beat a dead horse on core price. But we did see the moderation there, and it sounded like in your prepared comments, you said it was mainly due to energy and international intermodal. I was wondering if the
componenttext: Okay, that's really helpful. And I don't want to beat a dead horse on core price. But we did see the moderation there, and it sounded like in your prepared comments, you said it was mainly due to energy and international intermodal. I was wondering if there's any way to frame up how much of a headwind you saw from those 2 areas of the business? Maybe to say that was all a 50 basis points of the sequential deceleration that we saw or something like that?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Justin, this is Rob. We don't break it up that way. But I would just tell you, I mean, as you heard me say many times, we don't have a simple cookie-cutter one-price-fits-all. So all of our markets that we enjoy, and we have more markets because of the di
componenttext: Justin, this is Rob. We don't break it up that way. But I would just tell you, I mean, as you heard me say many times, we don't have a simple cookie-cutter one-price-fits-all. So all of our markets that we enjoy, and we have more markets because of the diversity of our franchises than many, gives us opportunities. And it's -- the pricing opportunities for us are very diverse. But having said that, we don't break out the way you're asking it.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Chris Wetherbee with Citi Group.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Chris Wetherbee with Citi Group.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I do just need that back price get I apologize I know it's been through you talked about it this morning, but just 1 thought on renewals. You guys reported core pricing be a little bit different than some of your peers. And I guess I just wanted to get a
componenttext: I do just need that back price get I apologize I know it's been through you talked about it this morning, but just 1 thought on renewals. You guys reported core pricing be a little bit different than some of your peers. And I guess I just wanted to get a rough sense of the relationship between inflation and the renewal dynamic. And I know it's not mechanical and it kind of highlight at that. But generally speaking, in a higher inflationary environment, would you expect renewals would accelerate as well and how much maybe of the Latvia think that there is. I'm guess I'm just try to get a rough sense regardless of the magnitude directionally I'm guessing there were together I just wanted to get some color around that would be great.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Chris. There would be just a couple of comments I would make. Number one, as I think you and others know, we have 5% of our business, if you will, is affected by a lift. So over a longer period of time, that mechanism sort of be maybe lumpy from quar
componenttext: Yes, Chris. There would be just a couple of comments I would make. Number one, as I think you and others know, we have 5% of our business, if you will, is affected by a lift. So over a longer period of time, that mechanism sort of be maybe lumpy from quarter-to-quarter but over a longer period of time, it tends to reflect what's happening with rail inflation, number one. But I guess -- I would broadly be saying, we currently price and as you all have for me say for many years, very proud of the fact that we are very conservative in terms of how we currently price. It is not a same-store sales kind of number. It is a mathematical calculation of how many dollars we yielded in that particular quarter from our pricing actions and the denominators are our entire book of business. So it includes contracts that perhaps we didn't touch certainly in the quarter for pricing. So having said that, there tends to be a little bit of a lead lag, if you will, in terms of the yield dollars that come from our pricing actions. But again, our focus is unchanged from what it's been at this point in time. We've got a couple of markets out there that are particularly challenging. Our commitment to driving value, driving quality service and driving positive pricing -- positive volumes or positive margins has not changed.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then switching gears and a follow-up on the front coal side. Eric, you had mentioned, I think, 27 days -- inventories are 27 days above average, I believe, is what you highlighted there. What do you think is the right number is i
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then switching gears and a follow-up on the front coal side. Eric, you had mentioned, I think, 27 days -- inventories are 27 days above average, I believe, is what you highlighted there. What do you think is the right number is in terms of the go-forward period? What is the natural gas curve is weather has been a factor over the summer. We don't know what it will be like winter. But what you think that right number is? How close are you guys getting towards normalized inventories, you think?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, to think about Powder River Basin inventories 5-year average is, as I said, was below 60s, 63, 65. And right now, we're still at 90s. So that's how you get to 27 days. I do think that 60-ish number is probably right. We have normal weather patterns
componenttext: Well, to think about Powder River Basin inventories 5-year average is, as I said, was below 60s, 63, 65. And right now, we're still at 90s. So that's how you get to 27 days. I do think that 60-ish number is probably right. We have normal weather patterns and normal cold winter. If you look at the natural gas futures curve, I think, right now, it's like 3 40 in the early part of next year. That will drive the inventories down. That will drive usage of coal. Coal market share in the quarter was 32% compared to like 28%, I think, in the second quarter. So coal market share has grown I think. It will be in a good place, good position. You would see good coal volumes grow coal pricings inventories go down and I think will be in a better place.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And one thing to note. You can get to that day's inventory reduction adjustment a number of ways. You think about what's happening in the coal world in a different perspective on a stock level of, call it, 80 million tons of SPRB coal. We're about 3 milli
componenttext: And one thing to note. You can get to that day's inventory reduction adjustment a number of ways. You think about what's happening in the coal world in a different perspective on a stock level of, call it, 80 million tons of SPRB coal. We're about 3 million tons higher year-over-year. And that represents, as Eric said, 25 days a burn. So it really doesn't take much in both how much you have in stock and how much we are burning to affect that days ratio. You can get the number of ways.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's really helpful. And real quick. did you say what the coal output volume within the low single-digit decline in the fourth quarter?
componenttext: That's really helpful. And real quick. did you say what the coal output volume within the low single-digit decline in the fourth quarter?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We didn't, Chris. But it's in the, call it, in the low-teens is probably a reasonable assumption. Down low-teens.
componenttext: We didn't, Chris. But it's in the, call it, in the low-teens is probably a reasonable assumption. Down low-teens.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Brian Ossenbeck from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Brian Ossenbeck from JPMorgan.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Lance, just wanted to get your views on  just on the regulatory backdrop. Obviously, there's been a lot of things coming out of the SGP they had there [indiscernible] consulting, recently that's in use of it. GL about the ECP brakes. But just looking at t
componenttext: Lance, just wanted to get your views on  just on the regulatory backdrop. Obviously, there's been a lot of things coming out of the SGP they had there [indiscernible] consulting, recently that's in use of it. GL about the ECP brakes. But just looking at the next year. It seems like it'll still be a fairly busy on the docket. I just wanted to get your thoughts if there would be any potential impacts, changes in regulations in 2017 that you would be particularly focused on?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brian, thank for that question. We are focused on the activity at the STV that's largely driven by the reauthorization from Congress about 1 year ago. In that reauthorization, Congress has essentially encouraged the STV to work through their docket. They
componenttext: Brian, thank for that question. We are focused on the activity at the STV that's largely driven by the reauthorization from Congress about 1 year ago. In that reauthorization, Congress has essentially encouraged the STV to work through their docket. They have a backlog of a fair number of action items. Our concern is that, that's interpreted as a desire to regulate the industry further. We don't believe that is the desire of Congress. We think Congress to have the work through their workload. So we've got our eyeballs and are working on different activities. Things like the reciprocals switching roles or the reduction of exemptions of different commodity groups. We're touching all the right points and making sure our perspective this known and Incorporated into the thought process. There's a lot of moving parts there so it's taken a fair amount of work on my part on our legal team and on our Washington team. I would say our largest concern with the kind of overwriting overall impact of each individual regulation. If the STB takes those in isolation, we could end up that is unintended and unconsidered. So we're also working hard to making sure that the STB takes into account the full perspective of everything they're working on and knocked on the impacts of each as a group. Does that make sense?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it does. And it's been helpful, I think. I think if you potential activists does seem like a docket this they did to move forward a bit. Just one real quick question for Eric on the engine impact. You mentioned the $13 million write-off. I was just c
componenttext: Yes, it does. And it's been helpful, I think. I think if you potential activists does seem like a docket this they did to move forward a bit. Just one real quick question for Eric on the engine impact. You mentioned the $13 million write-off. I was just curious if there's any operational issues you've been seeing as those containers come on shore and people move on anything from the chassis charters that we've been hearing little bit about that's a concern clearly there's a lot of puts and takes in the international intermodal side now?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Brian. So Union Pacific, I think, has weathered a lot of what I call the operational fall out from the bankruptcy fairly well. On a high level that they went bankrupt, they roughly had about 100 ships on the -- and flows around the world. 40 owned ab
componenttext: Yes, Brian. So Union Pacific, I think, has weathered a lot of what I call the operational fall out from the bankruptcy fairly well. On a high level that they went bankrupt, they roughly had about 100 ships on the -- and flows around the world. 40 owned about 60 leased, and there are lots of issues in terms of what to do with all the in traffic  flow there were still roughly $14 billion worth of goods and traffic flows, lots of issues about what's keeping with that. We had a fairly nominal number of boxes and route on our railroad. And we've been able to process all of those through. We probably have a couple of those left to process through from roughly, probably a little over 1,000 of bankruptcy. So we navigated that well. There are issues out there in navigating the rest of that. And I mean it is an issue for the industry and supply chain in terms of what to do with those boxes, both loaded and empty boxes on chassis what to do with those. And that's something that the industry is going to be struggling with the result. But for the Union Pacific side, we've navigated that fairly well.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of John Larkin with Stifel.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of John Larkin with Stifel.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had a question on coal. Q2, you said a couple of thousand stockpiles are still well above kind of targeted levels. Yet sequentially, there was a huge step up in coal volume to, in theory, replenished stockpiles down during the hotter-than-normal summer.
componenttext: I had a question on coal. Q2, you said a couple of thousand stockpiles are still well above kind of targeted levels. Yet sequentially, there was a huge step up in coal volume to, in theory, replenished stockpiles down during the hotter-than-normal summer. Was that very specific to a few different utilities? Or what really drove that? It seems a little contradictory to make that comment that coal will be up sequentially although stockpiles are still on average way above normal.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Eric, could you handle that?
componenttext: Eric, could you handle that?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The stockpiles are common down. If you look at over the second to the third quarter, stockpiles have come down 13 days. And  again, it came down because burning trees. So our volumes improved roughly 40% and the stockpiles came down because the burn
componenttext: Yes. The stockpiles are common down. If you look at over the second to the third quarter, stockpiles have come down 13 days. And  again, it came down because burning trees. So our volumes improved roughly 40% and the stockpiles came down because the burn increase at a higher percent in that.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So it doesn't sound like all that dedicated to drawing those stockpiles down that aggressively if they're replenishing still fairly aggressively there in the third quarter. Just one more question. The U.S. dollar has been sitting at elevated levels
componenttext: Okay. So it doesn't sound like all that dedicated to drawing those stockpiles down that aggressively if they're replenishing still fairly aggressively there in the third quarter. Just one more question. The U.S. dollar has been sitting at elevated levels relative to foreign currencies now for 1 year or longer. What's your outlook on that for the rest of this year and throughout 2017, and the impact it might have on exports, which are so critical and sort of the bulk side of your business?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, John. This is Lance. You're right, dollar has been strong. We don't make a prediction about what the dollar is going to be going forward. You got a believe on all reasonable expectations are it's going to continue to make it remain strong. In order t
componenttext: Yes, John. This is Lance. You're right, dollar has been strong. We don't make a prediction about what the dollar is going to be going forward. You got a believe on all reasonable expectations are it's going to continue to make it remain strong. In order to change that, you need real acceleration in the global market, which would and has a strength of other currencies. There's just not a lot of catalysts the PC for that. To your point, strong dollar does make exports difficult, however, even in today's world you see, for instance, grain exporting off Pacific Northwest and the Gulf coast and into Mexico despite a strong dollar, so market conditions can still prompt commodity movement and global trade. And the other thing to note is that the U.S. is unique in its ability for its manufacturing base to figure out how to be globally competitive over time. I think the shale energy revolution is indicative of that, where a couple of years ago, people would say $70 a barrel of shale oil was competitive and in today's world, no, they say that would be more like $50 a barrel. So there's a lot of moving parts there. Clearly, we would prefer an acceleration in the global economy, which would prompt more global trade, which would mean more U.S. exports. That all will be really helpful for us.

componenttext: Yes, Walter. This is Lance. Again, I won't compare ourselves to our peers. We're a unique railroad. When we began the year, we were hopeful we were going to make OR improvement. The top line went away from us, as Rob said, a little more aggressively than we had anticipated. If you think about our ability to improve OR over the long run, we're still confident that we can do it as shown in our maintaining the guidance for a plus-minus 60 in 2019. We did start the year with a very low operating ratio. It's still unattractive operating ratio. We're not pleased that wouldn't have the opportunity to improve this year. And again, we're just laser-focused on all the activity necessary to continue to improve our margins for our shareholders.

componenttext: So coming back to your long-term then. I mean, from where you sit today, that's a 900 basis points improvement. It's a significant improvement. componenttext: Yes, Walter. I guess I would remind you and everyone that we are confident in sticking with our 60 plus-or-minus target OR by full year 2019. And as you heard us talk, with eyes and go beyond that 55. What we have and have a date on 55. But I would just say that getting to a 60 is a very enviable spot in my opinion. I mean, we've made great progress on that. So I would not read that this 1 year of perhaps not making OR improvement is a new trend or a new objective when you signal here. It's not. To get from where we are today to that 60 is going to take all we just talked about and the sustained levers that got us 25 point improvement over the last decade. So we're going to continue to make that progress, and we haven't backed off our 60 OR guidance.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the Panama Canal story is right. We've been saying for the last several years and certainly, I think the last couple of quarters, we've been mentioning that the amount of traffic for hitting the West Coast versus East Coast did west traffic that m
componenttext: I think the Panama Canal story is right. We've been saying for the last several years and certainly, I think the last couple of quarters, we've been mentioning that the amount of traffic for hitting the West Coast versus East Coast did west traffic that moved to the East Coast because of the strike and the zeal is trying to diversify the risk and not being dependent upon the West Coast. We did see that phenomenon. We have seen some of that business start to come back. But it hasn't all come back from before the strike. That is probably been a larger factor than any canal opening factor. The fact that the be seals are diversifying and flows at a lot of different ways have that risk. Having said all of that, we do believe -- I do believe that the West Coast ports are the most economical supply chain intends to have transit time to get goods from Asia to the interior of the country and even to the East Coast. If you look at some of the technologies at some of the West Coast ports are employing to make themselves more efficient with our tongues vehicles and things like that, I think West Coast ports is still going to be positioned as the best supply chain factor going into the future. Though you will see people running through risk mitigation strategies.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to the Union Pacific Third Quarter 2016 Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded, and the slides for today's presentation are available on Union Pacific's website.It is now my pleas
componenttext:
Greetings, and welcome to the Union Pacific Third Quarter 2016 Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded, and the slides for today's presentation are available on Union Pacific's website.
It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Mr. Lance Fritz, Chairman, President and CEO for Union Pacific. Thank you. Mr. Fritz, you may begin.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everybody, and welcome to Union Pacific's Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. With me here today in Omaha are Eric Butler, Chief Marketing Officer; Cameron Scott, Chief Operating Officer; and Rob Knight, Chief Financial Officer.This mo
componenttext:
Good morning, everybody, and welcome to Union Pacific's Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. With me here today in Omaha are Eric Butler, Chief Marketing Officer; Cameron Scott, Chief Operating Officer; and Rob Knight, Chief Financial Officer.
This morning, Union Pacific is reporting net income of $1.1 billion for the third quarter of 2016. This equates to $1.36 per share, which compares to $1.50 in the third quarter of 2015. Total volume decreased 6% in the quarter compared to 2015. Carload volume declined in 5 of our 6 commodity groups, with Coal and Industrial Products both down double digits. Agricultural Product volumes were up a robust 11% this quarter versus 2015, as grain shipments finally started to show some strength.
The quarterly operating ratio came in at 62.1%, which is up 1.8 percentage points from the record third quarter last year, but improved 3.1 percentage points from the second quarter of this year. Continued momentum from our productivity initiatives as well as positive core pricing helped partially offset the decline in total carload volumes. While many of the same volume challenges have continued throughout the year, we are keeping a laser focus on our 6 value tracks. This strategy ensures we provide our customers with an excellent value proposition and service experience, while efficiently and safely managing our resources.
Our team will give you more of the details, starting with Eric.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lance, and good morning. In the third quarter, our volume was down 6%, with near-record Agricultural Products shipments more than offset by declines in each of the business groups. We generated core pricing gains of 1.5% in the quarter, reflecting
componenttext:
Thanks, Lance, and good morning. In the third quarter, our volume was down 6%, with near-record Agricultural Products shipments more than offset by declines in each of the business groups. We generated core pricing gains of 1.5% in the quarter, reflecting the impacts of competitive markets in a weak economic environment, particularly in our energy-related and international Intermodal businesses. Despite these challenges, we continue to achieve solid reinvestable returns even in these difficult markets and remain committed to achieving positive core pricing gains that reflect our value proposition over the long term. The decline in volume and the 2% lower average revenue per car drove a 7% reduction in freight revenue.
Let's take a closer look at the performance for each of our 6 business groups. Ag Products revenue gained 6% on an 11% volume increase and a 4% decrease in average revenue per car. A robust U.S. grain supply and lower commodity prices generated export strength and lifted grain volumes 27% in the quarter. Wheat exports rebounded in the second half of the quarter, as adverse weather in South America caused significant losses, elevating demand for the higher protein U.S. wheat. Grain products carloads advanced 5% in the quarter, primarily due to increased ethanol exports and biodiesel shipments. Food and refrigerated carloads were flat in the quarter, as strong demand for import beer offset softness in refrigerated food shipments and import sugar. 
Automotive revenue was down 8% in the quarter, driven by a 2% decrease in volume and a 6% reduction in average revenue per car. Finished vehicle shipments decreased 7% by sales and production levels of passenger vehicles, impacting key Union Pacific-served plants and contract changes we referenced last quarter that will continue to impact our volumes through the first part of 2017. In total, finished vehicle sales in the quarter were at a seasonally adjusted average rate of 17.5 million, up 2% from the second quarter, but down 2% from the 2015 third quarter. On the parts side, the continued focus on over-the-road conversions drove a 5% increase in volume.
Chemicals revenue was down 1% for the quarter on a 1% decrease in volume and a 1% increase in average revenue per car. We continue to see headwinds on crude oil shipments, which were down 48% due to lower crude oil prices, regional pricing differences and available pipeline capacity. Chemicals volume, excluding crude oil shipments, was up 2% in the quarter. Partially offsetting the declines in crude oil was strength in other areas, including industrial chemicals, which was up 3% in the quarter.
Coal revenue declined 19% for the quarter on a 14% decrease in volume and 6% decline in average revenue per car. Sequentially, however, overall coal tonnage increased 40% from the second quarter of this year. Powder River Basin and Colorado/Utah tonnage declined 17% and 16%, respectively, in the quarter as increased demands from a warmer-than-average summer was unable to offset high coal stockpiles. PRB coal inventory levels in September were 90 days, down 13 days from June, but still 27 days above the 5-year average. 
Industrial Products revenue was down 13% on an 11% decline in volume and a 2% decrease in average revenue per car during the quarter. Minerals volume was down 22% in the quarter, driven by 26% decrease in frac sand carloadings, impacted by lower crude oil prices and decreased drilling activity. Construction Products volume was down 8% due to weather-impacted construction activity in the South. The strong U.S. dollar, weak commodity pricing and increased imports pushed metal shipments down 13% year-over-year. 
Intermodal revenue was down 9% on a 7% decline in volume and a 2% decrease in average revenue per car. Domestic Intermodal volume declined 2% in the quarter. Excluding headwinds from the previously discussed discontinuation of Triple Crown Service, domestic was nearly flat. International volumes were down 11% in the quarter as the industry continue to face significant headwinds from weaker global trade activity, softer domestic sales, high retail inventory and the Hanjin bankruptcy.
To wrap up, let's take a look at our outlook. In Ag Products, we expect a healthy U.S. harvest and strong world demand for U.S. grain to drive favorable export trends. Grain products will continue to be strong, driven by ethanol exports. In food and refrigerated, we expect continued strength in beer imports.
Turning to autos, light vehicle sales are forecasted to finish 2016 at 17.4 million, down less than 0.5% from the 2015 record rate of 17.5 million. Although we expect sales incentives, low gasoline prices and consumer preference will continue to drive demand, we remain cautious with respect to auto sales sustaining at these levels. A continued focus on over-the-road conversions will support auto parts growth. 
Our Chemicals franchise is expected to remain stable with strength in LPG and industrial chemicals, offset by declines in crude oil. Coal volumes will continue to be impacted by natural gas prices, high inventory levels and export demand. As always, weather conditions will be a key factor of demand.
In Industrial Products, lower crude prices and reduced drilling activity are expected to continue to challenge minerals volumes. We anticipate a softer year-end for metals as imports continue to impact domestic shipments and customers manage year-end inventories. We expect lumber to be stronger in the fourth quarter as housing starts continue to expand. 
Finally, in Intermodal, our international volumes will continue to be adversely impacted by a strained ocean carrier industry, offset partially by over-the-road highway conversions. In the face of a number of uncertainties in the worldwide economy, our diverse franchise remains well-positioned for growth as the economy slowly improves. We remain committed to strengthening our customer value proposition and driving new business opportunities.
With that, I'll turn it over to Cameron for an update on our operating performance.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Eric, and good morning. Starting with our safety performance. Our year-to-date reportable personal injury rate improved 16% versus 2015 to a record low 0.77.  Included in this was a record-low number of severe injuries, which have the greatest hum
componenttext:
Thanks, Eric, and good morning. Starting with our safety performance. Our year-to-date reportable personal injury rate improved 16% versus 2015 to a record low 0.77.  Included in this was a record-low number of severe injuries, which have the greatest human and financial impact. Although we continue to make significant improvement, we won't be satisfied until we reach our goal of 0 incidents, getting every one of our employees home safely at the end of each day.
With respect to rail equipment incidents or derailments, our year-to-date reportable rate of 3.13 improved 4% versus last year. While we made only a slight improvement on the reportable rate, enhanced TE&Y training and continued infrastructure investment helped significantly reduce the absolute number of incidents, including those who do not meet the reportable threshold to a record low.
In public safety, our grade crossing incident rate increased 13% to 2.55. We continue to focus on driving improvement by reinforcing public awareness through various channels, including public safety campaigns and community partnerships. 
Moving to network performance. While the California wildfires and flooding along various parts of our network created some challenges during the quarter, our network proved resilient as we continue to achieve solid operating performance. Effective use of our surge locomotive fleet and TE&Y workforce were critical to minimize the impact of these network challenges. As reported to the AAR, velocity improved 2% when compared to the third quarter of 2015.  Terminal dwell also improved 2%, but the benefits of a fluid network were somewhat offset by productivity gains, such as longer train lengths and other network management initiatives. 
Moving on to resources. As part of our ongoing business planning process, we continue to adjust resource levels to account for volume changes and productivity gains. As a result, our total TE&Y workforce was down 14% when compared to the same quarter last year, but up 2% sequentially from the second quarter to efficiently handle the 8% volume increase experienced since the end of June. We also continue to evaluate all other aspects of the business with the goal of driving productivity throughout the organization. This includes the rightsizing of our engineering and mechanical workforce, which was down a combined 1,900 employees or 9% versus the third quarter of last year. Our active locomotive fleet was down 9% from the third quarter of 2015, but up 2% sequentially to handle the increase in carloads.
As you know, we've been planning for the acquisition of 230 new locomotives this year. We now expect that number to be 200 locomotives this year, with the delivery of 30 units delayed into 2017. This would add to the 70 units previously scheduled in 2017 for a total of 100 next year. We're adjusting our 2016 capital program down about $100 million to just under $3.6 billion, primarily driven by this change in locomotive deliveries.
Turning to network productivity. While we remain focused on effectively balancing our resources, we also continue to realize efficiency gains through several productivity initiatives. Train length is a significant productivity driver and a primary focus area for us. During the quarter, our manifest and grain networks were in at all-time record train length levels, while our automotive network set a third quarter record.
Recrew rate, a cost incurred when the first crew has insufficient time to complete the trip, is an indicative measure of the fluidity and productivity of our network. Our third quarter recrew rate was 2.3%, a near-2-point improvement from 2015 and the third quarter record.
As we move forward, we expect our safety strategy will continue yielding positive results on our way to an incident-free environment. And where growth opportunities arise, we'll leverage that growth to the bottom line through increased utilization of existing assets, while maintaining our intense focus on productivity and efficiency across the network.
With that, I'll turn it over to Rob.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, and good morning. Let's start with a recap of our third quarter results. Operating revenue was about $5.2 billion in the quarter, down 7% versus last year. Lower volumes and lower fuel surcharges more than offset positive core pricing achieved in
componenttext:
Thanks, and good morning. Let's start with a recap of our third quarter results. Operating revenue was about $5.2 billion in the quarter, down 7% versus last year. Lower volumes and lower fuel surcharges more than offset positive core pricing achieved in the quarter. Operating expenses totaled just over $3.2 billion. Lower fuel costs, volume-related reductions and strong productivity improvements drove the 4% improvement compared to last year. 
Operating income totaled almost $2 billion, an 11% decrease from last year. Below the line, other income totaled $29 million, roughly flat versus 2015. Interest expense of $184 million was up 17% compared to the previous year. The increase was driven by additional debt issuance over the last 12 months as well as about $8 million for the fees associated with our recent debt exchange transaction. This increase was partially offset by a lower effective interest rate.
Income tax expense decreased about 14% to $674 million, driven primarily by lower pretax earnings. Net income totaled just over $1.1 billion, down 13% versus 2015, while the outstanding share balance declined 4% as a result of our continued share repurchase activity. These results combined to produce quarterly earnings of $1.36 per share. 
Turning now to our top line. Freight revenue of $4.8 billion was down 7% versus last year, primarily driven by a 6% decline in volumes. Fuel surcharge revenue totaled $173 million, down $141 million when compared to 2015, but up $86 million from the second quarter of this year. All in, we estimate the net impact of lower fuel prices was a $0.05 headwind to earnings in the third quarter versus last year. The business mix impact on freight revenue in the third quarter was about flat, similar to what we experienced in the second quarter.
Year-over-year growth in agricultural product shipments and declines in international intermodal volumes were positive contributors to mix, which were offset by declines in industrial products and finished vehicles volumes. Core price was a positive contributor to freight revenue in the quarter at about 1.5%. 
Slide 21 provides more detail in our pricing trends. As Eric just mentioned, pricing gains this quarter reflect the competitive marketplace in a soft economic environment. Going forward, we remain committed to our focus on positive return-driven core pricing, which reflects the value proposition that we provide our customers.
Moving on to the expense side. Slide 22 provides a summary of our compensation and benefits expense, which decreased 6% versus 2015. The decrease was primarily driven by a combination of lower volumes, improved labor efficiencies and fewer people in the training pipeline. General wage and benefit inflation partially offset these decreases. Labor inflation was about 3% in the third quarter, driven primarily by general wage increases and health and welfare expense, which were partially offset by some favorable pension costs. We still expect full year labor inflation to be about 2% and overall inflation to be about 1.5% for the year.
As a result of lower volumes, solid productivity gains and a smaller capital workforce, total workforce levels declined 10% in the quarter year-over-year or more than 4,700 employees. Looking sequentially, total workforce levels were down about 1% from the second quarter of this year. For the fourth quarter, we expect our force levels to be similar to the third quarter and also down somewhat from the prior year as comps get a little bit more difficult. 
Turning to the next slide. Fuel expense totaled $392 million, down 19% when compared to 2015. Lower diesel fuel prices, along with a 6% decline in gross ton-miles, drove the decrease in fuel expense for the quarter. Compared to the third quarter of last year, our fuel consumption rate improved 2% to a record $1.075, while our average fuel price declined 13% to $1.57 per gallon. 
Moving on to our other expense categories. Purchased services and materials expense decreased 4% to $566 million. The reduction was primarily driven by lower volume-related expense and reduced locomotive and freight car repair and maintenance costs. Depreciation expense was $512 million, up 1% compared to 2015, driven primarily by higher depreciable asset base. For the full year, we still expect depreciation expense to increase slightly compared to last year.
Slide 25 summarizes the remaining 2 expense categories. Equipment and other rents expense totaled $282 million, which is down 7% when compared to 2015. Lower volumes, which reduced car hire expense, and reduced locomotive lease costs were the primary drivers of this decline. Other expenses came in at $271 million, up $66 million versus last year. We did have a couple of one-time items impacting the other expense category in the third quarter as well as a few favorable items that we incurred last year.
As we discussed back in September, we have written off the $13 million accounts receivables associated with the Hanjin bankruptcy. In addition, we also incurred $17 million of write-offs associated with in-progress capital projects, which we are no longer pursuing. Higher state and local taxes and increased environmental costs, partially offset by lower personal injury expense, also contributed to the negative variance in this category for the quarter. For the full year 2016, we now expect the other expense line item to increase close to 10%, including the one-time items that I just mentioned.
Turning to our operating ratio. The third quarter operating ratio came in at 62.1%, 1.8 points unfavorable when compared to the record third quarter of 2015. Fuel price negatively impacted the operating ratio by 0.4 points in the quarter.
Looking at cash flow. Cash from operations for the first 3 quarters totaled about $5.5 billion, down about $160 million when compared to the same period last year. The decrease in cash was driven by lower net income and was partially offset by the timing of tax payments, primarily related to the bonus depreciation on our capital spending. For the full year 2016, we now expect the net impact of bonus depreciation to be a tailwind of about $350 million. After dividends, our free cash flow totaled about $1.3 billion year-to-date through the end of September.
Taking a look now at the balance sheet. Our all-in debt -- adjusted debt balance increased to about $18.5 billion at quarter-end. We finished the third quarter with an adjusted debt-to-EBITDA ratio of over 1.9x, up from 1.7x at year-end. This brings us close to our target ratio of less than 2x. 
For the first 9 months of the year, we bought back over 25 million shares, totaling about $2.2 billion. Since initiating share repurchases in 2007, we have repurchased about 28% of our outstanding shares. Between our dividend payments and our share repurchases, we returned nearly $3.6 billion to our shareholders through the first 3 quarters of this year.
So that's a recap of the third quarter results. Looking out to the remainder of the year, volume declines on a year-over-year basis should moderate as the volume comparisons get easier in the fourth quarter. We would expect total fourth quarter volumes to be down in the low single digits, and we still expect total full year volumes to be down in the 6% to 8% range. While we do not expect to improve the operating ratio this year, we will continue to leverage our G55 + 0 initiatives to generate positive core pricing and strong productivity to achieve the lowest operating ratio possible.
And as Cam just mentioned, we now expect 2016 capital spending to be down about $100 million to just under $3.6 billion, primarily as a result of the delay in the locomotive deliveries. While we have not yet finalized our capital plans for 2017, we still expect our capital spending to be around 15% of revenue. 
From a productivity perspective, our G55 + 0 initiatives have generated significant efficiency savings for the company thus far this year. And we are confident that we will continue to drive further improvement well into the future as we work toward our operating ratio target of 60%, plus or minus, on a full year basis by 2019. And longer term, we are keeping our eye on the goal of a 55% operating ratio as we gain momentum with our G55 + 0 initiatives.
So with that, I'll turn it back over to Lance.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rob. As the team has articulated here this morning, we continued to experience a difficult but improving market environment in the third quarter. While we were pleased to see improving volumes in some of our business lines, such as grain and co
componenttext:
Thank you, Rob. As the team has articulated here this morning, we continued to experience a difficult but improving market environment in the third quarter. While we were pleased to see improving volumes in some of our business lines, such as grain and coal, many of our markets still remained at volume levels below a year ago. The macroeconomic environment still has its challenges: an unstable global economy, the relatively strong U.S. dollar and continued soft demand for consumer goods.
However, certain segments of the economy are showing signs of life. The recent rally in energy prices has crude oil over $50 a barrel and natural gas over $3 per million BTU, which are both encouraging for our coal and shale-related businesses. We are also pleased to see strength in the overall grain market. With a record harvest currently underway, we are well-positioned with our network and resources to serve an increase in demand from our ag customers.
Closing out 2016 and heading into next year, we're optimistic about the opportunities that lie ahead. In the coming months, we'll continue to do what Union Pacific does best: operate a safe, efficient and productive network, while providing an excellent customer experience and delivering solid shareholder returns.
With that, let's open up the line for your questions.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is coming from the line of Ken Hoexter with Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is coming from the line of Ken Hoexter with Merrill Lynch.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just can you, Rob, talk a little bit about the projects you're writing off? I just want to understand what kind of costs we have going forward. And it looks like, as the business comes back, you're starting to ramp up your locomotives and employees. But y
componenttext: Just can you, Rob, talk a little bit about the projects you're writing off? I just want to understand what kind of costs we have going forward. And it looks like, as the business comes back, you're starting to ramp up your locomotives and employees. But you noticed that there are fewer people in the training pipeline. Should we see some start-up costs as you start to bring people back in?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ken. What I commented in the quarter is it was around $17 million of projects that were started that we have chosen to not pursue, and so we're taking adjustment there. So I think if you look longer term, that's a number that is not going to be repea
componenttext: Yes, Ken. What I commented in the quarter is it was around $17 million of projects that were started that we have chosen to not pursue, and so we're taking adjustment there. So I think if you look longer term, that's a number that is not going to be repeat. I mean, we occasionally will have situations like that. But I think it's safe to assume that that's a number similar to the Hanjin receivables write-off that I mentioned that are not going to repeat in that line item. In terms of the cost, we're confident that we are well-situated, both on locomotives and employees, to leverage the volume that we hope does materialize. So we've got fewer people on training line because we've got so many people, if you will, in furlough status at this point. So we feel very good about our ability to and we'd love nothing more than to see volume pick up and be able to put resources back to work.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Cherilyn Radbourne with TD Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Cherilyn Radbourne with TD Securities.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: With the international shipping lines under continued financial pressures you noted and the prospect of a record grain crop matched back to something that I've been hearing more about, just curious if that's something that you are facilitating and potenti
componenttext: With the international shipping lines under continued financial pressures you noted and the prospect of a record grain crop matched back to something that I've been hearing more about, just curious if that's something that you are facilitating and potentially see the means to increase market share in intermodal or grain or both?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Eric?
componenttext: Eric?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As you mentioned, Cherilyn, there's a significant volatility going on in the international container ship business. There have been 3 major mergers, 1 bankruptcy. There are a number of other entities that are in dire or questionable financial shape.
componenttext: Yes. As you mentioned, Cherilyn, there's a significant volatility going on in the international container ship business. There have been 3 major mergers, 1 bankruptcy. There are a number of other entities that are in dire or questionable financial shape. One of the things that all of the container ship companies are looking at doing is finding ways to have match-backs or exports from the U.S. to Asia. One of the large historical exports has been grain, in particular, DDGs to China. We are continuing to look at that as an opportunity to grow our business in terms of the westbound business to Asia. We're also really excited longer term or midterm in terms of the opportunity to ship plastics to Asia from the expanding franchise we have in the Gulf. And we think that that's going to be an excellent opportunity for match-backs also. So we think both of those things are great opportunities. Of course, China, occasionally, as they have right now, has tariffs or other governmental policy things that hinder imports like DDGs; but we think, long term, that should be opportunity for us.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Cherilyn, this is Lance. What Eric just outlined is indicative of the franchise strength that the Union Pacific brings to the industry. We've got breadth and coverage in a number of markets that allow us visibility in the potential match-backs.
componenttext: Cherilyn, this is Lance. What Eric just outlined is indicative of the franchise strength that the Union Pacific brings to the industry. We've got breadth and coverage in a number of markets that allow us visibility in the potential match-backs.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And just by ways of very quick follow-up. When you say medium to long term on the plastics match-backs, is that sort of 2018 and belong -- and beyond?
componenttext: Great. And just by ways of very quick follow-up. When you say medium to long term on the plastics match-backs, is that sort of 2018 and belong -- and beyond?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, we -- as we've been saying for the last several quarters, we think what happened in 2018 and beyond there might be a tale of a similar ramp-up toward the end of 2017, but basically 2018 and beyond.
componenttext: Yes. I mean, we -- as we've been saying for the last several quarters, we think what happened in 2018 and beyond there might be a tale of a similar ramp-up toward the end of 2017, but basically 2018 and beyond.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Ravi Shanker with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Ravi Shanker with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions on pricing. You've committed to a positive core pricing. Can you also commit to pricing over inflation? And second, can you just help us understand what the driver of the pricing, I'd say, the deterioration of the gains has been, is
componenttext: A couple of questions on pricing. You've committed to a positive core pricing. Can you also commit to pricing over inflation? And second, can you just help us understand what the driver of the pricing, I'd say, the deterioration of the gains has been, is it mostly into rail competition? Is it truck competition? Or is it you guys kind of just supporting some of your customers who may be going through a hard time and hoping to get it back a little later on?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Eric?
componenttext: Eric?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ravi. So one of the things that we are really excited about is the great franchise we have, and we have a very diverse franchise. And some components of our franchise, obviously, as we mentioned, the energy-related and the international-related are f
componenttext: Yes, Ravi. So one of the things that we are really excited about is the great franchise we have, and we have a very diverse franchise. And some components of our franchise, obviously, as we mentioned, the energy-related and the international-related are facing both economic weakness conditions and also some competitive conditions. So we've been talking about the challenges in coal. Coal, as you know, has been greatly challenged not by demand because of weather and other usage demands, but natural gas has been a great -- a strong competitor to coal. The low -- below $2 natural gas prices has created a headwind for coal in the past. We're excited -- or we think that with natural gas being above $3 now and even some of the futures market showing it in the mid-3s that, that certainly will improve the competitive condition for coal. But that has clearly had an impact. Likewise, the 3 major bankrupts -- or the 3 major mergers, the 1 large bankruptcy in the international intermodal, the volatility that we talked about in previous earnings releases has created economic conditions and competitive conditions in international intermodal. Even despite those challenges in those markets, we still have been able to put our market price at reinvestable returns. And we think that looking at the broadness of our portfolio, we are pretty positive in the future about our ability to price for the excellent value we provide, and we are going to price above reinvestable returns. And we have a broad portfolio of opportunities to drive that message.

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you also -- do you have the confidence that you can stay above inflation and pricing?
componenttext: Can you also -- do you have the confidence that you can stay above inflation and pricing?

headline: Union Pacific Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ravi, this is Rob. Let me answer that. I mean, clearly, long term, that is still our goal. The one thing with these challenges that -- and opportunities that Eric just outlined, one of the things that we haven't finalized yet as we look into 2017, at this
